PREFACE 
This Code constitutes a complete recodification of the general and permanent ordinances of the City of Hialeah Gardens, Florida. 
Source materials used in the preparation of the Code were the 1985 Code, as supplemented through October 10, 1989, and ordinances subsequently adopted by the city council. The source of each section is included in the history note appearing in parentheses at the end thereof. The absence of such a note indicates that the section is new and was adopted for the first time with the adoption of the Code. By use of the comparative tables appearing in the back of this Code, the reader can locate any section of the 1985 Code, as supplemented, and any subsequent ordinance included herein. 
The chapters of the Code have been conveniently arranged in alphabetical order, and the various sections within each chapter have been catchlined to facilitate usage. Notes which tie related sections of the Code together and which refer to relevant state law have been included. A table listing the state law citations and setting forth their location within the Code is included at the back of this Code. 
Chapter and Section Numbering System 
The chapter and section numbering system used in this Code is the same system used in many state and local government codes. Each section number consists of two parts separated by a dash. The figure before the dash refers to the chapter number, and the figure after the dash refers to the position of the section within the chapter. Thus, the second section of chapter 1 is numbered 1-2, and the first section of chapter 6 is 6-1. Under this system, each section is identified with its chapter, and at the same time new sections can be inserted in their proper place by using the decimal system for amendments. For example, if new material consisting of one section that would logically come between sections 6-1 and 6-2 is desired to be added, such new section would be numbered 6-1.5. New articles and new divisions may be included in the same way or, in the case of articles, may be placed at the end of the chapter embracing the subject, and, in the case of divisions, may be placed at the end of the article embracing the subject. The next successive number shall be assigned to the new article or division. New chapters may be included by using one of the reserved chapter numbers. Care should be taken that the alphabetical arrangement of chapters is maintained when including new chapters. 
Page Numbering System 
The page numbering system used in this Code is a prefix system. The letters to the left of the colon are an abbreviation which represents a certain portion of the volume. The number to the right of the colon represents the number of the page in that portion. In the case of a chapter of the Code, the number to the left of the colon indicates the number of the chapter. In the case of an appendix to the Code, the letter immediately to the left of the colon indicates the letter of the appendix. The following are typical parts of codes of ordinances, which may or may not appear in this Code at this time, and their corresponding prefixes: 
CHARTER 	CHT:1 
CHARTER COMPARATIVE TABLE 	CHTCT:1 
CODE 	CD1:1 
CODE COMPARATIVE TABLES 	CCT:1 
STATE LAW REFERENCE TABLE 	SLT:1 
CHARTER INDEX 	CHTi:1 
CODE INDEX 	CDi:1 
 
Indexes 
The indexes have been prepared with the greatest of care. Each particular item has been placed under several headings, some of which are couched in lay phraseology, others in legal terminology, and still others in language generally used by local government officials and employees. There are numerous cross references within the indexes themselves which stand as guideposts to direct the user to the particular item in which the user is interested. 
Looseleaf Supplements 
A special feature of this publication is the looseleaf system of binding and supplemental servicing of the publication. With this system, the publication will be kept up-to-date. Subsequent amendatory legislation will be properly edited, and the affected page or pages will be reprinted. These new pages will be distributed to holders of copies of the publication, with instructions for the manner of inserting the new pages and deleting the obsolete pages. 
Keeping this publication up-to-date at all times will depend largely upon the holder of the publication. As revised pages are received, it will then become the responsibility of the holder to have the amendments inserted according to the attached instructions. It is strongly recommended by the publisher that all such amendments be inserted immediately upon receipt to avoid misplacing them and, in addition, that all deleted pages be saved and filed for historical reference purposes. 
Acknowledgments 
This publication was under the direct supervision of Alyce A. Whitson, Supervising Editor, and Charles Vignos, Editor, of the Municipal Code Corporation, Tallahassee, Florida. Credit is gratefully given to the other members of the publisher's staff for their sincere interest and able assistance throughout the project. 
The publisher is most grateful to Charles Blazek, City Clerk, and Neil Flaxman, City Attorney, for their cooperation and assistance during the progress of the work on this publication. It is hoped that their efforts and those of the publisher have resulted in a Code of Ordinances which will make the active law of the city readily accessible to all citizens and which will be a valuable tool in the day-to-day administration of the city's affairs.

ORDINANCE NO. 99-41 
AN ORDINANCE ACCEPTING, APPROVING AND ADOPTING THE CODIFICATION OF THE CHARTER AND CODE OF THE CITY OF HIALEAH GARDENS ATTACHED HERETO AS EXHIBIT "A", EXCEPTING, HOWEVER, PROVISIONS RELATED TO LAND USE REGULATION AND LICENSING; PROVIDING FOR SEVERABILITY; PROVIDING FOR EFFECTIVE DATE 
WHEREAS, the City of Hialeah Gardens Charter and Code have been codified in accordance with certain Charter amendments that have been adopted and ordinances which have been amended; and 
WHEREAS, attached hereto and made a part hereof is a true copy of the codification of said Code; and 
WHEREAS, with the exception of the Land Use Regulations and the licensing provisions contained in said Code, the City of Hialeah Gardens desires to accept said Charter and Code to be the Charter and Code of the City of Hialeah Gardens; 
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT ORDAINED BY THE MAYOR AND THE CITY COUNCIL OF THE CITY OF HIALEAH GARDENS, FLORIDA, AS FOLLOWS: 
Section 1: The City of Hialeah Gardens does hereby accept, approve and adopt the Charter and Code, as prepared by Municipal Code Corporation and as attached hereto as Exhibit "A" and made a part hereof as if fully set forth herein, with the exception of the chapter referred to as Land Use Regulations and Licensing. 
Section 2: The ordinances of the City of Hialeah Gardens, as it relates to Land Use Regulations and Licensing, together with codification of such ordinances in prior Codes, be and the same is hereby accepted, approved and adopted. 
Section 3: Should any section, paragraph, sentence, phrase, clause or other part or provision of this ordinance be declared by a court of competent jurisdiction to be invalid or unconstitutional, the same shall not affect the validity of the ordinance as a whole or any part thereof other than the one part so declared to be invalid. 
Section 4: This ordinance shall become effective upon its adoption in accordance with law. PASSED AND ADOPTED this 4 th day of January, 2000.

PART I - CHARTER[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Printed herein is the Charter of the City of Hialeah Gardens, Florida, as adopted by referendum on March 6, 1984. Amendments to the Charter are indicated by parenthetical history notes following amended provisions. The absence of a history note indicates that the provision remains unchanged from the original Charter. Obvious misspellings have been corrected without notation. For stylistic purposes, a uniform system of headings, catchlines and citations to state statutes has been used. Additions made for clarity are indicated by brackets. 
State Law reference— Municipal home rule powers, F.S. ch. 166. 
 
ARTICLE I. - INCORPORATION 
 
Sec. 1. - Name. 
The present government existing under the name of "City of Hialeah Gardens" shall continue to exist and shall continue to be known as "City of Hialeah Gardens."  
Sec. 2. - Charter to prevail. 
This Charter, adopted by the electors of the City of Hialeah Gardens, shall supersede all previous Charters, and incorporate all provisions of the previous Charters of the City of Hialeah Gardens which are not embraced herein, and which are not inconsistent with this Charter, and which shall become ordinances of the City of Hialeah Gardens, subject to modification or repeal in the same manner as other ordinances of the City. This Charter, being adopted pursuant to the Constitution of the State of Florida, and F.S. ch. 166, eff. October 1, 1973, and amended, shall supersede all general laws of the State of Florida under which the City was heretofore organized.  
Sec. 3. - Existence and boundaries. 
The municipal corporation for which this Charter is adopted shall be known as the City of Hialeah Gardens, the inhabitants of which shall be and constitute a body, corporate and politic, with perpetual existence, within the boundaries and territorial limits of the County of Dade, State of Florida, as follows: 
All that part of Section 10, 53 South, 40 East, lying North and East from the center line of the Miami Canal. 
All that part of Section 3, 53 South, 40 East, lying North and East from the center line of the Miami Canal. 
All that part of Section 4, 53 South, 40 East, lying North and East from the center line of the Miami Canal. 
All that part of Section 33, 52 South, 40 East, lying North and East from the center line of the Miami Canal. 
All that part of Section 32, 52 South, 40 East, lying North and East from the center line of the Miami Canal. 
All that part of Section 29, 52 South, 40 East, lying North and East from the center line of the Miami Canal, less the North 330 feet of said section. 
City of Hialeah Gardens 
The procedures for adjusting the boundaries of Hialeah Gardens through annexations or contractions of its corporate limits will be as prescribed by F.S. ch. 171, as amended. 
State Law reference— Municipalities adopt annexation ordinances pursuant to the Dade County Charter, F.S. § 171.071.  
Sec. 4. - Powers of the municipality. 
A.  The City of Hialeah Gardens shall have governmental, corporate, and proprietary powers to enable it to conduct municipal government, perform municipal functions, and render municipal services, and may exercise any power for municipal purposes except where expressly prohibited by law. 
B.  The powers of the City of Hialeah Gardens shall be construed liberally in favor of the City, limited only by the State Constitution, general law, the Dade County Charter, and specific limitations contained herein. Through the adoption of this Charter, it is the intent of the electors of the City of Hialeah Gardens to grant the broadest exercise of home rule powers permitted under the State Constitution and State Law to the municipal government established herein. 
State Law reference— Home rule powers, F.S. § 166.021.  
ARTICLE II. - SUCCESSION 
 
Sec. 1. - Succession of rights. 
This municipality shall succeed to the title, rights, and ownership of property, uncollected taxes, claims, judgments, decrees, and choses in action, including any and all property rights, personal or mixed, of any nature whatsoever held or owned by the City prior to the adoption of this Charter, all of which shall pass to and be vested in the City under this Charter.  
Sec. 2. - Continuance of contractual obligations. 
This Charter shall not be construed in any manner to impair any obligations or contracts, debts, or obligations heretofore binding upon the City, and the same shall continue to be binding on the City under this Charter.  
Sec. 3. - Pending matters. 
All rights, claims, actions, orders, contracts, and legal or administrative proceedings involving the City shall continue except as modified pursuant to the provisions of this Charter.  
Sec. 4. - Ordinances and resolutions preserved. 
All ordinances and resolutions in effect upon the adoption of this Charter, to the extent not inconsistent with it, shall remain in force until repealed or changed as provided herein.  
ARTICLE III. - GOVERNMENT 
 
Sec. 1. - Form of government. 
The form of government of the City of Hialeah Gardens, Florida, provided for under this Charter shall be known as the "Mayor-Council form of Government." All legislative powers of the City shall be vested in the City Council. All executive powers of the City shall be vested in the Mayor. The Council shall consist of five (5) citizens, who are qualified voters of the city, and who shall hold no other elective public office, and who shall be elected in a manner hereinafter provided (Article III, Section 9). The individual Council members shall have one (1) vote in all matters before the City Council. The Mayor shall be a qualified voter of the City, and shall hold no other elective public office, and shall be elected in a manner hereinafter provided (Article III, Section 9). In the event of a tie vote by the members of the City Council, the issue shall be considered defeated; however, the Mayor shall have the right, at his discretion, to call a special Council meeting within ten (10) days to reconsider this particular issue. In the event a vacancy exists in the Council, the Mayor shall have the right to cast one (1) tie-breaking vote.  
Sec. 2. - Powers of the City Council. 
A.  The City Council shall constitute the governing body of the City with all governmental, corporate, and proprietary powers of the City of Hialeah Gardens. The Council shall have the power to pass ordinances, resolutions, and to adopt regulations to enable it to conduct municipal government, perform municipal functions, and to render municipal services. 
B.  The City Council shall be the legislative and governing body of the City, with the assistance of such officers, servants, agents, and employees as may be deemed necessary. The Council shall by resolution provide for and set the compensation of all employees. Each member of the City Council may appoint to any board or committee one (1) member, who is a registered voter of the City of Hialeah Gardens, or is the proprietor of an established business in the City of Hialeah Gardens, to serve at the discretion of the Council without compensation, with such duties as provided by resolution as the Council may deem necessary. 
C.  The City Council shall elect by majority vote from within itself a Chairperson, a Vice-Chairperson, and a Financial Director, at the organizational meeting following each election. 
State Law reference— Municipal home rule powers, F.S. ch. 166.  
Sec. 3. - Powers of the Mayor. 
A.  The Mayor shall constitute the executive head of the City, with all the necessary powers and authority to enforce all laws, ordinances, and resolutions of the City Council. 
B.  The Mayor shall be recognized as the official head of the City for all ceremonial purposes, by the Courts for the purpose of serving civil process, and by the Governor for all military or Civil Defense purposes. In time of public danger or emergency, the Mayor, with the consent of the City Council, may take command of the police to maintain order and enforce the laws. 
C.  During the Mayor's absence or disability, the duties of Mayor shall be performed by the Chairperson of the City Council. 
D.  The Mayor shall be responsible for the preparation of an annual budget in a manner hereinafter provided (Article IV, Section 2). 
E.  The Mayor shall advise the City Council as to the needs of the City. It shall be the duty of the Mayor to keep the City Council well informed as to the financial condition of the City. 
F.  The Mayor may appoint to any board or committee, with the exception of the Zoning Board, two (2) members to serve at the discretion of the Council without compensation, with such duties as provided by resolution as the Council may deem necessary. 
G.  The Mayor shall be responsible for the day to day operation of the City by overseeing all City Departments. 
H.  The Mayor shall have the right and the responsibility to appoint and remove all officers, servants, agents and employees of the City, without the right of veto by the Council. In the event of demotion, suspension, or discharge of an employee, the employee, with written notice, is entitled to appeal to the Personnel Review Board, subject to the rules and regulations thereof. 
I.  The Mayor shall attend meetings of the City Council, with the right to take part in discussion on all matters before the Council, but not to vote, except as heretofore provided (Article III, Section 1). 
J.  The Mayor shall perform such duties as may be prescribed by the Charter, ordinances, or resolutions of the City Council. 
K.  The Mayor shall have the right and responsibility to appoint and remove all officers, servants, agents and employees of the City. 
(Ord. No. 97-19, § 2, 11-18-97/3-3-98)  
Sec. 4. - Rate of compensation of the City Council members and the Mayor. 
A.  The rate of compensation paid to Councilpersons shall be set by ordinance, provided, however, that there shall be at least a required four-fifths vote of the Council for adoption of any such ordinance. 
B.  The rate of compensation paid to the Mayor shall be set by ordinance, provided, however, that there shall be at least a required four-fifths vote of the Council for adoption of any such ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 97-21A, § 2, 11-18-97/3-3-98; Ord. No. 97-20, § 2, 11-18-97/3-3-98; Ord. No. 99-33, § 1, 12-7-99/3-14-00; Ord. No. 99-34, § 1, 12-7-99/3-14-00) 
Editor's note— Ord. Nos. 99-33 and 99-34 superseded and replaced Ord. Nos. 99-12 and 99-13, respectively. Ord. Nos. 99-12 and 99-13 affected the same portions of this Charter (art. III, §§ 4A and 4B) as Ord. Nos. 99-33 and 99-34.  
Sec. 5. - General and Run-off elections. 
Nonpartisan General Elections for the nomination of candidates shall be held on the first Tuesday following the first Monday in March of each year. Run-off elections shall be held fourteen (14) days following the General Election. 
(Ord. No. 99-38, § 1, 12-7-99/3-14-00) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 99-38 superseded and replaced Ord. No. 99-10. Ord. No. 99-10 affected the same portions of this Charter (art. III, § 5) as Ord. No. 99-38, but was never voted upon and was therefore omitted from notation within this Code. 
State Law reference— Florida Election Code, F.S. chs. 97—106.  
Sec. 6. - Qualifications of candidates. 
A.  Candidates for public office shall reside in the City of Hialeah Gardens for a period of at least one (1) year preceding the general election for which said candidate qualifies for and, in addition, candidates shall have been registered on the City Voters Registration Books as being eligible to vote at such general election. 
B.  The name of any qualified elector of the City shall be placed on the general election ballot as a candidate for nomination to the office of Mayor or as a candidate for nomination to a seat on the City Council upon: 
1.  Submitting to the City Clerk a petition signed by at least twenty-five (25) registered voters of the City, on a form supplied by the City Clerk, not more than seventy-five (75) days or less than forty-five (45) days prior to the date of the general election. 
2.  Paying a qualifying fee to the City of Hialeah Gardens of one hundred ($100) dollars if qualifying for the office of Mayor, and fifty ($50) dollars if qualifying for a seat on the City Council. 
3.  Submitting to the City Clerk, on a form supplied by the City Clerk, a sworn statement as to the applicant's full name, address, occupation, and willingness to serve if elected to office (in accordance with Section 6, Paragraph A, hereof.) 
(Referendum, 3-3-87; Ord. No. 99-37, § 1, 12-7-99/3-14-00) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 99-37 superseded and replaced Ord. No. 99-11. Ord. No. 99-11 affected the same portion of this Charter (art. III, § 6A) as Ord. No. 99-37, but was never voted upon and was therefore omitted from notation within this Code.  
Sec. 7. - Supervisor of City elections. 
A.  Every municipal election shall be conducted by and be under the personal supervision of the City Clerk, who is hereby empowered and directed to exercise all of the powers and to perform all of the duties and functions appropriate to the conduct of such election, including the establishment, promulgation, and enforcement of such rules and regulations relating to such election and the establishment, maintenance, filing, and preservation of such election records as the City Clerk may deem necessary, or which may be required by City, County, or State Law. 
B.  Prior to each municipal election, the Mayor shall designate a Clerk of Election and one inspector of election, and each Council member shall appoint one inspector of election and the names of such clerks and inspectors shall be published by posting at City [Hall]. All persons who shall serve as clerks of election or as inspectors of election at any municipal election held in the City shall have the status of casual and temporary employees not entitled to the status or to any of the rights or benefits of regular or permanent City employees.  
Sec. 8. - Judge of City elections. 
The City Council shall be the judge of all City elections, and the qualifications of all applicants for all elected City offices.  
Sec. 9. - Election of City officials and terms of office. 
A.  The office of Mayor shall be a nonpartisan office. The Mayor shall be elected by a majority vote of the City's electorate. All candidates seeking the office of Mayor shall file to run in Group I. All qualified candidates' names shall be placed on the general election's ballot. The names of the two candidates receiving the highest number of votes shall be placed on the Run-off election's ballot, except if one candidate received a clear majority vote at the general election, in which case the candidate receiving the majority vote would be declared Mayor-elect. The candidate receiving the majority vote at the Run-off election shall be declared Mayor-elect. 
B.  The Mayor, Group I, shall be elected at the City's Run-off election in 1981, and thereafter shall be elected each odd numbered year for a four (4) year term of office. 
Editor's note— Res. No. 2244, § 2, adopted Mar. 18, 2008 set out provisions, affecting Sec. 9B., that the term of office of the Mayor be extended from a two-year term to a four-year term, commencing with the mayoral election to be held on Mar. 6, 1997. Election for said provisions was held on Sept. 3, 1996. 
C.  The five (5) seats that make up the City Council shall be nonpartisan offices. The five (5) members of the City Council shall be elected at large by a majority vote of the City's electorate. All candidates seeking a seat on the City Council shall file to run in any one (1) of the five (5) groups that represent the five (5) City Council seats, Group II, Group III, Group IV, Group V or Group VI. All qualified candidates filing for the same group shall have their names placed together on the general election's ballot. There shall be as many separate groups as there are seats on the Council open for election. The names of the two candidates receiving the highest number of votes in each group shall be placed on the Run-off election's ballot, except if one candidate received a clear majority vote over the other candidates in the group at the general election. In that case, the candidate receiving the majority vote would be declared Council-member-elect in that group. The candidate receiving the highest number of votes at the Run-off election shall be declared Council-member-elect in that group. 
D.  Commencing with the election in March 1997, all council groups shall serve a four year term, with one seat continuing to be two years. 
Editor's note— Ord No. 98-01, § 1, adopted Feb. 3, 1998, set out provisions to implement § D, as follows: "That all councilpersons elected at the next election (March 3, 1998) shall serve for a period of four years and at councilpersons elections after March 3, 1998, all councilperson's term of office shall be for four years, with the councilperson who receives the least votes in such election to serve for a two year term." 
E.  The City's Council members in Groups II, III, and IV shall be elected at the City's general or Run-off election in 1981. The City's Council members in Groups V and VI, shall be elected at the City's primary or Run-off election in 1982. 
F.  All elected City officials, Mayor, and City Council members, shall remain in office until their successors are elected and sworn into office. 
G.  Any incumbent City Council member seeking the office of Mayor, Group I, shall submit a written resignation to the City Clerk not less than ninety (90) days prior to the date of the City's Run-off election, and said resignation shall become effective on the date of the Run-off election. Upon receipt of a written resignation, the City Clerk shall make a public announcement of the resignation and will accept candidates to run for election to the remaining unexpired term of the City Council member's seat. 
H.  Any elected City Official, Mayor, or City Council member, seeking some other elective public office outside the City, shall submit a written resignation to the City Clerk upon qualifying for the other elective public office. Should the City official refuse or fail to submit a written resignation upon qualifying for another elective public office, the official shall be ousted from office and the office shall be declared vacant. 
I.  Any elected official, Mayor or City Council member, who no longer remains a resident and qualified elector of the City during their term in office, shall submit a written resignation to the City Clerk. Should the City Official refuse or fail to submit a written resignation, the official shall be ousted from office immediately, and the office shall be declared vacant. 
J.  The Mayor shall serve full time during regular City Hall business hours to fulfill the mayoral powers. Such mayoral service shall be the Mayor's only full time employment. 
(Referendum, 3-3-87; Ord. No. 90-50, § 2, 12-20-91/3-3-92; Ord. No. 90-53, § 2, 12-20-91/3-3-92; Ord. No. 94-09, § 1, 1-17-95/3-7-95; Ord. No. 96-20, § 1, 11-5-96/3-4-97; Ord. No. 98-01, § 1, 2-3-98; Res. No. 2244, 3-18-08)  
Sec. 10. - Recall of an elected City Official. 
The Mayor or any member of the City Council may be removed from office by the City's electorate in accordance with the recall procedure as established by F.S. § 100.361. Should the Florida State Legislature amend or adopt a new statute establishing recall proceedings, then the amended or new statute shall automatically be adopted by this section of the Hialeah Gardens City Charter. 
State Law reference— Recall of elected officials, F.S. § 100.361.  
Sec. 11. - Standards of conduct for City Officials and employees. 
A.  The standards of conduct for City Officials, both elected and nonelected, servants, agents, and other employees, shall be in accordance with The Standards of Conduct Law, F.S. § 112.311 et seq., and as amended. 
B.  No member of the immediate family of the Mayor, and no member of the immediate family of a City Council member, shall be chosen as the City Clerk, or to any other city office or employment. Further, this Charter adopts all the provisions of F.S. § 116.111. 
State Law reference— Code of ethics, F.S. § 112.311 et seq.  
Sec. 12. - Rules for the City Council. 
A.  Should any elected official of the City fail to attend three (3) consecutive City Council meetings, the elected official shall be considered to have resigned the office. However, illness, absence from the City, or other reasonable excuse, may be offered in writing, for purposes of record, by the elected official, to the City Council. If such be accepted by the City Council, this provision shall not be invoked. 
B.  A minimum of three (3) members of the City Council shall constitute a quorum to do City business. 
C.  A minimum of three (3) affirmative votes is necessary for the City Council to act on any matter brought before the Council. 
D.  The City Council may determine its own rules of procedure and may punish its own members for misconduct. 
E.  The latest published and released edition of Robert's Rules of Order shall be the official parliamentary guide for all meetings of the City Council when it is not in conflict with the Charter or other rules adopted by the City Council. 
F.  All motions to be voted on by the City Council at a regular or special meeting must be pertinent to the items on the official agenda for that specific City Council meeting. This requirement may be waived by the unanimous consent of the City Council in order to conduct matters of an emergency nature. 
G.  Forty-eight (48) hours after the close of the polls on the date of the City's Run-off election, the City Council shall meet in the Council Chambers of the City for the purpose of swearing in the newly elected City officials. Thereafter the City Council shall meet at such time and place as shall be prescribed by resolution of the City Council. 
H.  All meetings of the City Council and all sessions of any Board or Committee of the City shall be public. 
I.  No member of the City Council shall be excused from voting except on matters involving the consideration of his or her own official conduct, or where his or her financial interests are involved. 
(Referendum, 3-3-87) 
State Law reference— Voting conflicts, F.S. § 112.3143.  
Sec. 13. - Manner of passage of ordinances. 
A.  All ordinances, except concerning appropriations or budget, shall be confined to one subject which shall be clearly expressed in the title. Any ordinance concerning appropriations or budget shall be confined to the subject of appropriations or budget. 
B.  No ordinance shall be passed until it has been read into the public record by title, or in full, on two separate occasions, separated by at least a period of twenty-four (24) hours. Ordinances shall be read by title only unless a motion to read an ordinance in its entirety is duly made and seconded, and at least two-thirds of the Council members present agree to the reading in its entirety. 
C.  Copies of all proposed ordinances shall be furnished to each Council member and the Mayor, at least seven (7) days before the first reading of the ordinance. This requirement may be waived by a unanimous consent of the City Council. Copies of all proposed ordinances shall be made available to all interested persons at City Hall during normal business hours. 
D.  The "Yes" and "No" votes of the City Council members shall be taken and placed into the public record on the consideration of all ordinances. Every ordinance shall require, on each reading, a minimum of three (3) affirmative votes for passage. 
E.  All ordinances passed by the City Council shall be submitted before going into effect, to the Mayor or person acting as such, for his approval. If approved he shall sign the same, when it shall become a law. If vetoed, he shall return the same with his objections in writing to the City Council, at their next regular meeting, who shall cause the same to be entered in full upon the record of their proceedings, and proceed to consider the Mayor's objections, and to act upon the same. If, upon consideration, the City Council shall pass the same by a two-thirds vote of the members present, which vote shall be entered upon the records, the ordinance or ordinances shall then become a law, the Mayor's objections to the contrary notwithstanding. Any ordinance which shall not be returned to the City Council at the next regular meeting of the Council after its passage, shall become a law in like manner as if signed by the Mayor or person acting as such. 
F.  All procedures for adoption of ordinances and resolutions as set forth in F.S. § 166.041 shall be adopted by this Charter, and should the State of Florida Legislature amend or adopt a new statute establishing procedures for adoption of ordinances and resolutions, then the amended or new statute shall automatically be adopted by this Section of the City of Hialeah Gardens Charter. 
State Law reference— Minimum mandatory procedure for adoption of ordinances, F.S. § 166.041.  
Sec. 14. - The initiative. 
A.  Power to initiate ordinances. The people shall have power at their option to propose ordinances, including ordinances granting franchises or privileges and to adopt the same at the polls, such power being known as the "initiative." A petition, meeting the requirements hereinafter provided and requesting the City Council to pass an ordinance, therein set forth or designated, shall be termed an initiative petition and shall be acted upon as hereinafter provided. 
B.  Preparation of initiative petition; affidavit of genuineness of signatures. Signatures of initiative petitions need not all be on one paper, but the circulator of every such paper shall make an affidavit that each signature appended to the paper is the genuine signature of the person whose name it purports to be, which affidavit shall be substantially in the following form: 
STATE OF FLORIDA 	) 	
	) 	SS. 
COUNTY OF DADE 	) 	
 
___________ being duly sworn, deposes and says that he is the circulator of the foregoing petition paper containing _____ signatures, and that the signatures appended thereto were made in his presence and are the signatures of the persons whose names they purport to be. 
	(Signed) _____ 
 
Subscribed and sworn to before me this _____ day of ________ 19___. 
	_____
Notary Public 
 
With each signature shall be stated the place of residence of the signer, giving the street, number or other description sufficient to identify the place. All such papers pertaining to any one measure shall have written or printed thereon the names and addresses of at least fifteen (15) registered voters who shall be officially regarded as filing the petition, and shall constitute a committee of the petitions for the purposes hereinafter named. All such papers shall be filed in the office of the City Clerk as one instrument. 
C.  Filing of petitions. Within twenty (20) days after the filing of the petition, the City Clerk shall ascertain by examination the number of registered voters whose signatures are appended thereto and whether this number is at least ten percent (10%) of the total number of the registered voters as shown by the City registration books, and the City Clerk shall attach to said petition a certificate showing the result of such examination. If, by the City Clerk's certificate, of which notice in writing shall be given to one or more of the persons designated, the petition is shown to be insufficient, it may be amended within ten (10) days from the date of said certificate by filing supplementary petition papers with additional signatures. The City Clerk shall within ten (10) days after such amendments make examination of the amended petition, and if the City Clerk's certificate shall show the same to be insufficient, the Clerk shall file the petition in the City Clerk's office and shall notify each member of the committee of that fact. The final finding of the insufficiency of a petition shall not prejudice the filing of a new petition for the same purpose. 
D.  Submission of petition to City Council. If the petition shall be found to be sufficient, the City Clerk shall so certify and submit the proposed measure to the City Council at its next meeting. Upon receiving the proposed measure the City Council shall at once proceed to consider it and shall take final action thereon within thirty (30) days from the date it is filed with them. 
E.  Election on initiated measures. If the City Council shall fail to pass the proposed measure, or shall pass it in a form different from that set forth in the petition, then the measure shall be submitted by the City Council to the vote of the electors at the next election occurring not less than thirty (30) days after the date of the final action by the City Council, and if no election is to be held within six (6) months from such date, then the City Council shall call a special election to be held not less than thirty (30) days nor more than forty-five (45) days from such date. When submitted the measure shall be in its original form. 
F.  Initiative ballots. The ballots used when voting upon any such proposed measure shall state the Title of the Measure, with a run-off statement of the substance thereof. When a measure proposed by initiative petition is passed by the City Council, but not in its original form, and is to be submitted to a vote of the electors, the measure as passed by the City Council shall not take effect until after such vote, and, if the measure so submitted be approved by a majority of electors voting thereon it shall thereupon become an ordinance of the City and the measure as passed by the City Council shall be deemed repealed. If a majority of the electors voting on any such measure shall vote in favor thereof, it shall thereupon become an ordinance of the city, and may not be overturned except by referendum. 
G.  Number of measures to be initiated. Any number of proposed measures may be voted upon at the same election in accordance with the provisions of this Charter.  
Sec. 15. - Vacancies and filling vacancies. 
A.  Should a seat on the City Council become vacant due to the death, resignation, or removal from office in any manner authorized by law, the remaining unexpired term shall be filled by: 
1.  If the unexpired term of office is less than one hundred eighty (180) days until the next Run-off election, the office shall be filled by appointment by the Mayor, approved by a majority vote of the City Council, at its next meeting. 
2.  If the unexpired term of office is one hundred eighty (180) days or more until the next Run-off election, the office shall be filled by a special election. 
3.  The special election, if necessary, shall be held not less than thirty (30) days nor more than sixty (60) days after such vacancy occurred. 
4.  For the purpose of counting days after a vacancy, the count shall start on the day of the death, the day that the resignation is submitted to the City Clerk, or the day that the removal from office takes effect. 
B.  Any temporary vacancy of a seat on the City Council, created by suspension by virtue of a Grand Jury Indictment, shall be filled by: 
1.  For the first thirty (30) days after the suspension, no action shall be taken to fill the vacancy. 
2.  After thirty (30) days, at the next meeting of the City Council, the office shall be filled by a temporary appointment by the Mayor, approved by a majority vote of the City Council. 
3.  After one hundred eighty (180) days the office shall be declared vacant, and the vacancy shall be filled as per paragraph A of this section. 
4.  Any person serving as a temporary appointee shall have all the duties and powers of a City Council member. 
5.  Should the suspended official be acquitted or cleared of the charges contained in the indictment, the official shall be restored to office if the term of office has not expired. 
C.  Should the office of Mayor become vacant due to the death, resignation, or removal from office in any manner authorized by law, the remaining unexpired term shall be filled by: 
1.  If the unexpired term of office is less than one hundred eighty (180) days until the next Run-off election, the Chairperson of the City Council shall assume the office of Mayor. The Vice-Chairperson shall then become the Chairperson of the City Council, and the vacancy on the City Council shall be filled as per paragraph A.1 of this section. 
2.  If the unexpired term of office is one hundred eighty (180) days or more until the next Run-off election, the Chairperson of the City Council shall become acting Mayor, along with retaining the duties of the Chairperson of the City Council, until the office shall be filled by a special election. 
3.  The special election, if necessary, shall be held not less than thirty (30) days nor more than sixty (60) days after such vacancy occurred. 
4.  For the purpose of counting days after a vacancy, the count shall start on the day of the death, the day that the resignation is submitted to the City Clerk, or the day that the removal from office takes effect. 
D.  Any temporary vacancy of the office of Mayor, created by suspension by virtue of a Grand Jury Indictment, shall be filled by: 
1.  For the first one hundred eighty (180) days the Chairperson of the City Council shall become Acting Mayor, along with retaining the duties of the Chairperson of the City Council. 
2.  After one hundred eighty (180) days the office of Mayor shall be declared vacant, and the vacancy shall be filled as per paragraph C.1 or C.2 of this section. 
E.  Should the suspended Mayor be acquitted or cleared of the charges contained in the Indictment, the Mayor shall be restored to office if the term of office has not expired. 
(Referendum, 3-3-87)  
Sec. 16. - Oath of office. 
Every elected officer of the City before entering the duties of office shall take and subscribe to the following oath before any judicial officer of the State of Florida, to be filed and kept in the office of the City Clerk: 
"I do solemnly swear (or affirm) that I will support, protect and defend the Constitution and Government of the United States and the State of Florida, and that I will in all respects observe the provisions of the Charter and ordinances of the City of Hialeah Gardens; that I am fully qualified to hold office under the Constitution of the State; and that I will well and faithfully perform the duties of (title of office) on which I am now about to enter. So help me God." 
State Law reference— Oath, F.S. § 876.05.  
ARTICLE IV. - FINANCIAL[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Financial matters, F.S. §§ 166.101 et seq., 218.30 et seq. 
 
Sec. 1. - Fiscal year. 
The fiscal year for the City shall commence on the first day of October of each calendar year and shall end on the thirtieth (30th) day of September of the following year. Such fiscal year shall also constitute the budget and accounting year. 
State Law reference— Mandatory fiscal year, F.S. §§ 166.241, 218.33.  
Sec. 2. - Preparation of budget. 
The Mayor shall be responsible for the preparation of an annual budget which shall contain estimates of contemplated revenues and expenditures for the ensuing fiscal year, and which shall itemize separately the sums contemplated as revenues, according to their respective sources, and itemized as to contemplated expenditures in accordance with the offices, departments, divisions, or other separable units as may be related to the administration of the financial affairs of the City. The preparation of the annual budget shall further be in accordance with the Uniform Accounting System Manual for the State of Florida.  
Sec. 3. - Adoption of budget. 
A.  The preliminary budget shall be prepared and presented to the Council no later than the last day of July of each year. The Council shall hold a public hearing on the budget in accordance with State and County requirements, at which time interested persons shall be given an opportunity to be heard. The City Clerk shall post a notice of the place and time of the public hearing. Copies of the proposed budget shall be available in the office of the City Clerk for public inspection at the time of posting such notice. 
B.  During such public hearing the Council may insert new items or may increase, decrease, or delete any items in the budget. 
C.  The budget shall be finally adopted by majority vote of the Council no later than the last day of September of each year, and the millage or rate of taxation necessary to pay all outstanding debts in the ensuing fiscal year shall be fixed according to the provisions of F.S. ch. 200. Upon adoption, by ordinance, the budget shall constitute an appropriation of the amounts set forth herein. 
D.  Transfer of funds or revisions which may be required to conduct the affairs of the City, where unanticipated changes in revenues and expenses occur, reasonably requiring a revision of the budget, shall be adopted by resolution. 
E.  A copy of the budget, as finally adopted, shall be certified by the City Council and the budget so certified shall be filed for the use of all offices and departments of the City. 
State Law reference— Mandatory procedure for adoption of budget, F.S. § 200.065.  
Sec. 4. - Independent audit. 
Prior to the end of each fiscal year, the Council shall designate a certified public accountant who shall make an independent audit of accounts and other evidences of financial transactions of the City Government as of the end of the fiscal year, and who shall submit a report to the Council and to the State of Florida, as may be required by law. 
State Law reference— Requirement for annual audit, F.S. § 218.32.  
ARTICLE V. - BONDED INDEBTEDNESS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference— Finance and taxation, bonds, F.S. § 166.101 et seq. 
 
Sec. 1. - Referendum requirement. 
The City of Hialeah Gardens shall not incur any form of bonded indebtedness any portion of which is backed by the full faith and credit or taxing power of the City, nor shall the City issue bonds, notes, or obligations of any nature, type, or form which are backed in whole or in part, by the full faith and credit or taxing power of the City, unless issuance of such bonds has been approved by vote of the majority of the electors voting on the issuance of such bonds in a Run-off election. In any Run-off or special election in which a bond issue appears, the bond issue shall be called, noticed, and conducted and the results thereof determined and declared in a manner required by Florida State Law. 
(Referendum, 3-3-87)  
Sec. 2. - Special assessment district. 
Special assessments shall be in the method provided for by Florida Statutes, or by majority vote or a petition signed by a majority of the owners of property within the District to be assessed consenting to the special assessment. 
(Ord. No. 99-35, § 1, 12-7-99/3-14-00) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 99-35 superseded and replaced Ord. No. 99-14. Ord. No. 99-14 affected the same portion of this Charter (art. V, § 2) as Ord. No. 99-35, but was never voted upon and was therefore omitted from notation within this Code.  
Sec. 3. - Ordinance for bond issue. 
Upon a majority vote of the electors approving the issuance of bonds, the City Council may by ordinance, issue bonds of the City of Hialeah Gardens for the payment of all or any part of such costs, for which the bonds were established, including the reimbursement of any funds that the City used to pay any part thereof.  
Sec. 4. - Conditions for sale of bonds. 
Bonds approved as herein provided may be sold by the City at public or private sale at the discretion of the Mayor and Council. If sold at public sale, the sale shall be made pursuant to advertisement published in a newspaper of run-off circulation in Dade County which publication shall be made once a week for three consecutive weeks. The sale shall be held on a date and time fixed in the advertisement, not less than ten (10) days nor more than thirty (30) days from the date of the last publication. Such bonds shall be sold for such prices as the City Council shall determine; provided the amount is not less than 96 percent of face value plus accrued interest. If sold at private sale, the bonds shall be sold for cash at not less than 96 percent of the face value plus accrued interest. The interest and principal on such bonds shall be payable at some responsible bank or trust company designated by the City Council. The interest rate limitations on bond issues shall be provided by Florida State Law.  
Sec. 5. - Annual tax. 
The City Council shall levy an annual tax upon all the taxable property in the City of Hialeah Gardens sufficient to pay the principal of such bonds as they mature and interest on outstanding bonds.  
Sec. 6. - Liberal construction. 
The requirements of this Article are to be construed as additional or supplemental requirements and shall not be deemed to preclude the issuance of bonds by the City pursuant to other authority provided by law and are not in derogation of any powers of the City provided by law for the same or similar purposes.  
ARTICLE VI. - PLANNING AND ZONING[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference— Local government comprehensive planning and land development regulation act, F.S. § 163.3161 et seq. 
 
Sec. 1. - Authority to regulate and restrict. 
The City Council shall have the power to regulate and restrict the location, height, size, cubic contents, construction and areas of buildings and other structures, including billboards and advertising devices, the percentage and portion of lots of land that may be occupied or built on, the size of yards, courts and other open structures, the density of population and the use of buildings, structures and land for trade industries, residences, apartment houses and any other purpose and for any of the said purposes, in promoting the safety, health, comfort, morals, convenience, peace, prosperity or run-off welfare of the City or its inhabitants, to divide the City into zones of such number, shapes and areas as may be deemed best suited to effectuate the purposes of this section and within such zones to regulate and restrict the erection, construction, reconstruction, alteration, repair, destruction, or removal of buildings, land and structures. The regulations in one or more zones may differ from those in other zones and the City Council shall have reasonable regard for the character of buildings and other structures in each zone and the use for which the land is suitable, to the end that economic prosperity and the enhancement of the health, comfort, convenience and run-off welfare of the inhabitants of the City may be promoted. To insure that the regulations so established are complied with, the City shall have all of the powers accorded it by law to take such legal action necessary to enforce such regulations, including the power to declare any violation a public nuisance and to seek judicial action for the abatement of same.  
Sec. 2. - Power to create administrative departments. 
The Mayor and City Council shall have the power to create and budget for such departments as it deems necessary to administer the power established in this Article and to delegate to any such departments the power and authority to accomplish such purpose, pursuant to Article IV, Section 3.  
Sec. 3. - Creation of a Planning and Zoning Board. 
There is hereby created a Planning and Zoning Board, consisting of five (5) members, who shall be residents of Hialeah Gardens. Each member of the City Council shall appoint one (1) citizen of the City as a member of the Planning and Zoning Board. The Board members shall elect from among themselves a Chairperson. 
This Board shall be appointed at the first regular meeting of the City Council following the Run-off Election each year. 
It shall be mandatory that this Board meet as a Planning Board within thirty (30) days following its appointment, together with the City's Building Inspector, for the sole purpose of reviewing the City's Comprehensive Plan and to make written recommendation to the City Council of any action they believe should be taken. It shall further be mandatory that this Planning Board meet every six (6) months, together with the City's Building Inspector, or at any time deemed necessary. 
This Board shall have the duty to hear all matters concerning zoning and zoning variances. After hearing the matter before them, the Board shall make a written recommendation to the City Council of the action they believe should be taken. 
(Referendum, 3-3-87)  
Sec. 4. - Original and appellate jurisdiction of Council. 
The City Council shall have final jurisdiction in all matters related to the granting or denial of variances and changes in zoning and shall sit in an appellate capacity to review decisions rendered by the Planning and Zoning Board.  
Sec. 5. - Building and zoning legislation. 
The City shall have the power to make and enforce ordinances, resolutions, rules, and regulations necessary or expedient for effectuating the powers granted by this Article and to impose penalties for violations thereof as provided for by the Laws of the State of Florida.  
ARTICLE VII. - PERSONNEL REVIEW BOARD 
 
Sec. 1. - Creation of a Personnel Review Board. 
There is hereby created a Personnel Review Board, the controlling rules and regulations thereof to be established by ordinance, which ordinance shall not be amended except by a four-fifths ( 4/5 ) vote of the City Council.  
ARTICLE VIII. - DEPARTMENT OF WATER AND SEWER 
 
Sec. 1. - Establishment of a Department of Water and Sewers. 
The is hereby established a Department of Water and Sewers of the City of Hialeah Gardens. The Department shall be administered by a Department Head who shall be appointed by the Mayor with 4/5 's approval of all members of the City Council in accordance with the provisions of the Charter of the City, relating to the officers and employees of the City generally. 
(Referendum, 12-1-87)  
Sec. 2. - Duties of Department. 
The Department of Water and Sewers shall manage, develop and maintain all water and sewer systems of the City in accordance with the provisions of the Code of Ordinances, at such rates and under policies adopted by the City Council. 
(Referendum, 12-1-87)  
Sec. 3. - Accounts kept separate; expenses; bonds. 
The water and sewer systems of the City shall be administered separate and apart from the general fund as a public utility enterprise and shall budget and account for all income received, expenses and costs incurred in its operation including all funding and capital expenditures which shall be necessary and proper to operate, develop and maintain the systems. The City Council may issued bonds, contract loans and incur indebtedness related to the development of the water and sewer systems of the City in accordance with the provisions of F.S. §§ 166.101 through 166.141. 
(Referendum, 12-1-87)  
Sec. 4. - Revenues. 
All revenues of the water and sewer systems shall be kept separate from the general administrative funds of the City and used exclusively to meet the operation, maintenance, depreciation, labor, interest, bond retirement, sinking funds requirements, capital expenditures, additions and improvements and other necessary expenses and indebtedness of the water and sewer systems. All expenses incurred by the Department and by the Board in exercising their powers and performing their functions and duties, including the payment of salaries, shall be paid solely from the revenues of the water works system of the City or from both of such sources; and no liability or obligation not payable from the revenues of either or both of said systems shall at any time be incurred in connection with the operation thereof. 
(Referendum, 12-1-87)  
Sec. 5. - Membership of Board; terms of membership; appointment of successor Board members. 
The Board shall consist of five (5) members, four (4) of which shall be electors of the City of Hialeah Gardens. Existing members of the Water and Sewer Board having been duly appointed and qualified pursuant to provisions applicable are composed of the following with terms expiring as follows: 
Michael Kemp 	7th day of March, 1989 
George Hameetman 	7th day of March, 1989 
Romilio Garcia 	6th day of March, 1990 
Martin Goodman 	6th day of March, 1990 
Roman Piloto 	5th day of March, 1991 
 
The members of the Board shall serve until the expiration date of the term of each and no member of the Board shall serve for a period to exceed six (6) consecutive years. 
At the conclusion of each term of office, the successor shall be appointed to hold office for a term of three (3) years from the date thereof, except that any person appointed to fill any vacancy shall serve only for the unexpired term. 
Within ten (10) days prior to the date of the expiration of the term of any member of the Board, or within ten (10) days after the death, resignation or removal of any such member, his/her successor shall be named and appointed by the City Council. 
(Referendum, 12-1-87; 3-7-89; Ord. No. 97-22, § 2, 11-18-97/3-3-98)  
Sec. 6. - Powers of Department Head and Water and Sewer Board. 
The Department Head and the Water and Sewer Board shall have such powers and authority as may be authorized by Ordinance and the Charter of the City of Hialeah Gardens. 
(Referendum, 12-1-87)  
Sec. 7. - Transition. 
A.  The term of office of Board members of the Water and Sewer Board in existence at the time of the passage of this Charter amendment shall terminate upon passage of the Ordinance. Each member of the City Council shall thereafter appoint one Board member and subsequent Board members as provided by Charter Section 5. 
B.  All Ordinances in effect upon adoption of this Charter amendment to the extent not inconsistent with it shall remain in force and effect until repealed or amendment. 
C.  The City Council shall have the power, by Resolution, to delete this section from the Charter or any portion thereof including this entire section, when all events of transition have occurred. 
(Referendum, 12-1-87)  
ARTICLE IX. - GENERAL PROVISIONS 
 
Sec. 1. - Public records. 
All records and accounts of Hialeah Gardens shall be open for personal inspection and examination by any person desiring to do so during office hours under reasonable conditions and under supervision of the City Clerk. 
State Law reference— Public records act, F.S. ch. 119.  
Sec. 2. - Publication of notice. 
Any notices required to be published by provisions of State Law or this Charter shall be published in accordance with the applicable Laws of the State of Florida. 
State Law reference— Notice of public meetings, F.S. ch. 286.  
Sec. 3. - Tort liability. 
No suit shall be maintained against the City of Hialeah Gardens or its Agencies for damages to persons or property or for wrongful death arising out of any tort unless six (6) months have elapsed after notice to the City of such tort. 
State Law reference— Tort liability, F.S. § 768.28.  
Sec. 4. - Surety bonds. 
The City Council may require by resolution any officer or employee to give bond in such amount and with such surety as deemed necessary and approved by the City Council. The premiums on such bonds shall be paid by the City.  
Sec. 5. - Separability. 
If any article, section, or part of a section of this Charter shall be held invalid for any reason, the remainder of this Charter shall remain in full force and effect.  
Sec. 6. - Manner of adoption of Charter. 
This Charter shall be adopted as the Charter of the City of Hialeah Gardens, Florida, pursuant to the Constitution of the State of Florida, and F.S. ch. 166, eff. October 1, 1973, and amended and shall become effective at 12:00 noon following the day on which this Charter has been approved by a majority of the qualified electors of the City of Hialeah Gardens voting thereon. The ballot to be used in the referendum election to be held on this Charter shall be substantially as follows and shall be printed in English and Spanish. 
BALLOT 
SHALL THE NEW CHARTER OF THE CITY OF HIALEAH GARDENS, FLORIDA, DATED THE 17TH DAY OF JANUARY, 1984, PROPOSED BY THE COUNCIL, WHICH CHARTER PROVIDES FOR THE ESTABLISHMENT OF A MAYOR-COUNCIL FORM OF GOVERNMENT FOR THE CITY OF HIALEAH GARDENS, PROVIDES FOR THE JURISDICTION AND POWERS OF THE SAID CITY AND PROVIDES FOR THE MANNER OF ADMINISTRATION AND GENERAL GOVERNMENT OF THE CITY BE APPROVED AND ADOPTED? 
YES 394 
NO 237  
Sec. 7. - Charter amendments. 
Amendments to this Charter shall be enacted in the manner provided by the Dade County Charter, and Florida State Law.

Subpart A - GENERAL ORDINANCES  
Chapter 1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 
 
Sec. 1-1. - Designation and citation of Code. 
The ordinances embraced in the following chapters and sections shall constitute and be designated as the Code of Ordinances, City of Hialeah Gardens, Florida, and may be so cited. 
(Code 1985, § 10.01)  
Sec. 1-2. - Definitions and rules of construction. 
In the construction of this Code, and of all ordinances, the following rules shall be observed, unless the context clearly indicates otherwise: 
And/or. "Or" may be read "and," and "and" may be read "or" if the sense requires it. 
Charter. The word "Charter" means the Charter of the City of Hialeah Gardens, Florida, printed as part I of this volume. 
City. The word "city" means the City of Hialeah Gardens, Florida, including its officers, boards, committees, commissions, and employees. 
City council. The term "city council" means the city council of Hialeah Gardens. 
Code. The term "Code" means the Code of Ordinances, City of Hialeah Gardens, Florida. 
Computation of time. In computing any period of time prescribed or allowed by ordinance the day of the act, event or default from which the designated period of time begins to run shall not be included. The last day of the period so computed shall be included unless it is a Saturday, Sunday or legal holiday, in which event the period shall run until the end of the next day which is neither a Saturday, Sunday or legal holiday. When the period of time prescribed or allowed is less than seven days, intermediate Saturdays, Sundays and legal holidays shall be excluded in the computation. 
State Law reference— Computation of time, Fla. Rules of Civ. Proc., Rule 1.090(a). 
County. The term "county" means the County of Dade. 
State Law reference— Dade County boundary description, F.S. § 7.13. 
F.S. Whenever the abbreviation "F.S." is used, it shall refer to the official Florida Statutes and all amendments and supplements adopted by the state legislature. 
Gender. A word importing the masculine gender only may extend and be applied to females and to firms, partnerships and corporations as well as to males. 
Interpretation. All words, matters, and phrases contained in this Code shall, except as otherwise provided in this Code, be interpreted in the manner provided by the laws of the state for the interpretation of like words, matters, and phrases occurring therein, and as far as applicable the provisions contained in the state laws for the construction of the provisions thereof shall apply to the provisions of this Code. 
Number. A word importing the singular number only may extend and be applied to several persons and things as well as to one person and thing. 
Oath. The word "oath" includes an affirmation in all cases in which, by law, an affirmation may be substituted for an oath, and in such cases the words "swear" and "sworn" shall be equivalent to the words "affirm" and "affirmed." 
Officers, employees, boards, committees, commissions. The title of any office, officer, employee, board, committee or commission shall be used as though the words "of Hialeah Gardens" were added. Whenever a provision appears authorizing or requiring a particular officer or employee of the city to do some act, it shall be construed to authorize such officer or employee to delegate, designate and authorize subordinates to do the act unless the terms of the provisions or section specify otherwise. 
Owner. The word "owner," when applied to a building or land, shall include any part owner, joint owner, tenant in common, tenant in partnership, joint tenant, or tenant by the entirety, of the whole or of a part of the building or land. 
Person. The word "person" shall include associations, clubs, societies, firms, partnerships, and bodies politic and corporate as well as individuals. 
Personal property. The term "personal property" means every species of property except real property. 
Shall, may. The word "shall" is mandatory; the word "may" is permissive. 
State. The words "the state" or "this state" shall be construed to mean the State of Florida. 
Tense. Words used in the past or present tense include the future as well as the past and present. 
(Code 1985, §§ 10.02, 10.04, 10.05, 10.08) 
State Law reference— Construction of statutes, F.S. § 1.01 et seq.  
Sec. 1-3. - Catchlines and headings. 
The headings and captions of the several sections of this Code are intended as mere catchwords to indicate the contents of the section and shall not be deemed or taken to be the titles of the sections, nor as any part of the section, nor, unless expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed when any of the sections, including the captions, are amended or reenacted. 
(Code 1985, § 10.03)  
Sec. 1-4. - Internal references to chapters, articles, divisions or sections. 
Whenever in one section of this Code reference is made to another section of this Code, the reference shall extend and apply to the section referred to as subsequently amended, revised, recodified, or renumbered unless the subject matter is changed or materially altered by the amendment or revision. 
(Code 1985, § 10.07)  
Sec. 1-5. - History notes. 
The history notes appearing in parentheses after sections of this Code are not intended to have any legal effect, but are merely intended to indicate the source of matter contained in the section.  
Sec. 1-6. - References to chapters or sections. 
All references to chapters or sections are to the chapters and sections of this Code, unless otherwise specified.  
Sec. 1-7. - References and editor's notes. 
References and editor's notes following certain sections of this Code are inserted as an aid and guide to the reader and are not controlling or meant to have any legal effect.  
Sec. 1-8. - Provisions considered as continuation of existing ordinances. 
The provisions appearing in this and the following chapters and sections, so far as they are the same as ordinances existing at the time of the adoption of this Code, shall be considered as a continuation thereof and not as new enactments.  
Sec. 1-9. - Ordinances not affected by Code. 
Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall affect any ordinance: 
(1)  Promising or guaranteeing the payment of money by or to the city, or authorizing the issuance of any bonds of the city or any evidence of the city's indebtedness, or any contract or obligation assumed by the city; 
(2)  Appropriating funds or establishing or relating to the annual budget; 
(3)  Imposing taxes which are not inconsistent with this Code; 
(4)  Establishing positions, classifying employees or setting salaries and any personnel regulations, pension or deferred compensation plans or other benefits; 
(5)  Any right of franchise granted by the city; 
(6)  Dedicating, naming, establishing, locating, relocating, opening, paving, widening, or vacating any street or public way; 
(7)  Establishing or prescribing street grades; 
(8)  Providing for local improvements and assessing taxes therefor; 
(9)  Prescribing through streets, parking prohibitions, parking limitations, one-way streets, speed limits, load limits or loading zones not inconsistent with this Code; 
(10)  Which rezones specific property; 
(11)  Dedicating, accepting or rejecting any plat or subdivision; 
(12)  Annexing or deannexing property; 
(13)  Which is special although permanent; 
(14)  Which is temporary, although general; 
(15)  Regarding any fees, charges, rates, or deposits. 
All such ordinances are hereby recognized as continuing in full force and effect to the same extent as if set out at length in this Code and are on file in the city clerk's office. 
(Code 1985, § 10.13)  
Sec. 1-10. - Effect of repeal of ordinance. 
(a)  The repeal of an ordinance shall not revive any ordinances in force before or at the time the ordinance repealed took effect. 
(b)  The repeal of an ordinance shall not affect any punishment or penalty incurred before the repeal took effect, nor any suit, prosecution, or proceeding pending at the time of the repeal for an offense committed or cause of action arising under the ordinance repealed. 
(Code 1985, § 10.11)  
Sec. 1-11. - Amendments to Code; effect of new ordinances; amendatory language. 
(a)  All ordinances passed subsequent to the adoption of this Code which amend, repeal or in any way affect this Code may be numbered in accordance with the numbering system of this Code and printed for inclusion herein. In the case of repealed chapters, sections and subsections or any part thereof by subsequent ordinances, such repealed portions may be excluded from the Code by the omission thereof from reprinted pages affected thereby. The subsequent ordinances as numbered and printed or as omitted, in the case of repeal, shall be prima facie evidence of such subsequent ordinances until such time that this Code of Ordinances and subsequent ordinances numbered or omitted are readopted as a new Code of Ordinances by the city council. 
(b)  Amendments to any of the provisions of this Code may be made by amending such provisions by specific reference to the section number of this Code in substantially the following language: "That section _____ of the Code of Ordinances, City of Hialeah Gardens, Florida, is hereby amended to read as follows:…." The new provisions shall then be set out in full as desired. 
(c)  If a new section not then existing in the Code is to be added, the following language may be used: "That the Code of Ordinances, City of Hialeah Gardens, Florida, is hereby amended by adding a section, to be numbered _____, which said section reads as follows:…." The new section shall then be set out in full as desired. 
(d)  All sections, articles, chapters or provisions desired to be repealed must be specifically repealed by section, article or chapter number, as the case may be. 
State Law reference— Minimum procedural requirements for adoption of ordinances and resolutions, F.S. § 166.041.  
Sec. 1-12. - Supplementation of Code. 
(a)  By contract or by city personnel, supplements to this Code shall be prepared and printed whenever authorized or directed by the city. A supplement to the Code shall include all substantive permanent and general parts of ordinances passed by the city council or adopted by initiative and referendum during the period covered by the supplement and all changes made thereby in the Code, and shall also include all amendments to the Charter during the period. The pages of a supplement shall be so numbered that they will fit properly into the Code and will, where necessary, replace pages which have become obsolete or partially obsolete, and the new pages shall be so prepared that, when they have been inserted, the Code will be current through the date of adoption of the latest ordinance included in the supplement. 
(b)  In preparing a supplement to this Code, all portions of the Code which have been repealed shall be excluded from the Code by the omission thereof from reprinted pages. 
(c)  When preparing a supplement to this Code, the codifier, meaning the person authorized to prepare the supplement, may make formal, nonsubstantive changes in ordinances and parts of ordinances included in the supplement, insofar as it is necessary to do so to embody them into a unified code. For example, the codifier may: 
(1)  Organize the ordinance material into appropriate subdivisions; 
(2)  Provide appropriate catchlines, headings and titles for sections and other subdivisions of the Code printed in the supplement and make changes in catchlines, headings and titles; 
(3)  Assign appropriate numbers to sections and other subdivisions to be inserted in the Code and, where necessary to accommodate new material, change existing section or other subdivision numbers; 
(4)  Change the words "this ordinance" or words of the same meaning to "this chapter," "this article," "this division," etc., as the case may be, or to "sections _____ through _____." The inserted section numbers will indicate the sections of the Code which embody the substantive sections of the ordinance incorporated into the Code; and 
(5)  Make other nonsubstantive changes necessary to preserve the original meaning of ordinance sections inserted into the Code, but in no case shall the codifier make any change in the meaning or effect of ordinance material included in the supplement or already embodied in the Code.  
Sec. 1-13. - Altering Code. 
It shall be unlawful for any person in the city to change or amend, by additions or deletions, any part or portion of this Code, or to insert or delete pages, or portions thereof, or to alter or tamper with the Code in any manner whatsoever which will cause the law of the city to be misrepresented thereby. 
(Code 1985, § 10.14)  
Sec. 1-14. - Errors and omissions. 
If a manifest error is discovered in this Code, consisting of the misspelling of any words; the omission of any word or words necessary to express the intention of the provisions affected; the use of a word or words to which no meaning can be attached; or the use of a word or words when another word or words was clearly intended to express the intent, the spelling shall be corrected and the word or words supplied, omitted, or substituted as will conform with the manifest intention of the city council, and the provisions shall have the same effect as though the correct words were contained in the text as originally published. No alteration shall be made or permitted if any question exists regarding the nature or extent of the error. 
(Code 1985, § 10.09)  
Sec. 1-15. - Severability. 
The sections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses, and phrases of this Code are severable, and if any phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph, or section of this Code is declared unconstitutional by the valid judgment or decree of a court of competent jurisdiction, the unconstitutionality shall not affect any of the remaining phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs, and sections of this Code. 
(Code 1985, § 10.06)  
Sec. 1-16. - General penalty. 
Unless otherwise specifically provided in this Code, any person violating any of the provisions of the Code shall be punished by a fine not exceeding $500.00 or by imprisonment in the county jail for a period not to exceed 60 days, or by both such fine and imprisonment at the discretion of the court. 
(Code 1985, § 10.99) 
State Law reference— Penalty for ordinance violations, F.S. § 162.21.  
Chapter 2 - ADMINISTRATION[1] 
Footnotes:
