Cross reference— Administration of the flood hazard reduction regulations, § 70-61 et seq.; administration and enforcement of the land use regulations, § 78-41 et seq.; administration of the sign regulations, § 82-31 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 2-1. - City flag adopted. 
Ordinance No. 2000-05 adopted an official flag for the City of Hialeah Gardens, Florida. This flag will be on display in city hall. 
(Ord. No. 2000-05, § 1, 7-19-00)  
Secs. 2-2—2-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - CITY COUNCIL[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Charter reference— Compensation, art. III, § 4; election, art. III, § 9; legislative powers vested in city council, art. III, § 1; powers of city council, art. III, § 12; rules governing city council, art. III, § 12; standards of conduct, art. III, § 11; vacancies, art. III, § 15. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 2-31. - Requirements for holding elective office. 
Under the power granted by F.S. § 166.021, the city council hereby declares that a necessary requisite for the holding of an elective office of the city shall be faithful devotion to the duties inherent in the office. These duties include, but are not limited to, faithful attendance at all meetings, regular and special, of the city council by the members of the council, the mayor, and the city clerk. 
(Code 1985, § 31.01) 
Charter reference— Qualifications, art. III, § 6.  
Sec. 2-32. - Certification of elected officials. 
After the certification of elected officials by the board of elections, the officials shall take their oath of office within 48 hours after the close of the polls on the date of the city's runoff election. Such officials shall assume their respective duties in compliance with F.S. § 166.021. 
(Code 1985, § 31.02)  
Sec. 2-33. - Group insurance benefits. 
Elected officials of the city shall be eligible to participate in the city's group insurance program, in the same manner and to the same extent as if the elected official were an employee of the city. Elected officials may include their spouse and/or any other eligible dependents under the group insurance coverage in the same manner and to the same extent as if the elected official were an employee of the city. 
(Ord. No. 90-31, § 1(31.03), 4-2-91; Ord. No. 92-09, § 1(31.03), 12-1-92)  
Sec. 2-34. - Continuation of group insurance. 
(a)  Former elected officials who have served at least one year with the city shall be eligible to participate in the city's group insurance program in like manner as an employee, upon payment by the former elected official of the total premium required for such coverage. This section is intended to permit former elected officials to enjoy participation in the city's group insurance program to the same extent as city employees. 
(b)  The full cost of the premium authorized by this section for coverage of the former elected official and/or his spouse and any other eligible dependents shall be paid by the former elected official. 
(c)  The former elected official may include his spouse and/or any other eligible dependents under the group insurance coverage to the same extent that he would have been able to include them if he were still an elected official of the city, merely by the payment of the full premium for himself, his spouse and/or eligible dependents by the former official. 
(d)  If the former elected official should predecease his spouse, or should die leaving other surviving eligible dependents, and if the spouse and/or other eligible dependents were covered by the city's group insurance at the time of the former elected official's death, then the spouse and/or other eligible dependents may elect to continue coverage for as long as they would have been eligible had the former elected official survived, merely by the payment of the full premium for such spouse and/or other eligible dependents. 
(Ord. No. 90-31, § 1(31.07), 4-2-91; Ord. No. 92-09, § 3, 12-1-92)  
Sec. 2-35. - Appropriation of funds. 
The city shall appropriate and provide in its annual budget sufficient moneys to meet the requirements of sections 2-33 and 2-34. 
(Ord. No. 90-31, § 1(31.08), 4-2-91; Ord. No. 92-09, § 4, 12-1-92)  
Sec. 2-36. - Expenses and reimbursement. 
The rate of compensation paid to councilpersons shall be set by ordinance, provided, however, that there shall be at least a required four-fifths vote of the council for adoption of any such ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 98-14, § 3, 8-18-98; Ord. No. 99-08, § 1, 4-20-99) 
Editor's note— By direction of the city, § 2-36 has been revised to be consistent with § 4 of the Charter.  
Secs. 2-37—2-50. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - MAYOR[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Charter reference— Compensation, art. III, § 4; authority to break tie vote, art. III, § 1; powers, art. III, § 3; election, art. III, § 9; filling of vacancy, art. III, § 15; preparation of budget, art. III, § 2; full-time position, art. III, § 9. 
 
Sec. 2-51. - Term; duties upon leaving office. 
(a)  The mayor shall serve for a term as provided in the Charter, article III, section 9B. If for some reason the mayor shall not be able to complete his term in office, the office of mayor shall be filled for the incompleted term in accordance with Charter, article III, section 15C.2. 
(b)  Whenever a person has been elected and taken the oath of office of mayor, he shall be required, on termination of his term of office, to present to the city council, at the last regular meeting before expiration of his term of office, a final accounting of any funds, books, records, or any other matters or items belonging to the city which he had possession of as a result of such office. The council shall, if all is in order, approve the final accounting, thus allowing the person next assuming the office to be in a position of being fully aware of the obligations which that person shall assume. 
(Code 1985, § 31.11(A))  
Sec. 2-52. - Resignation. 
If the office of mayor becomes vacated by tendered resignation, the resignation shall not be accepted until a final accounting has been approved. 
(Code 1985, § 31.11(B))  
Sec. 2-53. - Expenses and reimbursement. 
The rate of compensation paid to the mayor shall be set by ordinance, provided, however, that there shall be at least a rewquried four-fifths vote of the council for adoption of any such ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 98-14, § 2, 8-18-98; Ord. No. 99-08, § 1, 4-20-99) 
Editor's note— By direction of the city, § 2-53 has been revised to be consistent with § 4 of the Charter.  
Secs. 2-54—2-70. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - MEETINGS AND RULES OF PROCEDURE[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Charter reference— Rules of city council, art. III, § 12. 
 
Sec. 2-71. - Adoption of rules. 
(a)  It is necessary that every deliberative body be governed by rules of procedure in order that the will of a majority of its members may be determined and revealed in an orderly manner. 
(b)  The city council must have rules to promote the orderly and businesslike consideration of the questions which come before it for determination. These rules shall determine the priority and manner of consideration of questions, and will provide an orderly and methodical plan so that all business may receive proper consideration, thus eliminating confusion and waste of time and effort. 
(c)  The city council has an inherent right to regulate its own procedure, subject to provisions of the state constitution, Florida Statutes, the City Charter, or other controlling authority. 
(d)  Sections 2-73 through 2-90 are the rules of procedure and shall govern all meetings of the city council. 
(Code 1985, § 30.01)  
Sec. 2-72. - Copy of rules available. 
The rules of procedure shall be made available for inspection by concerned parties at the city hall during normal business hours of city business. 
(Code 1985, § 30.02)  
Sec. 2-73. - Meetings. 
(a)  Regular meetings. The city council, at its organizational meeting following the runoff election, shall fix the day to hold regular meetings. When the day fixed for any regular meeting falls on a day designated by law as a legal holiday, the meeting may be held on the next succeeding day or may be canceled, at the discretion of the city council. Regular meetings may be otherwise postponed or canceled by resolution or motion adopted at a regular meeting by a majority of the councilmembers present. Notice of the postponement or cancellation of any regular meeting shall be published in a newspaper of general circulation by the city clerk for at least one publication. All regular meetings shall be held in the council chambers in city hall or at a place as approved by resolution or motion adopted at a regular meeting by a majority of the councilmembers present, and shall be open to the public and all news media. 
(b)  Special meetings. A special meeting of the city council may be called by the mayor, council chairperson, or by a majority of the members of the council. Whenever a special meeting is called, a notice in writing signed by the mayor, the council chairperson, or a majority of the members of the council shall be served on the city clerk. The city clerk shall forthwith serve verbal and written notice on each member of the council, the mayor, and the city attorney, stating the date, hour, and place of the meeting, and the purpose for which the meeting is called. No other business shall be transacted at such meeting. At least 48 hours must elapse between the time the city clerk receives notice in writing of such meeting and the time the meeting is to be held. 
(c)  Emergency meetings. An emergency meeting of the city council may be called by the mayor or the council chairperson, whenever in their opinion an emergency exists which requires immediate action by the city council. Whenever an emergency meeting is called, the mayor or the council chairperson shall notify the city clerk, who shall forthwith serve verbal (telephone) and written notice on each member of the city council, the mayor, and the city attorney. Such notice shall state the date, hour, and place of such meeting, and the purpose for which it is called. No other business shall be transacted at such meeting. At least 24 hours shall elapse between the time the city clerk receives notice of such meeting and the time the meeting is to be held. 
(d)  Notice requirements for special or emergency meetings; meetings open to public. If after reasonable diligence, it was impossible to give notice of a special or emergency meeting to each city councilmember, the failure shall not affect the legality of the meeting if a quorum is in attendance. The minutes of each special or emergency meeting shall show the manner and method by which notice of the special or emergency meeting was given to each member of the city council, or shall show a waiver of notice. All special or emergency meetings shall be open to the public and all news media. Anything to the contrary in this section notwithstanding, notice of any special or emergency meeting of the city council shall be waived only by not less than a majority of the entire membership of the city council. No special or emergency meeting shall be held unless notice is given in compliance with the provisions of this section, or notice is waived by a majority of the entire membership of the city council. 
(Code 1985, § 30.04) 
State Law reference— Open meetings, F.S. ch. 286.  
Sec. 2-74. - Agenda. 
(a)  There shall be an official agenda for every meeting of the city council, which shall determine the order of business conducted at the meeting. The city council shall not take action on any matter, proposal, or item of business which is not listed upon the official agenda, unless all of the city councilmembers present shall have first agreed to amend the agenda to include such item. No ordinance, resolution, or other matter listed on the agenda for public hearing or the vote thereon may be deferred until a later time unless two-thirds of the city council present shall vote in favor of the deferral. 
(b)  The agenda shall be prepared by the city clerk in appropriate form approved by the city council. Matters may be placed on the agenda by any councilmember, the mayor, the city attorney, or the city clerk. 
(c)  The deadline for placing matters on the agenda for regular meetings of the city council shall be noon of the seventh day preceding the day of the meeting. 
(Code 1985, § 30.05)  
Sec. 2-75. - Presiding officer. 
(a)  The chairperson of the city council shall preside at all meetings at which he is present. In the absence of the chairperson, the vice-chairperson of the city council shall preside. The chairperson and vice-chairperson shall be selected by the city council pursuant to the guidelines set forth in the Charter, article III, section 2C. The presiding officer shall preserve strict order and decorum at all meetings of the city council. He shall state every question coming before the city council and announce the decision of the council on all matters coming before it. 
During periods when the chairperson is also the acting mayor, the chairperson may, at any meeting such chairperson desires, delegate to the vice chairperson the duties required to preside over city council meetings to facilitate the acting mayor's consideration of issues before the council, provided it shall always be the chairperson's responsibilities to preserve strict order and decorum at all meetings of the city council. 
(b)  A majority vote of the city councilmembers present shall govern and conclusively determine all questions of order not otherwise covered. The presiding officer shall vote on all questions, his name being called last. The presiding officer shall be further permitted to offer any motion or resolution from the chair. 
(c)  In the absence of the chairperson, or in the event of his inability to serve by reason of illness or accident, the vice-chairperson shall perform the duties and functions of the chairperson until his return to the city or recovery and resumption of duty. 
(Code 1985, § 30.06; Ord. No. 99-42, § 1, 1-4-00)  
Sec. 2-76. - City attorney as parliamentarian. 
The city attorney, or his designee in his absence, shall act as parliamentarian, and shall advise and assist the presiding officer in matters of parliamentary law. The city attorney, or a member of his office as he may designate, shall be available to the city council at all meetings. 
(Code 1985, § 30.07)  
Sec. 2-77. - Call to order. 
The presiding officer shall take the chair at the hour appointed for the meeting, and shall call the city council to order immediately. In the absence of the chairperson and vice-chairperson of the city council, the city clerk shall then determine whether a quorum is present and in that event shall call for the election of a temporary chairperson. Upon the arrival of the chairperson or the vice-chairperson, the temporary chairperson shall relinquish the chair upon the conclusion of the business immediately before the city council. 
(Code 1985, § 30.08)  
Sec. 2-78. - Roll call. 
Before proceeding with the business of the city council, the city clerk shall call the roll of the members of the city council, and the names of those present shall be entered in the minutes. If the roll call reflects the absence of any councilmember on official city business, that fact shall be noted in the minutes. Any councilmember who intends to be absent from any council meeting shall notify the city clerk of the intended absence as soon as the member conveniently can do so. 
(Code 1985, § 30.09)  
Sec. 2-79. - Quorum; conflict of interest. 
(a)  A majority of the whole number of members of the city council shall constitute a quorum. No ordinance, resolution, or motion shall be adopted by the city council without the affirmative vote of the majority of all the members present. 
(b)  A member of the city council who has a conflict of interest on a particular matter before the council shall comply with the provisions in F.S. § 112.3143(3)(a) where applicable. 
(c)  If a quorum is not present within 30 minutes after the hour appointed for the meeting of the city council, the chairperson, the vice-chairperson, or in their absence the city clerk, may adjourn the meeting until the next day, unless by unanimous agreement those members present select another hour or day. The names of the members present and their action at the meeting shall be recorded in the minutes by the city clerk. 
(Code 1985, § 30.10) 
State Law reference— Voting conflicts, F.S. §§ 112.3143(3), 286.012.  
Sec. 2-80. - Order of business. 
All meetings of the city council shall be open to the public. Promptly at the hour set for each meeting, the members of the city council, the city attorney, the mayor, and the city clerk shall take their regular stations in the meeting room, and the business of the council shall be taken up for consideration and disposition in accordance with the agenda for the meeting. 
(Code 1985, § 30.11)  
Sec. 2-81. - Rules of debate. 
(a)  When a motion is presented and seconded, it is under consideration by the council and no other motion shall be received thereafter, except to adjourn, to lay on the table, to postpone, or to amend, until the question is decided. These motions shall have preference in the order in which they are mentioned and the first two shall be decided without debate. Final action upon a pending motion may be deferred until a date certain by a majority of the councilmembers present. 
(b)  The chairperson, the vice-chairperson, or other member of the council as may be presiding, may move, second, and debate, subject only to the limitations of debate as are by these rules imposed upon all councilmembers. 
(c)  Every councilmember desiring to speak for any purpose shall address the presiding officer, and upon recognition, shall confine himself to the question under debate, avoiding all personalities and indecorous language. The consequences of a measure may be denounced in strong terms; but to attack the motives of those who propose or advocate it shall not be in order. 
(d)  A councilmember once recognized shall not be interrupted when speaking unless it is to call the member to order or as otherwise provided in this section. If a member, while speaking, is called to order, the member shall cease speaking until the question of order is determined by the presiding officer, and, if in order, the member shall be permitted to proceed. Any member may appeal to the city council from the decision of the chairperson upon a question of order, when without debate the chairperson shall submit to the council the question, "Shall the decision of the chair be sustained?" The council shall decide such question by a majority vote. 
(e)  The councilmember moving the adoption of an ordinance or resolution shall have the privilege of closing the debate. 
(f)  Upon any roll call there shall be no discussion by any member voting, and he shall vote yes or no. Any member, upon voting, may give a brief statement to explain his vote. A member shall have the privilege of filing with the city clerk a written explanation of his vote. 
(g)  An action of the city council may be reconsidered only at the same meeting at which the action was taken or at the next regular meeting thereafter. A motion to reconsider may be made only by a member who voted on the prevailing side of the question and must be concurred in by a majority of those present at the meeting. A motion to reconsider shall not be considered unless at least the same number of members are present as participated in the original vote under consideration, or upon affirmative vote of two-thirds of those members present. Adoption of a motion to reconsider shall rescind the action reconsidered. 
(h)  Any member of the council may change his vote before the next item is called for consideration, or before a recess or adjournment is called, whichever occurs first, but not thereafter. 
(i)  Once action is taken on a proposed ordinance or resolution, which action was by four votes, neither the same matter nor its repeal or rescission may be brought before the city council again during the six-month period following such action, subject to the provisions of subsection (g) of this section, unless application by a majority of the councilmembers is first submitted to the mayor. If an ordinance or resolution is proposed that raises the same previously resolved matter, or its repeal or rescission, in different or modified form during such six-month period, the chairperson may declare the proposal out of order. 
(Code 1985, § 30.12)  
Sec. 2-82. - Reading of the minutes. 
(a)  Unless a reading of the minutes of a meeting is requested by a majority of the city council, the minutes, when approved by the council and signed by the chairperson and the city clerk, shall be considered approved without reading, provided that the clerk shall have given each member of the council a copy. The minutes of prior meetings may only be approved by a majority of the councilmembers present at a meeting of the council, and upon approval shall become the official minutes. 
(b)  The minutes of each council meeting shall be corrected or amended informally, the presiding officer directing the correction to be made when suggested, but if objection is made, the correction or amendment must be approved by the majority of the councilmembers present. Minutes of prior meetings may be corrected whenever the error is noticed, regardless of the time which has elapsed, and a majority vote of the councilmembers present is required for the adoption of the corrections or amendments, even though the minutes have previously been approved and it is too late to reconsider that vote. 
(Code 1985, § 30.13)  
Sec. 2-83. - Voting. 
On every roll call vote, the surname of the city councilmember present shall be called by the city clerk, who will tabulate the votes and announce the results. The vote on every ordinance shall be taken by roll call. The vote on any resolution, motion, or other matter may be by voice vote, unless the presiding officer or any councilmember desires a roll call vote to be taken on the resolution or motion. 
(Code 1985, § 30.14)  
Sec. 2-84. - Addressing the council. 
(a)  All proceedings and the order of business at all meetings of the city council shall be conducted in accordance with the official agenda. Any departure from the order of business set forth in the official agenda shall be made only upon majority vote of the members of the council present at the meeting. Any citizen shall be entitled to be placed on the official agenda of a regular meeting of the council and be heard concerning any matter within scope of the jurisdiction of the council. City councilmembers, the mayor, and the city clerk may place a citizen on the official agenda. The deadline for placing a citizen on the agenda is noon on Tuesday of the week preceding the week of the meeting at which the citizen wishes to be heard. Any citizen shall be entitled to speak on any matter appearing on the official agenda, but only when recognized by the presiding officer, and only on the subject matter under consideration at the time by the council. 
(b)  No citizen shall be permitted to address the council on any matter not appearing on the official agenda, unless the council first grants permission to be heard by a two-thirds vote of the entire council. 
(c)  Each person, other than a salaried member of the city, who addresses the city council shall stand before the council and shall give the following information in an audible tone of voice for the minutes. 
(1)  Such person's name. 
(2)  His address. 
(3)  Whether he speaks for himself, a group of persons, or a third party. If the person says that he represents an organization, he shall also indicate the number of members in the organization, the date of the most recent meeting of the organization's board or governing council, and whether the views expressed by the speaker represent an established policy of the organization approved by the board or governing council. 
(4)  Whether he is being compensated by the persons for whom he speaks. 
(5)  Whether he or any member of his immediate family has a personal financial interest in the pending matter, other than that set forth in subsection (c)(4) of this section. 
(d)  Unless further time is granted by the city council, the citizen shall limit his address to five minutes. All remarks shall be addressed to the council as a body and not to any member thereof. No person, other than councilmembers and the person having the floor, shall be permitted to enter into any discussion, either directly or through a member of the council, without the permission of the presiding officer. No question shall be asked a councilmember or the mayor except through the presiding officer. 
(Code 1985, § 30.15)  
Sec. 2-85. - Decorum. 
Any person making impertinent or slanderous remarks or who becomes boisterous while addressing the city council shall be barred from further audience before the council by the presiding officer, unless permission to continue or again address the council is granted by the majority vote of the councilmembers present. 
(Code 1985, § 30.16)  
Sec. 2-86. - Sergeant-at-arms. 
The chief of police or his designee, or any other city official or employee as the city council may designate, shall be the sergeant-at-arms of the council meeting. The sergeant-at-arms shall carry out all orders and instructions given by the presiding officer for the purpose of maintaining order and decorum at the meetings. 
(Code 1985, § 30.17)  
Sec. 2-87. - Persons authorized on dais. 
No person, except city councilmembers, the mayor, and the city attorney, shall be permitted on the dais, and no person shall be permitted to disturb any councilmember while on the dais during any meeting without the express permission of the presiding officer. 
(Code 1985, § 30.18)  
Sec. 2-88. - Committees. 
(a)  There shall be no committees of the city council, other than those provided for in subsection (b) of this section, except that the council may resolve itself into a committee of the whole at any regular or special meeting and select a chairman to preside over the meeting of the committee of the whole. In addition thereto, whenever the council deems it necessary or desirable that the council shall be represented at meetings, conferences, or other occasions involving other governmental entities, agencies, officials or groups, or nongovernmental organizations, departments, agencies, officials or groups, the mayor, or the chairperson of the city council in his absence, may designate members of the council, or himself, to represent the council at the meetings, conferences, or other occasions, with the consent of the designee. A majority of the councilmembers present may disapprove any such appointment. The representatives shall have no power to act for or on behalf of the council, or to make any commitment or binding obligation on behalf of the council or the city. The representatives shall report in writing to the council with regard to the meeting, conference, or other occasion. 
(b)  The city council may establish ad hoc committees from time to time as specific needs arise. The mayor, or chairperson of the council in his absence, shall make appointments to the committees with the consent of the appointees. A majority of the councilmembers present may disapprove any appointment. Any special ad hoc committees may be abolished by the mayor, or the chairperson of the council in his absence, when its continued existence no longer is necessary. A majority of the councilmembers present may disapprove the abolition of any such committee. 
(Code 1985, § 30.19)  
Sec. 2-89. - Ordinances, resolutions, contracts, motions. 
(a)  The city attorney, when requested by the city council, shall prepare ordinances and resolutions which shall be delivered to the city clerk. Ordinances shall be introduced and adopted pursuant to the guidelines set forth in article III, section 13, of the Charter. 
(b)  All ordinances, resolutions, and contract documents, before presentation to the council, shall have been reduced to writing and shall have been approved as to form and legality by the city attorney. Prior to the presentation to the city council, all such documents may be referred to the head of the department under whose jurisdiction the administration of the subject matter of the ordinance, resolution, or contract document would devolve. 
(c)  Ordinances, resolutions, and other matters and subjects requiring action by the city council must be introduced and sponsored by a member of the city council, except that either the mayor or the city attorney may present ordinances, resolutions, and other matters or subjects to the council for consideration. Any councilmember may assume sponsorship thereof by moving that the ordinance, resolution, matter, or subject be adopted in accordance with law; without such sponsorship, they shall not be considered. 
(d)  All actions of the city council may be taken by resolution or ordinance, except that any action of the council which provides for raising revenue, appropriating funds, or incurring indebtedness, or which provides a penalty or establishes a rule or regulation for the violation of which a penalty is imposed, shall be by ordinance, and except that approval of purely administrative matters may be accomplished by motion duly adopted and recorded in the minutes of the meeting. 
(Code 1985, § 30.20) 
Charter reference— Ordinance adoption procedure, art. III, § 13; three votes necessary to act on any matter, art. III, §§ 12C., 13D.  
Sec. 2-90. - Adjournment. 
A motion to adjourn shall always be in order and decided without debate. 
(Code 1985, § 30.21)  
Sec. 2-91. - Duties of city clerk. 
The city clerk, or designated deputy clerk, shall act as clerk of the city council. The city clerk shall duplicate the minutes and all resolutions and ordinances, and for a reasonable charge shall furnish copies to persons desiring them. The city clerk shall make available to the members of the city council a copy of the agenda 24 hours before the meeting. 
(Code 1985, § 30.22)  
Secs. 2-92—2-110. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Secs. 2-111—2-125. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - CITY CLERK[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Charter reference— Mayor appoints employees, exception, art. III, § 3H.; duties of city clerk as to elections, art. III, § 7. 
 
Sec. 2-126. - Appointment and removal; responsibilities. 
The city clerk shall be appointed or removed by the mayor and shall be under the direct supervision of the mayor. The city clerk shall be the official keeper of the city seal. In addition, but not in limitation, the city clerk shall perform and be responsible for the following: 
(1)  Be the supervisor of elections and be responsible for the preparation of the ballot and the conduct of all elections of the city. 
(2)  Appoint deputy clerks as may from time to time be necessary to carry out the duties of the office. 
(3)  Attend all meetings of the city council and keep the minutes of all these meetings. 
(4)  Certify and maintain all permanent official records and archives of the city, with the exception of police department records. Police department records shall be maintained within the police department and it shall be the responsibility of the police chief to certify and maintain all permanent official records and archives of the police department. 
(5)  Certify all ordinances and resolutions adopted by the city council. 
(6)  Perform all other duties required by ordinance or resolution of the city council or as otherwise needed in the day-to-day operation of the city. 
(Code 1985, §§ 30.06, 31.13(A); Ord. No. 97-22A, § 2, 1-6-97)  
Sec. 2-127. - Duty upon termination of office. 
The city clerk shall be required, on termination of his office, to present to the city council, at the last regular meeting before termination of his office, a final accounting of any funds, books, records, or any other matters or items belonging to the city which he had possession of as a result of the office. The city council shall, if all is in order, approve the final accounting, thus allowing the person next assuming the office to be in a position of being fully aware of the obligations which that person shall assume. 
(Code 1985, § 31.13(B))  
Sec. 2-128. - Vacancies in office; final accounting. 
Should the office of city clerk become vacated by tendered resignation, the resignation shall not be accepted until a final accounting has been approved. Should the office of city clerk become vacant because of disqualification or death, the president of the city council shall appoint one of the qualified electors of the city to survey the office which has become vacant and to render to the city council, after the survey, an accounting of the status of the office, which shall, if in proper order, be approved by the city council. 
(Code 1985, § 31.13(C))  
Sec. 2-129. - Council administrative assistant. 
The position of council administrative assistant is hereby established. The council administrative assistant shall assist and be under the supervision of the city clerk. 
(Code 1985, § 30.23)  
Secs. 2-130—2-145. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - DEPARTMENTS  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Secs. 2-146—2-160. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - POLICE DEPARTMENT 
 
Sec. 2-161. - Created; duties generally. 
There is hereby created and established a police department of the city, together with its employees, the duties of which are set forth in section 2-164. The police department shall have, in addition, those duties as established by state law, the Charter, and city ordinances and resolutions. 
(Code 1985, § 32.10(A); Ord. No. 90-64, § 1, 4-21-92)  
Sec. 2-162. - Composition. 
The police department shall be composed of a chief of police, as provided in section 2-163, and any police officers, patrol officers, and other employees as the mayor and council may determine. There shall be but one chief of police who shall oversee all police functions. 
(Code 1985, § 32.12; Ord. No. 90-64, § 3, 4-21-92)  
Sec. 2-163. - Chief of police. 
(a)  There is hereby created and established the office of the chief of police. 
(b)  The term of office of the chief of police shall be set by the city council. This provision shall in no way interfere with article III, section 3(H) of the Charter, giving the mayor the power to appoint and remove the chief of police. 
(c)  If a chief of police is not appointed in conformance with the provisions in the Charter, the police department shall be under the direct supervision of the mayor who shall carry out the orders and mandates of the city council. 
(d)  The chief of police shall have immediate direction and control of the police force, subject, however, to the supervision of the mayor, who shall carry out the mandates of the city council. 
(e)  The chief of police shall hire all police officers and other employees of the police department, subject to the approval of the mayor. 
(f)  The chief of police shall have the right and power to suspend any of the officers or employees under his immediate command who may be under his management or control for incompetency, common neglect of duty, immorality, drunkenness, failure to obey orders given by proper authorities, or for any other just or reasonable cause, and shall forthwith certify the fact in writing, together with the cause for suspension, to the mayor. 
(g)  The mayor shall, after review of the action taken by the chief of police under subsection (f) of this section, render final judgment thereon, which may be a reprimand, fine, suspension, reduction in rank, or removal, and which shall be final. Further, the mayor shall have the right, with respect to the chief of police, to suspend the chief of police for any of the causes for which the chief of police may suspend any of the officers or employees under his immediate command. Nothing contained in this subsection shall limit any statutory or contractual rights. 
(h)  The chief of police shall, at all times, day or night, have the following duties: 
(1)  To preserve the public peace; 
(2)  To protect the rights of persons and property; 
(3)  To provide proper police force protection at fires and to protect firefighters and property thereat; 
(4)  To protect strangers and travelers within the city; 
(5)  To suppress riots and insurrections, disperse unlawful or dangerous assemblages and assemblages which obstruct free passage on public streets, sidewalks, parks, and places; 
(6)  To preserve order at elections and all public meetings and assemblages; 
(7)  To regulate the movement of vehicles in the streets; 
(8)  To prevent the violation of all laws and ordinances in force applicable to the police department; and 
(9)  To cause the immediate arrest and apprehension of any violators of the laws and ordinances. 
(i)  It shall be the duty of the chief of police at all times to see to the proper training of the patrol officers and other police officers, regular and volunteer, and the training shall include compliance with the state department of law enforcement training and standards. 
(Code 1985, §§ 32.10, 32.11, 32.15; Ord. No. 90-64, §§ 1, 2, 4-21-92)  
Sec. 2-164. - Duties. 
It shall be the duty of the members and employees of the police department to: 
(1)  Preserve the public peace; 
(2)  Detect and prevent crimes; 
(3)  Arrest violators of the law; 
(4)  Protect the rights of persons and property; 
(5)  Preserve peace at all public meetings and public places; 
(6)  Prevent and remove, whenever possible, all nuisances on or in the streets, waters, and all other places; 
(7)  Regulate and control vehicular and pedestrian traffic on the streets; 
(8)  Investigate traffic accidents and determine the cause and responsibility for the accidents; 
(9)  Enforce the penal laws of the state, county and city; 
(10)  Enforce the penal ordinances of the city; and 
(11)  Perform and discharge all other duties as are imposed upon them by the laws of the state, by Charter, ordinances or resolutions of the city, or by the city council. 
(Code 1985, § 32.13; Ord. No. 90-64, § 4, 4-21-92)  
Sec. 2-165. - Employment requirements. 
Before any member of the police department shall assume his duties as such, the member shall first be fingerprinted and be cleared in accordance with standards as are from time to time established by the state department of law enforcement. 
(Code 1985, § 32.16; Ord. No. 90-64, § 6, 4-21-92)  
Sec. 2-166. - Compensation. 
All salaries, compensations, expenses, and other payments to be made to members of the police department shall be established by the city council by resolution, and may be changed from time to time as the council shall see fit. If any employees are governed by a collectively bargained agreement, such salaries shall be subject to those provisions and negotiation required under state and/or federal law. 
(Code 1985, § 32.17; Ord. No. 90-64, § 7, 4-21-92)  
Sec. 2-167. - Recordkeeping. 
All records required to be kept by the police department shall be kept in accordance with the provisions of Florida Statutes as from time to time amended and any other requirements as established by the state department of law enforcement, inclusive of statutory requirements and rules and regulations regarding case reports of pending criminal investigations. 
(Code 1985, § 32.18; Ord. No. 90-64, § 8, 4-21-92) 
State Law reference— Public records act, F.S. § 119.07.  
Sec. 2-168. - Rules and regulations. 
The police chief shall promulgate department rules and regulations, which rules and regulations shall be approved by the city council. The rules and regulations which are currently in full force and effect shall remain in full force and effect until such time as they are amended or repealed by council action. 
(Code 1985, § 32.19; Ord. No. 90-64, § 9, 4-21-92)  
Sec. 2-169. - Disposal of abandoned property by the police department. 
(a)  The police chief is authorized to utilize the procedures outlined in F.S. § 705.101 et seq. concerning the disposal of abandoned property. 
(b)  All provisions as set forth in F.S. § 705.101 et seq. concerning abandoned property are hereby adopted and incorporated by reference. 
(c)  If, at the end of the notice period as provided for in F.S. § 705.103, the owner or any person interested in an abandoned article has not claimed such article or shown reasonable cause for failure to do so, then the police chief is directed to either salvage the article should the article be of nominal value or sell the article should in the opinion of the police chief the sale of the article be warranted. 
(Code 1985, § 32.20)  
Sec. 2-170. - Statutory powers. 
Nothing contained in this division shall in any way limit the powers of the city police department or its police chief. The police department and chief of police shall have any and all powers as are established by state statutes, as from time to time amended. 
(Ord. No. 90-64, § 11, 4-21-92)  
Secs. 2-171—2-185. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - PUBLIC WORKS DEPARTMENT 
 
Sec. 2-186. - Established; director; organization; appointments. 
(a)  The public works department of the city is hereby established. The head of the department is the director of public works, who shall be appointed by the mayor and shall serve at the will of the mayor. 
(b)  The organization and operating procedures of the public works department shall be as prescribed by the mayor. 
(c)  The mayor, with the advice of the public works director, shall appoint such employees as may be necessary to perform the functions of the public works department. The salaries for the director and all departmental officers and employees shall be fixed by the city council. The manager or director may assign one person to perform, without additional compensation, the duties of other offices or positions created by, or made necessary by, the provisions of this division. 
(Ord. No. 90-05, § 1(32.60), 3-27-90)  
Sec. 2-187. - Functions, powers and duties. 
The public works department shall perform the following functions: 
(1)  Plan, design, construct and maintain all arterial and other roads, bridges, tunnels, canals and related facilities in the city, as well as such other arterial and other roads, bridges, tunnels, canals and related facilities situated partially or entirely within the city, which are from time to time designated by the mayor. 
(2)  Develop plans and make recommendations for the establishment, merger, and abolishment of special purpose districts within which may be provided water, streets, sidewalks, street lighting, sewage collection and disposal, drainage, and other essential facilities and services, and at the direction of the mayor and city council construct, maintain, provide and administer such facilities and services. 
(3)  With the cooperation of the building department, establish and enforce minimum standards for the approval of platting or replatting of any lands in the city. 
(4)  Perform any other functions reasonably necessary to, or reasonably related to, the performance of the functions as may be designated by the mayor. 
(5)  Review plans, issue permits and make inspections of paving and drainage on public rights-of-way and private property in the city. 
(Ord. No. 90-05, § 1(32.61), 3-27-90)  
Sec. 2-188. - Permit fees. 
(a)  Collection of fees. The public works department shall charge and collect fees for public works construction, under permit issued by the public works department, in canal, road and street rights-of-way, and utility or other easements, in the city area and in rights-of-way of canals, roads and streets located within the city drainage on private property. Such fees are on file in the city clerk's office. 
(b)  Penalty fees. When work for which a permit required by this section is commenced prior to obtaining a permit, a penalty fee will be imposed. The payment of such penalty fee shall not relieve any person from fully complying with all of the requirements of all applicable regulations and codes, nor shall it relieve such persons from any of the penalties therein. 
(c)  Extension of permit. A permit may be extended for a period of up to, but not more than, one year from the expiration date of the original permit, provided the permit section of the public works department is notified prior to the expiration of the permit. If the permit is allowed to expire without requesting an extension, a new permit will be required, including appropriate fees, for the remainder of the uncompleted work. 
(Ord. No. 90-10, 4-24-90)  
Sec. 2-189. - Refund of permit fee. 
(a)  Full or partial refunds may be granted to a permit holder whose permit is canceled by owner authorization where work has commenced and the owner selects a second contractor to complete the work. The second contractor shall pay a full fee to complete the work unless the first contractor waives his opportunity to a refund in writing, in which case the second contractor is entitled to a permit to cover the same work on prorated charge basis. 
(b)  No refunds will be made where any work has commenced as evidenced by any recorded inspections having been made by the department. 
(c)  No refunds will be made where construction was stopped by court order or permits canceled by same. 
(d)  Where there is a change of contractor or qualifier involving a permit for which a fee of more than $75.00 was paid to the department the following conditions shall prevail: 
(1)  The original permit holder: 
a.  Is not entitled to any refund if the permit has expired or if work, as evidenced by any recorded inspection has commenced under such permit; or 
b.  Is entitled to a full refund where the permit has not expired and no work, as evidenced by any recorded inspection, has commenced. 
(2)  The second permit holder: 
a.  Shall pay a full fee if the original permit has expired; 
b.  Shall pay only $75.00 to cover the cost of transferring information from first permit holder permit to the second; or 
c.  Shall pay full fee plus $75.00 to cover the costs of transferring information from the first permit holder permit to the second when work, as evidenced by any recorded inspection, has commenced under the original unexpired permit. 
(Ord. No. 90-10, 4-24-90)  
Sec. 2-190. - Lost and revised plans fee. 
When plans for pavement, drainage, sidewalk, driveway or any construction on right-of-way are lost by the owner or contractor, a recertification fee will be required to review, stamp and approve a new set of plans as a field copy. Such fee shall be based on 15 percent of the original public work permit. 
(Ord. No. 90-10, 4-24-90)  
Sec. 2-191. - Reinspection fees. 
When extra inspection trips are necessary due to the wrong address being given on call for inspections, permit cards and plans not available for the inspector, the prior rejection of work due to faulty construction, work not being ready for inspections at the time specified, failure to call for final or other inspections, required corrections not being made or completed at the time specified, or other code violation or special inspections, a fee of $40.00 for each reinspection may be charged. The payment of reinspection fees may be required before any further permits will be issued to the person or firm owning same, and further inspections may be refused until payment of reinspection fees have been made. 
(Ord. No. 90-10, 4-24-90)  
Sec. 2-192. - Exception. 
A fee will be charged for each permit except when waived for governmental agencies. 
(Ord. No. 90-10, 4-24-90)  
Secs. 2-193—2-210. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - CODE COMPLIANCE[6] 
Footnotes:
