DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Secs. 2-211—2-230. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - CODE COMPLIANCE DEPARTMENT[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2006-03, § 1 (Exh. 1), adopted Feb. 7, 2006, amended Div. 2 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Div. 2, §§ 2-231—2-250.4, pertained to the zoning and code compliance department, and derived from Ord. No. 97-21, §§ 1, 2, adopted Jan. 6, 1998; Ord. No. 2001-09, § 1, adopted June 19, 2001. 
Cross reference— Code compliance department, § 78-51. 
 
Sec. 2-231. - Guidelines for code compliance department. 
There is hereby established a code compliance department. The City of Hialeah Gardens does hereby establish operational guidelines for the code compliance department. These operational guidelines shall coincide with the statutes of the State of Florida and in particular, Chapter 162, "County or Municipal Code Compliance." The intent of this division is to improve the health, safety, and welfare of the citizens of the city by providing an equitable, expeditious, effective method of enforcing the various codes that are pertinent to the city; inclusive of local business tax receipt, fire prevention, building, land use, minimum housing, contractor, sign and related technical codes. 
This division also establishes the fines that correspond to the different types of violations. The violation of any section of this Code as well as a violation of any of the regulations set forth in section 2-250.2 of this division shall constitute a civil offense punishable by civil penalty in the amount prescribed in section 2-250.2. 
(Ord. No. 2006-03, § 1 (Exh. 1), 2-7-06; Ord. No. 2008-06, § 3, 9-16-08)  
Sec. 2-232. - Federal and state authority. 
The provisions of this Code shall not deprive any federal or state agency, or any applicable governing authority having jurisdiction, of any power or authority which it had on the effective date of the adoption of this division or of any remedy then existing for the enforcement of its orders, nor shall it deprive any individual or corporation of its legal rights as provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 2006-03, § 1 (Exh. 1), 2-7-06)  
Sec. 2-233. - Creation and establishment of the code compliance department. 
There is hereby established a department to be called the code compliance department. This department shall establish operational guidelines for the department. The person in charge shall be known as the code compliance director. 
(Ord. No. 2006-03, § 1 (Exh. 1), 2-7-06)  
Sec. 2-234. - Employee qualifications. 
(a)  Code compliance director. The code compliance director shall be appointed by the mayor. The qualifications for this position are to be set by the mayor and reviewed periodically. 
(b)  Code compliance officer. The qualifications for code compliance officer will be set by the mayor and reviewed periodically. 
(Ord. No. 2006-03, § 1 (Exh. 1), 2-7-06)  
Sec. 2-235. - Powers and duties. 
(a)  Code compliance director. The code compliance director's duties are to be designated by the mayor and reviewed periodically. 
(b)  Code compliance officer. The duties of a code compliance officer are to be designated by the mayor and reviewed periodically. 
(c)  Code compliance secretary. The duties of the code compliance secretary position are to be designated by the mayor and reviewed periodically. 
(Ord. No. 2006-03, § 1 (Exh. 1), 2-7-06)  
Sec. 2-236. - Right of entry. 
Whenever necessary to make an inspection to enforce any of the provisions of this Code, or whenever any code compliance officer has reasonable cause to believe that there exists in any building or upon any premise any condition or code violation which makes such building, structure, commercial space, business space, vacant land, unsafe, dangerous or hazardous, or holds an illegal business operation, the code compliance officer may enter such building, structure, commercial space, business space, vacant land or premises at all reasonable times to inspect the same or to perform any action necessary to enforce or effectuate this Code, provided that if such building or premises is occupied at the time, he/she shall first present proper credentials to the occupant and request entry. If such building, structure, or premises is unoccupied, he/she shall first make a reasonable effort to locate the owner or other persons having charge or control of such and request entry. If entry is refused, the code compliance director shall have recourse to every recourse provided by law to secure entry. 
(Ord. No. 2006-03, § 1 (Exh. 1), 2-7-06)  
Sec. 2-237. - Warrants. 
When a code compliance officer has obtained a proper inspection warrant or other remedy or recourse provided by law to secure entry, no owner or occupant or any other persons having charge, care or control of any building, structure, or premises shall fail or neglect, after proper request is made as herein provided, to promptly permit entry to the code compliance officer for the purpose of inspection and examination pursuant to this Code. 
(Ord. No. 2006-03, § 1 (Exh. 1), 2-7-06)  
Sec. 2-238. - Liability. 
Any code compliance officer or employee of the city, charged with the enforcement of this Code, acting for the city in the discharge of his/her duties, shall not be personally liable, and is hereby relieved from all personal liability, for any damage that may accrue to persons or property as a result of any act required or permitted in the discharge of his/her duties. Any suit brought against any city employee because of an act performed in the enforcement of any provision of this Code, division or any other code adopted by the city shall be defended by the city until the final termination of the proceedings. 
(Ord. No. 2006-03, § 1 (Exh. 1), 2-7-06)  
Sec. 2-239. - Civil offenses and penalties; hearing officers. 
The violation of any section of the City Code shall constitute a civil offense punishable by civil penalty in the amount prescribed. 
Additionally, there is hereby created and established a code compliance position to be filled by a special master known as the "special master" to hear appeals in the form of administrative hearings and to consider evidence and issue orders therewith and in connection with the enforcement of city ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 2006-03, § 1 (Exh. 1), 2-7-06)  
Sec. 2-240. - Appointment and qualification of officers; removal and organization. 
(a)  Special master appointments shall be made by the mayor and city council on the basis of experience and interest in code compliance. 
(b)  The mayor and city council shall appoint as many special masters as are deemed necessary. Appointments shall be made for a term of one year and any reappointments are at the discretion of the mayor and city council. There shall be no limit on the number of reappointments that may be given to any special master provided, however, that a determination as to removal or reappointment must be made for each hearing officer at the end of each of his/her one-year terms. The mayor or city council shall have the authority to remove special masters with or without cause. Appointments to fill any vacancy shall be for the remainder of the unexpired term. 
(c)  Special masters shall be shall compensated by the code compliance department budget at the rate determined by the mayor and city council. 
(Ord. No. 2006-03, § 1 (Exh. 1), 2-7-06)  
Sec. 2-241. - Enforcement procedures. 
(a)  A code compliance officer shall have the authority to initiate an enforcement proceeding provided by this Code. No special master shall have the power to initiate proceedings provided by this Code. All code compliance proceedings shall be conducted pursuant to the provisions of F.S. ch. 162. To the extent that the provisions of this division vary from the Florida Statutes, the provisions of the Florida Statutes shall govern. Pursuant to F.S. 162.03(2), the city has chosen to adopt the code compliance system provided for herein which provides for a special master of the city with the authority specified herein. The city does not choose to have a code compliance board. 
(b)  A code compliance officer who finds a violation of any of the city ordinances shall give a maximum of 30 days for the violator to correct the violation. This determination shall be based on considerations of fairness; practicality; ease of correction; ability to correct; severity of violation; nature, extent and probability of danger or damage to the public; and other relevant factors relating to the reasonableness of the time period prescribed. A time for correction need not be specified if the violation is deemed to be not a correctable violation. 
(c)  A code compliance officer who finds such a violation shall issue a civil citation to the violator. Service shall be effective by delivering the civil citation to the violator or his agent or by leaving the civil citation at the violator's usual place of abode with any person residing therein who is 15 years of age or older and informing that person of its contents. If such service cannot be effected, the civil citation may be sent by certified mail, return receipt requested, or by posting of the civil citation in a conspicuous place on the premises or real property upon which the violation has been observed. Such posting of the civil citation shall be deemed proper service, and the time for compliance, stated in the citation, shall commence with the date such notice is posted. The civil citation shall include but not be limited to the following: 
(1)  Date and time of issuance; 
(2)  Name of code compliance officer and department issuing the civil citation; 
(3)  Name and address of the violator; 
(4)  Ordinance or section of the Code that has been violated; 
(5)  Brief description of the nature of the violation, including location, date, and time of violation; 
(6)  Amount of the civil penalty for which the violator may be liable; 
(7)  Instructions and due date for paying the civil fine or filing for an appeal at an administrative hearing before a special master. 
(8)  Time within which the violation must be corrected if applicable; 
(9)  Notice that each day of continued violation after the time period for correction has run shall be deemed a continuing violation subject to additional penalty in the same amount, without the need for issuance of additional civil violation notice; 
(10)  Notice that the filing of a request for an administrative hearing will toll the accrual of continuing violation penalties; 
(11)  Notice that failure to request an administrative hearing within five days after service of the civil citation shall constitute a waiver of the violator's right to appeal at an administrative hearing before the special master; and 
(12)  Notice that the violator may be liable for the reasonable cost of the administrative hearing as well as the cost of the violation should he be found guilty of the violation. 
(Ord. No. 2006-03, § 1 (Exh. 1), 2-7-06)  
Sec. 2-242. - Civil citations and related procedures. 
(a)  Penalties for violation(s) of the ordinances to be enforced by this division shall be in the amount prescribed in the schedule of civil citations in section 2-250.2. 
(b)  A repeat violation which remains uncorrected beyond the time prescribed for correction in the civil citation shall be treated as a continuing violation subject to additional penalties in the same amount without the need for issuance of additional civil violation notice. 
(c)  Continuing violation penalties shall accrue from the date of correction given in the civil citation until the correction is made if a request for administrative hearing is not timely filed. If the named violator requests a hearing with the special master on a correctable violation and loses this appeal, the special master shall determine a reasonable time period within which correction of the violation must be made, based an the considerations set forth in section 2-244. If correction is not made within the period set by the special master, continuing violation penalties shall begin after the time for correction has run. No continuing violation penalties shall accrue during the time period from the date of the civil citation until the date of the administrative hearing, if the named violator timely requests an administrative hearing to appeal the decision of the code compliance officer. Continuing violation penalties cannot be imposed by the hearing officer for uncorrectable violations. 
(d)  Civil citations issued to "violators" along with the penalties assessed pursuant to this division are due and payable to the city no later than the last day of the period allowed for correction of the violation. 
(Ord. No. 2006-03, § 1 (Exh. 1), 2-7-06)  
Sec. 2-243. - Right of violators; payment of fine; right to administrative hearing/appeal; failure to pay and correct, or to appeal. 
(a)  A violator who has been served with a civil citation shall elect either to: 
(1)  Pay the civil penalty in the manner indicated on the notice, and correct the violation within the time specified on the civil citation; or 
(2)  Request an administrative hearing before a special master to appeal the decision of the code compliance officer which resulted in the issuance of the civil citation. 
(b)  In order to appeal the civil citation by administrative hearing, the individual receiving the citation must file a request in writing to the address indicated on the citation no later than five calendar days after being served with the civil citation. 
(c)  If the named violator, after being served with the civil citation, fails to pay the civil penalty and correct the violation within the time specified (if applicable), or fails to timely request an administrative heating before the special master, the special master shall be informed of such failure by report from the code compliance officer. If the named violator pays the civil penalty for a correctable violation but does not correct that violation within the time specified, each day that the violation continues beyond such specified time shall constitute a continuing violation. Failure of the named violator to appeal the decision of the code compliance officer within the prescribed period shall constitute a waiver of the violator's right to administrative hearing before the special master. A waiver of the right to administrative hearing shall be treated as an admission of the violation and penalties may be assessed accordingly. 
(Ord. No. 2006-03, § 1 (Exh. 1), 2-7-06)  
Sec. 2-244. - Scheduling and conducting an administrative hearing. 
(a)  Upon receipt of a named violator's timely request for an administrative hearing, the special master shall set the matter down for hearing on the next regularly scheduled hearing date or as soon thereafter as possible. 
(b)  The special master or the code compliance department shall send a summons, by first class mail or hand delivery, to the named violator at his known address. The summons shall include but not be limited to the following: 
(1)  Name of the code compliance officer who issued the civil citation; 
(2)  Factual description of alleged violation; 
(3)  Date of alleged violation; 
(4)  Section of the code allegedly violated; 
(5)  Place, date and time of the administrative hearing; 
(6)  Right of violator to be represented by a lawyer; 
(7)  Right of violator to present witnesses and evidence; and 
(8)  Notice that failure of violator to attend the hearing may result in civil penalty being assessed against him. 
(c)  The special master shall call hearings on a monthly basis or upon the request of the code compliance department. No hearing shall be set sooner than five calendar days from the date of service of the civil citation. 
(d)  A hearing date shall not be postponed or continued unless a request for continuance, showing good cause for such continuance, is received in writing by the special master at least ten calendar days prior to the date set for the hearing. 
(e)  All code compliance hearings shall be open to the public. All testimony shall be under oath. Assuming proper notice, a hearing may proceed in the absence of the named violator. 
(f)  The proceedings at the hearing shall be recorded and may be transcribed at the expense of the party requesting the transcript. 
(g)  Each case before the special master shall be presented by the code compliance officer that issued the civil citation. In the case that the code compliance officer who issued the civil citation is absent, any other code compliance officer, with prior knowledge of the case, may present the case before the special master. 
(h)  The hearing need not be conducted in accordance with the formal rules relating to evidence and witnesses. Any relevant evidence shall be admitted if the special master finds it competent and reliable, regardless of the existence of any common law or statutory rule to the contrary. Furthermore, fundamental due process shall be observed and shall govern the proceedings. 
(i)  Each party shall have the right to call and examine witnesses to introduce exhibits; to cross examine opposing witnesses on any matter relevant to the issues even though that matter was not covered in the direct examination; to impeach any witness regardless of which party first called him/her to testify, and to rebut the evidence against him. 
(j)  The special master shall make findings of fact based on evidence of record. In order to make a finding upholding the code compliance officer's decision, the special master must find that a preponderance of the evidence indicates that the named violator was responsible and that there is as a violation of the relevant section of the Code as charged. 
(k)  If the named violator is found guilty of the violation, he will be held liable for the cost of the administrative hearing. 
(l)  The determination of the special master shall be limited to whether the violation alleged did occur and, if so, whether the person named in the civil citation is responsible for that violation. Based upon this determination, the special master shall either affirm or reverse the decision of the code compliance officer as to the responsibility of the named violator for the code violation. If the special master affirms the decision of the code compliance officer, he shall determine a reasonable time period within which the violation must be corrected. If the special master reverses the decision of the code compliance officer and finds the named violator not responsible for the Code violations alleged in the civil citation, the named violator shall not be liable for the payment of any civil penalty or for the costs associated with the administrative hearing. If the decision of the special master is to affirm, then the following elements shall be included in the decision: 
(1)  Amount of civil penalty; 
(2)  Administrative costs of hearing; and 
(3)  Date by which the violation must be corrected to prevent imposition of continuing violation penalties (if applicable). 
(m)  The special master shall have the power to: 
(1)  Adopt procedures for the conduct of hearings; 
(2)  Subpoena alleged violators and witnesses for hearings; subpoenas may be served by the city's police department, the code compliance department or by a court authorized agent; 
(3)  Subpoena evidence; 
(4)  Take testimony under oath; and 
(5)  Assess and order the payment of civil penalties as provided herein.  
Secs. 2-245—2-247. - Reserved.  
Sec. 2-248. - Administrative fines; costs of repair liens. 
(a)  The city's special master, upon notification by the code compliance officer that an order of the code compliance officer or special master has not been complied with by the set time or, upon finding that a repeat violation has been committed, may order the violator to pay a fine in an amount specified in the civil citation fee schedule for each day the violation continues past the date set by the special master for compliance or, in the case of a repeat violation, for each day the repeat violation continues, beginning with the date the repeat violation is found to have occurred by the code inspector. In addition, if the violation is a violation described in section 2-250.2, the code compliance department shall notify the city council, which may authorize all reasonable repairs, which are required to bring the property into compliance and charge the violator with the cost of the repairs along with the fine imposed pursuant to this section. If a finding of a violation or a repeat violation is made as provided in this part, a separate hearing shall not be necessary for issuance of the order imposing the fine. 
(b)  (1)  A fine imposed pursuant to this section shall not exceed $250.00 per day for a first violation and shall not exceed $500.00 per day for a repeat violation, inclusive of the costs of repairs pursuant to subsection (a). 
(2)  In determining the amount of the fine, if any, the special master shall consider the following factors: 
a.  The gravity of the violation; 
b.  Any actions taken by the violator to correct the violation; 
c.  Any previous violations committed by the violator; and 
d.  The scope of the existing regulations. 
(3)  A special master may reduce a fine imposed pursuant to this section, upon a showing of good cause. 
(c)  A certified copy of the special master's order imposing a fine may be recorded in the public record and thereafter shall constitute a lien against the land on which the violation exists and upon any other real and/or personal property owned by the violator. Upon petition to the circuit court, such order may be enforced in the same manner as a court judgment. A lien arising from a fine imposed pursuant to this section is in favor of the city, and the may execute a satisfaction or release of lien entered pursuant to this section. After three months from the filing of any such lien which remains unpaid, the code compliance department may authorize the city attorney to foreclose on real property which is not homestead under § 4, Art. X of the State Constitution. 
(Ord. No. 2006-03, § 1 (Exh. 1), 2-7-06)  
Sec. 2-249. - Duration of lien. 
No lien provided for herein shall continue for a period longer than 20 years after the certified copy of an order imposing a fine has been recorded, unless within that time an action to foreclose on the lien is commenced in a court of competent jurisdiction. In an action to foreclose on a lien, the prevailing party is entitled to recover all costs, including a reasonable attorney's fee that it incurs in the foreclosure. The city shall be entitled to collect all costs incurred in recording and satisfying a valid lien. 
(Ord. No. 2006-03, § 1 (Exh. 1), 2-7-06)  
Sec. 2-250. - Appeals. 
An aggrieved party, including the city, may appeal a final administrative order of the special master to the circuit court. Such an appeal shall not be a hearing de novo but shall be limited to appellate review of the record created before the special master. An appeal shall be filed within 30 days of the date of entry of the order to be appealed. If an appeal is filed, the city attorney's office shall represent the city at such proceedings. 
(Ord. No. 2006-03, § 1 (Exh. 1), 2-7-06)  
Sec. 2-250.1. - Notices. 
(a)  All notices required shall be provided to the alleged violator by certified mail, return receipt requested; by hand delivery by the police department, code compliance officer, or other person designated by the city; or by leaving the notice at the violator's place of residence with any person residing therein who is above 15 years of age and after informing such person of the contents of the notice. 
(b)  In addition to providing notice as set forth in subsection (a), in the event that the whereabouts of the alleged violator is unknown, and at the option of the code compliance department, notice may also be served by publication or posting, as follows: 
(1)  Such notice shall be published once in a newspaper of general circulation in the county where the violation is located. The newspaper shall meet such requirements as are prescribed under F.S. ch. 50 for legal and official advertisement. 
(c)  Proof of publication shall be made as provided by F.S. ch. 162. 
(1)  In lieu of publication as described in subsection (b), such notice may be posted for at least ten days in at least two locations, one of which shall be the property upon which the violation is alleged to exist and the other shall be at city hall. 
(d)  Proof of posting shall be by affidavit of the person posting the notice, with said affidavit shall include a copy of the notice posted and the date and places of its posting. 
(1)  Notice by publication or posting may run concurrently with, or may follow, an attempt or attempts to provide notice by hand delivery or by mail as required under subsection (a). 
(e)  Evidence that an attempt has been made to hand deliver or mail notice as provided in subsection (a), together with proof of publication or posting as provided in subsection (b), shall be sufficient to show that the notice requirements of this part have been met without regard to whether or not the alleged violator actually received such notice. 
(Ord. No. 2006-03, § 1 (Exh. 1), 2-7-06)  
Sec. 2-250.2. - Payment of civil citation and description of fee schedule. 
The fee schedule for payments of civil citations is on file in the city clerk's office. 
(Ord. No. 2006-03, § 1 (Exh. 1), 2-7-06)  
Sec. 2-250.3. - Definitions. 
For the purpose of this division the following definitions shall apply. Unless specifically defined below, words or phrases used in this Code shall be described a meaning which they have in common usage and which gives this Code its most reasonable application. 
Abut means to physically touch, or having property or district lines in common. 
Accessory structure means a subordinate structure detached from but located on the same lot as the principal structure, the use of which is incidental and subordinate to that of the principal structure. Where there is no principal structure on the lot, the accessory structure shall be considered as a principal structure for the purpose of the height, area and bulk regulations. 
Accessory use means a use incidental to, and on the same lot as, a principal one. 
Advertising signs. See chapter 82 pertaining to sign regulations. 
Alcoholic beverages. As defined by F.S. 561.01(4). 
Alley means a through public right-of-way of less than 25 feet in width that offers only secondary access to abutting properties. 
Alteration means any change in the arrangement of a building, including any work affecting the structural parts of a building or any change in wiring, plumbing or heating systems (see Florida Building Code). 
Amusement arcade means a building or a part of a building in which five or more pinball machines, video games, or other similar player operated amusement devices are maintained. 
Apartment. See dwelling, multi-family. 
Apartment building. See dwelling, multi-family. 
Auto rental lot means a lot or parcel of land on which passenger automobiles for active rental purposes are stored or parked, together with associated maintenance activities, not including mechanical or body repair. 
Automobile wrecking yard (see also junkyard) means an area where the dismantling or wrecking of used motor vehicles or trailers, or the storage, sale, or dumping of dismantled or wrecked vehicles or their parts takes place. 
Awning means an accessory structure either temporary or permanent which is supported by an open framework and is covered by a synthetic or metal material. 
Bar or saloon means any place devoted primarily to the selling or dispensing and drinking of alcoholic beverages. 
Barbecue pit or building means an open or enclosed pit or fireplace or an open or enclosed building used primarily for cooking meats in the barbecue style. 
Barbecue stand means a place to gather for the primary purpose of serving barbecued meats. 
Basement means a story partly underground and having at least one-half of its height above the average adjoining grade. A basement shall be termed a cellar when more than one-half of its height is below the average adjoining grade. A basement or cellar shall be counted as a story if vertical distance from the average adjoining grade to the ceiling is over five feet. 
Bedroom means any room used principally for sleeping purposes, an all-purpose room, a study, or a den, provided that no room has less than 100 square feet of floor area. 
Beer. As defined in F.S. 563.01. 
Block means a tract of land bounded by streets. 
Boat docking facility means a place where vessels may be secured to a fixed or floating structure or to the shoreline. 
Boat slip means a berthing space for a vessel between two piers or pilings. 
Borrow pit means any place or premises where dirt, soil, sand, gravel, or other material is removed below the grade of surrounding land for any purpose other than necessary and incidental to site grading or building construction. 
Boundary of district means any district limits shown on the comprehensive plan land use map or on the zoning district map. 
Building means any structure having a roof entirely separated from any other structure by space or by walls for the purpose of providing-support or shelter for persons, animals, things or property of any kind. 
Building height means the vertical distance from grade to the parapet or roof ridge. 
Building official means that official designated by the city to enforce the provisions of the Florida Building Code and other applicable laws. 
Bulky waste means less than one cubic yard of construction and demolition debris, large discarded items or large accumulations of trash. Bulky waste shall include, but is not limited to, appliances, furniture, yard trash, crates, corrugated cardboard, and other similar items. Bulky waste shall not include tires or other solid waste requiring special handling. 
Bundled yard trash means clean yard trash which is gathered into bundles and tied securely so that each bundle does not exceed three feet in length or weigh more than 50 pounds. 
Bus means any motor vehicle designed for carrying more than ten passengers and used for the transportation of persons; and every motor vehicle, other than a taxicab, designed and used for the transportation of persons for compensation. 
Business, professions and occupations. These activities do not include the customary religious, charitable or educational activities of NONPROFIT religious, nonprofit charitable and nonprofit educational institutions in this state; which are more particularly defined and limited as follows: 
(1)  Religious institutions. Houses of worship, church cemeteries or established physical places for worship at which NONPROFIT religious services and activities are regularly conducted and carried on, and who have registered with the State of Florida and have been approved as not-for-profit organizations by the Internal Revenue Service of the United States. 
(2)  Educational institutions. State tax-supported or parochial, church, and NONPROFIT private schools, colleges or universities conducting regular classes and courses of study required for accreditation by or membership in the Southern Association of Colleges and Secondary Schools, the Department of Education or the Florida Council of Independent Schools. Nonprofit libraries, art galleries, and museums open to the public are defined as educational institutions and eligible for exemption, if in compliance with state and federal laws and regulations for not-for-profit organizations. 
(3)  Charitable institutions. NONPROFIT corporations operating physical facilities, registered with the State of Florida, and approved by the Internal Revenue Service, at which charitable services are provided. 
Cabana or pool house means an accessory structure usually used in connection with outdoor bathing or recreation providing enclosed space for showering or changing clothes. The structure may include recreational cooking or bar facilities including storage facilities, but no sleeping rooms. 
Cabaret means a place of business other than a "night club" located in a lodging establishment having 50 or more guest rooms, where liquor, beer or wine is sold, given away or consumed on the premises, and where music or other entertainment is permitted or provided for the guest of said lodging establishment only. 
Cafeteria means a place where food is obtained by self-service and eaten on the premises. 
Cancellation of license means a license which was issued through error or fraud is declared void and terminated. 
Cargo van means an enclosed vehicle designed to haul cargo, having a gross vehicle weight (GVW) of not more than 8,200 pounds. 
Cellar. See basement. 
Center line of highway means a line running parallel with the highway right-of-way which is half the distance between the extreme edges of the official right-of-way width. 
Code compliance officer means the designated authority charged with the interpretation, administration and enforcement of this Code and of matters pertaining to local business tax receipt. 
Clean fill means material consisting of soil, rock, sand, earth, marl, clay, stone and/or concrete rubble. 
Clean yard trash means yard trash free of other forms of solid waste. 
Certified survey means a survey, sketch, plan, map or other exhibit is said to be certified when a written statement regarding its accuracy or conformity to specified standards is signed by the specified professional registered surveyor. 
Club, private means buildings, facilities or premises used or operated by an organization or association for some common purpose, such as, but not limited to, a fraternal, social, educational or recreational purpose beneficial to its members. In addition, the main purpose shall not be for serving alcoholic beverages to its members and others. 
Cluster development means a development design technique that concentrates buildings in specific areas on a site to allow the remaining land to be used for recreation, common open space, and preservation of environmentally sensitive areas. 
Code compliance officer means a designated authority, subordinate to the code compliance director, whose duty it is the enforcement of this Code and matters pertaining to local business tax receipts. 
Combustion contaminants means particulate matter discharged into the atmosphere from the burning of any kind of material containing carbon in a free or combined state. 
Combustible refuse means any combustible waste material containing carbon in a free or combined state. 
Commingled yard trash means yard trash mixed with other forms of solid waste. 
Commission means Miami-Dade County, Florida Board of County Commissioners. 
Commercial district. See Chapter 78 Land Development Regulations. 
Community residential home means a dwelling unit licensed to serve clients of the State of Florida Department of Health and Rehabilitative Services, which provides a living environment for seven to 14 unrelated residents who operate as the functional equivalent of a family. Supervisory and supportive staff may be necessary to meet the physical, emotional, and social needs of the resident clients and shall be excluded from said count. 
Comprehensive plan. As defined in F.S. ch. 163. 
Composting means controlled biological decomposition of organic materials. 
Concurrency means a condition where specified facilities and services have or will have the necessary capacity to meet the adopted level of service standards at the time of impact of the development project. 
Condensed fumes means minute solid particles generated by the condensation of vapors from solid matter volatilization from the molten state, or may be generated by chemical processes, operation or reactions, when these processes create air-borne particles. 
Conditional permit means a permit issued subject to revision or cancellation by the issuing department under the terms of the land development regulation and Florida Building Code. 
Cone of influence means a localized depression draw-down of the groundwater due to water supply well pumpage. 
Construction and demolition debris means solid waste comprised exclusively of materials which are not hazardous materials and which are not water soluble, including steel, concrete, glass, brick, soils not containing any hazardous materials, asphalt roofing and paving material, and lumber from a construction or demolition project. 
Convention hall means an assembly or meeting place for delegates for action on particular matters such as political, fraternal veterans affairs and the like. 
Crosswalk means: 
(1)  That part of a roadway at an intersection included within the connections of the lateral lines of the sidewalks on opposite sides of the highway measured from the curbs or, in the absence of curbs, from the edges of the traversable roadway. 
(2)  Any portion of a roadway at an intersection or elsewhere distinctly indicated for pedestrian crossing by lines or other markings on the surface. 
Court means an open, unoccupied unobstructed space except for trees, shrubs and foundations, statuary, other than a yard, on the same fit as a building. 
Court, inner means a court surrounded by a structure and not extending to a street or alley or to a front, side or rear yard. 
Court, outer means a court extending to a street or alley or to a front or rear yard. 
Daytime means a half hour before sunrise to a half hour after sunset. Nighttime means at any other hour. 
DERM means the Miami-Dade County Department of Environmental Resources Management. 
Depth of lot means the mean horizontal distance between the front and rear lot lines. 
Development means generally consists of changes in land use or intensity; the construction, reconstruction, conversion, structural alteration, relo- cation, or enlargement of any structure; any excavation, landfill, or land disturbance; any use or extension of the use of land and that which is further defined in F.S. 380.04. 
Development land means land upon which structures or facilities have been constructed. 
Developed property means any parcel of land which contains an impervious area. 
Diameter breast height (DBH) means the diameter of a tree's trunk measured at a point four and one-half feet above the ground surface. 
Dog kennel means the keeping of any dog or dogs, regardless of number, for sale, breeding, boarding or treatment purposes, except in a dog hospital, dog beauty parlor or pet shop, as permitted by law, or the keeping of five or more dogs, six months or older, on premises used for residential purposes, or the keeping of more than one dog on vacant property or on property used for business or commercial purposes. 
Domestic sewage means waste water from toilets, showers, sinks, baths, and other facilities designed for human sanitation whether located within residential or nonresidential land uses. 
Drainage well means any excavation that is drilled cored, bared, washed, driven, dug, jetted or otherwise constructed when the intended use of such excavation is for the artificial recharge of groundwater, or the intentional introduction of, water into any underground formation. 
Drip line means an imaginary vertical line extending from the outermost horizontal circumference of a tree's branches to the ground. 
Dumping means throwing, discarding, placing, depositing or burying any solid waste in an area or manner not permitted by the city. 
Dust means minute solid particles released into the air by natural forces or by mechanical processes such as crushing, grinding, milling, drilling, demolishing, shoveling, conveying, covering, bagging, sweeping, etc. 
Dwelling means one or more rooms physically arranged so as to create an independent housekeeping establishment for occupancy by one family with separate toilets and facilities for cooking and sleeping, but not including hotels, motels, mobile homes, boardinghouses and lodginghouses. 
Dwelling, multifamily means a building or portion thereof used for occupancy of three or more families living independently of each other and containing three or more dwellings, including, but not limited to, what is commonly known as an apartment building. 
Dwelling, single-family attached (group, row, duplex, and townhouses) means one or more dwellings having a common or party wall. 
Dwelling, single-family detached means a dwelling entirely surrounded by open space. 
Electrical power facility means any electrical generating facility of 20 megawatts or more using any process or fuel and includes associated facilities except those electrical generating facilities the regulation and certification of which are expressly preempted by F.S. ch. 403. 
Enforcing agency means the zoning, code compliance and building departments. 
Enforcing (inspecting) officer means any employee of the referenced enforcing agencies charged with the responsibility of making inspections of buildings and premises and issuing violation notices when necessary. 
Environmentally-sensitive tree resources means a specimen tree, natural forest community, or any other tree or trees that substantially contribute(s) to the aesthetics of an area and which are not exempted from permit requirements under section 24-60.4(f), Miami-Dade County Code. 
Environment means the complex of climatic, edaphic and biotic factors that act upon an organism or an ecological community and ultimately determine its form and survival and which will be affected by the proposed word. 
Emission means the act of passing into the atmosphere an air contaminant or gas stream which contains or may contain an air contaminant; or the material so passed to the atmosphere. 
Essential services means public utility facilities related to the water, sanitary sewer, storm drainage, solid waste, telephone, cable television, gas and systems serving the city but not including buildings housing employees, or public safety facilities such as fire or police. 
Excavation means the action or process of creating any lake, rockmining (excluding ancillary property uses necessary for extracting and processing subsurface materials), reservoir, pond or other surface water. 
Explosive means any chemical compound or mechanical mixture that is commonly used or intended for the purpose of producing an explosion. 
Facility means something designed or created to provide a service or fulfill a need. 
Flammable liquid means any liquid which has a flash point of 70 degrees Fahrenheit, or less, as determined by a Tagliabue or equivalent closed-cup test device. 
Floating structure means a barge like entity, with or without accommodations, which is not used as a means of transportation on water but which serves purposes or provides services typically associated with a structure upon or improvements to real property. Incidental movement or the capability of movement upon water shall not preclude an entity from classification as a floating structure. Registration of the entity as a vessel in accordance with F.S. ch. 327, shall not preclude an entity from classification as a floating structure. 
Floor area ratio means is a measurement of development intensity. 
Florida No. 1 grade or equivalent means the classification of the quality of a nursery plant as published in Grades and Standards for Nursery Plants, Part 11, Florida Department of Agriculture and Consumer Services, Division of Plant Industry. 
Firebreak means an area of bare ground no more than ten feet in width in a forest which has been created to prevent the spreading of wild fires. 
Flue means any duct or passage for air, gases, or airborne materials, such as a stack or chimney. 
Fresh waters means all waters of the state which are contained in lakes and ponds, or are in flowing streams above the zone in which tidal actions influence the salinity of the water and where the concentration of chloride ions is normally less than 500 milligrams per liter. 
Freshwater wetlands means those lands where the dominant plant community is composed of primary and secondary wetland plant species constitutes the dominant plant community or those lands which are subject to soil saturation conditions (i.e., groundwater levels no lower than one foot below surface elevations) for a minimum of 30 consecutive days per year based on an average of data for a minimum ten-year period. 
Garage, private means a structure for the private use of the owner or occupant of a principal structure situated on the same lot for the storage of motor vehicles. 
Garage, public means a structure designed and used for the storage of motor vehicles. 
Garage, repair means (see also service station): a building designed and used for the storage, care, repair, or refinishing of motor vehicles, including both minor and major mechanical overhauling, paint, and body work. 
Garbage means any accumulation of animal, fruit or vegetable matter which is subject to decay. 
Home occupation means an occupation, activity, or use which is located in a home office that is clearly a customary, incidental, and secondary use of a residential dwelling unit and which does not alter the exterior of the property or affect the residential character of the neighborhood. 
Hotel or motel (lodging establishment) means a building or structure under a common ownership interest and single management where sleeping accommodations are supplied for pay to transient guests. Food or drink may be served to the transient or permanent guests and other persons, The sleeping accommodations and dining rooms, restaurants, or lounges where food or drink are served to the transient or permanent guests and other persons. The sleeping accommodations and dining rooms, restaurants, or lounges, if existing being within the same building or buildings in connection therewith. 
House of worship means a tax-exempt institution that people regularly attend to participate in or hold religious services and meetings. 
Junk means waste material, such as furniture, lumber, metal, glass or other materials, or inoperative vehicles and other machinery. 
Junkyard means a parcel of land where junk is collected, stored, salvaged or sold. 
Landscaping, required means those natural plantings required by the provisions of chapter 78, including beautification strips, hedges, trees, planted ground cover, sodded and grassed areas, and planted floral installations. 
Lot means a designated parcel, tract, or area of land established by plat, subdivision, or as otherwise permitted by law, to be separately owned, used, developed or built upon. 
(1)  Corner lot: A lot abutting the intersection of two or more streets. 
(2)  Interior lot: A lot other than a corner lot having frontage on only one street. 
(3)  Through lot: An interior lot having frontage on two streets other than a corner lot. 
Lot coverage, building means is determined by dividing that area of a lot which is occupied or covered by the total horizontal projected surface of all buildings, including covered porches and accessory buildings, by the gross area of that lot. 
Lot depth means the mean horizontal distance between the front and rear lot lines. 
Lot lines means the lines bounding a lot. Also, as defined in chapter 78. 
Lot of record means a parcel of land as originally subdivided or subsequently re-subdivided and properly recorded as a lot within a subdivision or plat. 
Lot width means the horizontal distance between side lot lines, measured at the required front setback line. 
Mobile home park means a parcel of land that has been planned and improved for the placement of mobile homes for dwelling purposes. 
Nonconforming use means a lawful use of land that does not comply with the use regulations for its land use district but which did so at the time the use was established. 
Nursery, day means a building or lot where supervised care is provided to children of preschool age, school age, or both for remuneration. No overnight facilities or services are provided. 
Nursing, home. Defined as adult living facility in chapter 78. 
Parking lot means an open area or plot of land used exclusively for the storage or parking of motor vehicles together with associated access drives and aisles. 
Planning and zoning board means the city planning and zoning board, as described in chapter 78, article II. 
Principal use or building means a use or building in which is conducted the predominant or primary function or activity of the lot on which it is located. 
Private school means a building, or lot where education and instruction is provided for at least 20 hours per week to five or more persons, either children or adults, for remuneration. A private school may also provide room and board for the students, instruct day students only, or both. 
Recycling container means a receptacle used for recyclable material. 
Recyclable material means any material, which is capable of being recycled and which, if not recycled, would be processed and disposed of as solid waste. The term recyclable material shall include green glass, brown glass and clear glass; aluminum and steel cans and scrap metal; plastic containers, mixed paper, newspaper, corrugated cardboard, office paper, and phonebooks. Any recyclable material mixed with solid waste shall be considered solid waste. 
Recycling program means an operation which provides for the separate gathering, storage, collection and marketing of recyclable material. 
Recycling services means business activities related to buying, selling, trading, marketing, transferring, separating collection or processing of recyclable material. Such service shall include the proper handling and disposal of any portion of collected recyclable material deemed unusable or unmarketable. 
Repairs means restoration of portions of a building to its condition before decay, wear or damage, but not including alteration of the shape or size. 
Residence. See dwelling. 
Restaurant means a food and/or beverage establishment. 
Resubdivision means any change in the shape or size of any lot, tract or parcel of land that was previously platted. 
Right-of-way means a strip of land occupied or intended to be occupied by a street, crosswalk, electric transmission line, oil or gas pipeline, water main, sanitary or storm sewer main, shade trees, or other utilities. 
Right-of-way line means the outside boundaries of such right-of-way. 
Rooming house means a residential building where accommodations are provided for pay to less than five transient or permanent guests, in three to five rooms, but which does not maintain a public dining room or cafe in the same building, nor in any building in connection therewith. 
Sanitary nuisance means the keeping of anything, by an individual, municipality, organization or cooperation, by which the health or life of an individual or individuals, may be threatened or impaired or by which or through which, directly or indirectly, disease may be caused. 
Service bar means a liquor, beer or wine or other alcoholic, vinous or malt beverage bar or counter used in connection with the operation of a bona fide restaurant, where drinks are prepared solely for the purpose of service to and consumption by the guests of the restaurant. No service of drinks or food is permitted to guests of patrons at the service bar. 
Service station means any premises where gasoline and other petroleum products are sold and/or limited light maintenance activities such as engine tuneups, lubrication, minor repairs, and carburetor cleaning are conducted. 
Setback means the minimum horizontal distance between the lot or property line and the nearest front, side, or rear line of the building, as the case may be, including terraces or any covered projection thereof. Steps and ramps are excluded from this calculation. 
Sign. See chapter 82 pertaining to sign regulations. 
Site means a parcel of land which is to be developed as a single unit, subdivision, or project. 
Special execption means a use not permitted by right but may provide for an individual or community serving need and which, subject to conditions, would not impact the integrity of the zoning district. 
Sponsoring agency means an agency or unit of government, a profit or nonprofit agency, or any person or organization which intends to establish or operate a child day care home or adult living facility. 
Statement of code compliance means a statement issued by the chief code compliance officer setting forth that the permitted construction has been completed in compliance with the approved plans and resolutions and conforms with all the provisions of the land development regulations. 
Story means that portion of a building included between the surface of any floor and the surface of the floor next above it, or if there is no floor above it, the space between such floor and the ceiling above it. A basement shall be counted as a story if its ceiling is over five feet above the average level of the finished ground surface adjoining the exterior walls of such building, or if it is occupied for business or dwelling purposes. 
Street means a public or private right-of-way used, or intended to be used, for passage or travel by motor vehicles. Streets are further classified by the functions they perform. 
Structural alterations means any change in the shape or size of any portion of a building or of the supporting menders of a building or structure such as walls, columns, beams, arches, girders, floor joists or roof joists. 
Structure means anything constructed or erected the use of which requires rigid location on the ground, or attachment to something having a permanent location on the ground, including buildings, walls, fence, signs, light standards, tower, tanks, etc. 
Subdivision means a division of a lot, tract or parcel of land. 
Temporary housing means a structure used for human shelter which is not permanently attached to the ground, to another structure, or to any utility system. Manufactured homes or mobile homes shall not be designated as temporary housing. For the purpose of this Code, living quarters for migratory agricultural workers shall be defined as temporary housing. 
Tent means any structure or enclosure, made of any light material, either attached or unattached to a building or structure. 
Tentative plat. See chapter 78 for definition. 
Testing laboratory means a plant which tests materials, products, methods and systems in accordance with established standards or procedures. 
Trailer means a non-self-propelled vehicle or conveyance permanently equipped to travel upon the public highway, that is used either temporarily or permanently as a residence or living quarters. Such mobile home may be affixed to the ground in accordance with the provisions for tie-downs in Chapter 19A of the Code of Miami-Dade County, Florida, but shall not otherwise be permanently secured to a foundation. 
Trash means cuttings from vegetation, refuse, paper, bottles, rags and other junk. 
(Ord. No. 2006-03, § 1 (Exh. 1), 2-7-06; Ord. No. 2008-06, § 3, 9-16-09)  
Sec. 2-250.4. - Technical standards adopted. 
The following technical standards as may be amended from time to time, are hereby adopted and shall be enforced by the code compliance department of the city: 
(1)  The Florida Building Code. 
(2)  The Public Works Manual of Miami-Dade County and the standards of the Miami-Dade county water and sewer authority Department (WASAD). 
(3)  The requirements for accessibility by physically, disabled persons as specified in F.S. ch. 553, Part V and Florida Building Code. 
(4)  Subdivision, Chapter 28 as specified in the Code of Miami-Dade County, Florida. 
(5)  Minimum Housing Standard, Chapter 17 as specified in the Code of Miami-Dade County, Florida. 
(6)  Fire Prevention, Chapter 14 as specified in the Code of Miami-Dade County, Florida. 
(7)  Contractors, Chapter 10 as specified in the Code of Miami-Dade County, Florida. 
(8)  Environmental Protection, Chapter 24 as specified in the Code of Miami-Dade County. 
(Ord. No. 2006-03, § 1 (Exh. 1), 2-7-06; Ord. No. 2008-06, § 3, 9-16-08)  
Secs. 2-250.5—2-250.20. - Reserved.

ARTICLE VI. - ELECTIONS[9] 

Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
Charter reference— Elections, art. III, §§ 5—9. 
 
Sec. 2-251. - Holding of elections; notice. 
(a)  Nonpartisan general and runoff elections shall be held as provided in the Charter, article III, section 5. The mayor and councilmembers shall be elected in accordance with the procedure established in article III, section 9, of the Charter. 
(b)  A notice of all city elections shall be given at least 30 days prior to the date of the election by posting a written notice of the election in at least three public places within the city. It shall be the duty of the city clerk to post the notices. 
(Code 1985, § 33.01) 
State Law reference— Notice of special elections or referendum, F.S. § 100.342.  
Sec. 2-252. - Polling place; compilation of votes and certification of results. 
(a)  The city polling place, where the qualified voters of the city may cast their ballots in secret in all elections, shall be as established by the county. 
(b)  The city clerk shall cause the polling place to be opened, and the devices used in balloting, as are approved and used by the county, shall be provided for the use of the qualified electors of the city. 
(c)  After the closing of the elections, the city clerk, under the supervision of the clerks and inspectors of election and in the presence of one police officer and those watchers, if any, designated by the several candidates, shall cause a compilation of the votes registered on the devices to be made therefor. The compilation shall be presented to the board of elections with a tally of all properly submitted absentee ballots. After certification by the board of elections, the tally and compilation shall be the official result of the election after presentation to the council. 
(Code 1985, § 33.02)  
Sec. 2-253. - Verification of signatures on petition. 
The petition required by Charter, article III, section 6B, shall be submitted by the city clerk to the county supervisor of elections for verification of signatures. 
(Code 1985, § 33.06(B))  
Sec. 2-254. - Adoption of state law. 
The following provisions in state law are adopted by reference and will be applicable to city elections.

section 	  Subject 
101.105—101.694 	Absentee voters 
102.166 	Contest of elections 
 
(Code 1985, § 33.08)  
Secs. 2-255—2-280. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VII. - PERSONNEL  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 2-281. - Policies, rules and regulations adopted. 
The city personnel policies, rules and regulations, including the adoption by the city of F.S. § 112.0455, concerning the Drug-free Working Place Act, to provide for a drug-free working place, is hereby adopted by reference and is on file in the city clerk's office. 
(Code 1985, § 34.13; Ord. No. 89-16, § 1, 9-26-89)  
Sec. 2-282. - Conflicts of interest. 
(a)  Part-time or full-time employees or consultants of the city including, but not limited to, the city architect, city attorney, city engineer, city planner, building official or code compliance officer, or any other city employee or consultant, shall be prohibited from representing on a consulting basis or otherwise, regarding obtaining city approval, persons or entities requesting from the city, either administratively or through the planning and zoning board or the city council, any form of city approval including but not limited to, approval for obtaining of licenses, permits, variances, zoning changes, or any other form of approval from the city. 
(b)  The provisions of this section may be waived by a four-fifths vote of the city council on proper disclosure as made pursuant to subsection (c) of this section; provided, however, that concerning matters which are under the jurisdiction of the water and sewer department, the provisions of this section may be waived by a four-fifths vote of the water and sewer board. 
(c)  Prior to any vote being made to waive the provisions of this section, the party requesting the waiver shall make a full disclosure of the type of services to be performed, the amount of compensation to be paid, and such other material details of the transaction as are requested either by the water and sewer board concerning water and sewer matters, or by the city council concerning other matters. 
(Code 1985, §§ 34.35—34.37)  
Sec. 2-283. - Disclosure of interest with any entity contracting with the city. 
(a)  Definitions: 
(1)  Immediate relative. The term "immediate relative" includes a brother, sister, father, mother, brother-in-law or sister-in-law. 
(2)  Entity. The term "entity" includes any business, whether individually owned, corporately owned, or otherwise, excluding corporations whose stock is traded on any public exchange and in which the person subject to this section does not own more than five percent interest therein. 
(3)  Full or part-time employee. The term "full or part-time employee" includes all employees of the city, whether on a full time or part time basis, but does not include elected officials. 
(4)  Consultant. The term "consultant" includes any individual who provides advice to the city on a fee basis. 
(b)  Disclosure. Every full or part time employee, or consultant of the city shall disclose any interest he or she may have or his or her immediate relative may have in any entity contracting with the city at least ten days prior to consideration by the council for final approval of such contract. 
(c)  Violation. In the event of a violation of this section, such individual so violating this section shall, absent good cause, be subject to dismissal or to have his or her consulting agreement terminated. 
(Ord. No. 99-18, §§ 1—3, 8-17-99)  
Secs. 2-284—2-300. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - PERSONNEL REVIEW BOARD[10] 

Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
Charter reference— Creation of personnel review board, art. VII, § 1. 
 
Sec. 2-301. - Composition; appointments; terms of office; filling of vacancies. 
(a)  The personnel review board shall consist of five members to be appointed as follows. 
(1)  Two of the members shall be appointed by the mayor and the city council on the basis of rotating appointment privileges as set forth in Ordinance No. 82-02, passed February 16, 1982, and Ordinance No. 85-02, passed March 19, 1985. The mayor shall have the first appointment and the council person shall have the second appointment and shall serve for a period of two years. 
(2)  Two of the members shall be elected by permanent status employees of the city for a period of two years. 
(3)  The fifth member shall be elected by a majority of the four members of the board who have been appointed or elected as set forth above, such member to be a resident of the city, or proprietor of an established business located within the city and shall serve for a period of two years. 
(b)  Vacancies occurring on the board shall be filled for the unexpired term of any such vacancy in the same manner as the member of the board causing such vacancy was appointed or elected as the case may be. A member of the board may serve for more than one term and shall continue to serve until his successor has been appointed or elected. 
(Code 1985, § 34.10(B); Ord. No. 99-04, § 2, 1-19-99)  
Sec. 2-302. - Officers; duties of secretary; support services. 
(a)  The board shall initiate its organization by electing one of its members to serve as the chairperson for the period to be designated by the board and the board may appoint other subordinates as it deems necessary. 
(b)  The city clerk or designee shall act as the secretary of the personnel review board, attending all meetings of said board, maintaining a written record of the minutes of meetings of said board and performing such other duties in connection with the administration of this division as may be required by the board. He/she shall not be considered a member of the board or entitled to vote. 
(c)  All consultation or support services furnished to the board must be requested and approved by the city council or their designated authority. 
(Code 1985, § 34.10(C); Ord. No. 99-04, § 2, 1-19-99)  
Sec. 2-303. - Compensation of members. 
Members of the personnel review board shall serve without compensation. The city clerk or designee shall receive compensatory time at the rate of time and one-half for attendance at board meetings or hearings when held subsequent to regular office hours. 
(Code 1985, § 34.10(D); Ord. No. 99-04, § 2, 1-19-99)  
Sec. 2-304. - Rules and regulations. 
The rules and regulations of the personnel review board, pursuant to article VII, section 1, of the Charter, shall be established by ordinance, which ordinance is not subject to amendment other than by four-fifths vote of the city council. 
(Code 1985, § 34.10(A))  
Sec. 2-305. - City officers, employees entitled to appeal to the board. 
All officers or employees of the city shall be entitled to appeal to the board with the exception of the following: 
(1)  Mayor, members of the city council, and any members of appointed or elected boards or commissions for the city. 
(2)  City attorney and associates. 
(3)  Persons of technical, scientific, or professional training who maintain an independent practice of their respective professions who are employed by the city on a consulting or retainer basis. 
(4)  Persons of a temporary, seasonal or emergency employment status working less than a 30-hour work week, or for a duration less than six months. 
(5)  Any employee who has not completed the probationary period of employment which entitles him/her to permanent employee status. 
(Code 1985, § 34.11; Ord. No. 99-04, § 2, 1-19-99)  
Sec. 2-306. - Personnel operations and procedures. 
All employees of the city are required to fulfill their respective duties and to abide by rules or procedure as set forth in departmental operational and procedural manuals. Modifications or amendments as to state or federal law which are applicable to operational or procedural matters within the city shall be automatically adopted. Periodic revisions to the aforesaid manuals shall be made and each employee shall be made aware, in writing, of changes relative thereto, however the failure to amend or modify such rules shall not preclude the city from enforcing any law applicable to the situation. The personnel review board may consider matters contained in these rules and regulations and procedural and operational manuals in its decision making process. 
(Code 1985, § 34.12(A); Ord. No. 99-04, § 2, 1-19-99)  
Sec. 2-307. - Authority. 
The personnel review board shall be a recommendation body with respect to all employee petitions or claims before it, which issues shall only concern demotion, suspension or dismissal. The mayor shall be the final decision maker. 
(Code 1985, § 34.12(B); Ord. No. 99-04, § 2, 1-19-99)  
Sec. 2-308. - Lobbying. 
(a)  Definitions. For the purposes of this section, the following terms, phrases, words, and their derivations shall have the meaning given herein. When not inconsistent with the context, words used in the present tense shall include future tense, words in the plural number shall include the singular number and words in the singular number shall include the plural number. The word "shall" is always mandatory and not merely directory. 
Agency means the City of Hialeah Gardens, including all elected and appointed officials, employees and persons acting on behalf of the agency. 
Lobbyist means any person who, for compensation or remuneration, direct or indirect, seeks to influence the governmental decision making of the agency or seeks to encourage the passage, defeat or modification of any ordinance, resolution, contract, bid award, proposal, recommendation, action or decision of the agency. 
Lobbyist does not mean: 
(1)  A city employee when acting in his official capacity. 
(2)  Any person, or its full-time employee, officer or owner who appears before the city council, city board or committee, or staff in an individual capacity for the purpose of self representation or for the representation of others without compensation or reimbursement to express support of or in opposition to any ordinance, resolution, action, recommendation or decision of any city board; or any resolution, action, recommendation or decision or recommendation of the mayor. 
Person includes individual, firms, associations, joint ventures, general and limited partnerships, estates, trusts, business trusts, syndicates, fiduciaries, corporations, and all other groups or combinations. 
(b)  Registration of lobbyist. Commencing 15 days after the effective date of this section and continuing thereafter, all lobbyists shall, before engaging in any lobbying activities, register with the city clerk. 
(c)  Registration forms. Every person required to register as a lobbyist shall do so on forms prepared by the city clerk and shall state under oath his or her name, business address, the name and business address of each person which has employed said registrant to lobby and the specific issue on which he or she has been employed to lobby. Separate registrations shall be required for each specific issue and for each employer. 
(d)  Filing and disclosure of annual expenditures. Commencing on April 1, 2003 and on January 1 of each year thereafter, all lobbyists registered pursuant to this section shall submit to the city clerk a signed statement under oath listing all lobbying expenditures for the preceding calendar year. A statement shall be filed even if there have been no expenditures during the reporting period. Annual statements shall be required until such time as the lobbyist files a notice of withdrawal of lobbying activities with the city clerk. 
(e)  Penalties for violation; cumulative in nature. 
(1)  Whenever a violation of this section exists, the city council may publicly reprimand, censure, and/or prohibit such lobbyist before the agency for a period of up to but not to exceed two years. 
(2)  The penalties provided herein are cumulative in nature. Nothing contained in this section shall prevent the agency from pursuing any other remedies available to the agency under the agency's code and/or Florida law for the enforcement of its ordinances. 
(f)  Public records. All registration forms and annual disclosure statements required by this section shall be public records subject to inspection and examination as provided for in section 119.07 of the Florida Statutes. 
(g)  Lobbyist registration fee. An annual lobbyist registration fee in the amount of $25.00 per calendar year for each lobbyist shall be paid to the city clerk at the time the lobbyist files a registration form. This fee is necessary to cover the administrative expenditures required by this section. 
(Ord. No. 2003-12, 4-1-03)  
Chapter 6 - ADVERTISING[1] 
Footnotes:

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL

ARTICLE II. - HANDBILLS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Businesses, ch. 18. 
 
Sec. 6-31. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Billposter means and includes any person engaging in the business for hire of posting, fastening, nailing, or otherwise affixing any written, painted, or printed matter of any kind, or other form or reproduction thereof (referred to in this article as a sign), containing a message or information of any kind whatsoever, to any outdoor billboard, or to or on any bridge, fence, pole, post, sidewalk, tree, or to or on the exterior of any other structure. The terms of this definition shall not apply to nor include any sign mounted on, fastened to, or suspended from the outside of any building or other structure, in accordance with and authorized by any provisions of an ordinance or statute, for any public convenience or use, nor to the construction or use of so-called outdoor display signs, whether the display signs are illuminated or not. 
Commercial handbill means and includes any printed or written matter, any sample or device, dodger, circular, leaflet, pamphlet, paper, booklet, or any other printed or otherwise reproduced original or copies of any matter or literature which does the following: 
(1)  Advertises for sale any merchandise, product, commodity, or thing. 
(2)  Directs attention to any business, mercantile, commercial establishment, or other activity, for the purpose of either directly or indirectly promoting the interests thereof by sales. 
(3)  Directs attention to or advertises any meeting, theatrical performance, exhibition, or event of any kind, for which an admission fee is charged for the purpose of private gain or profit. The terms of this provision shall not apply where an admission fee is charged or collection is taken up for the purpose of defraying the expenses incident to the meeting, theatrical performance, exhibition, or event of any kind when any of these is held, given, or takes place in connection with the dissemination of information which is not restricted under the ordinary rules of decency, good morals, public peace, safety, and good order. Nothing contained in this provision shall be deemed to authorize the holding, giving, or taking place of any meeting, theatrical performance, exhibition, or event of any kind without a license, where a license is or may be required by any law of this state, or under any ordinance of this city. 
(4)  While containing reading matter other than advertising matter, it is predominantly and essentially an advertisement, and is distributed or circulated for advertising purposes, or for the private benefit and gain of any person so engaged as an advertiser or distributor. 
(5)  Any matter or literature which is not covered by the definition of sign under the definition of billposter in this section. 
Handbill distributor means and includes any person engaging or engaged in the business for hire or gain of distributing commercial or noncommercial handbills, other than newspapers distributed to subscribers thereof, and any person receiving compensation directly or indirectly for the distribution of handbills. 
Litter means and includes any garbage, rubbish, trash, refuse, cans, bottles, containers, paper (including the promiscuous and uncontrolled distribution of advertising matter and handbills), lighted or unlighted cigarettes or cigars, or flaming or glowing material. 
Newspaper means and includes any newspaper of general circulation as defined by general law, any newspaper duly entered with the post office department of the United States in accordance with federal statute or regulation, and any newspaper filed and recorded with any recording officer as provided by general law. In addition, it shall include any periodical or current magazine regularly published with not less than four issues per year, and sold to the public. 
Noncommercial handbill means and includes any printed or written matter, any sample or device, dodger, circular, leaflet, pamphlet, newspaper, magazine, paper booklet, or any other printed or otherwise reproduced original or copies of any matter or literature not included in the definitions of sign, commercial handbill, or newspaper. 
Private premises means and includes any dwelling, house, building, or other structure designed or used either wholly or in part for private residential purposes, whether inhabited or temporarily or continuously uninhabited or vacant, and shall include any yard, grounds, walk, driveway, porch, steps, vestibule, or mailbox belonging or appurtenant to the dwelling, house, building, or other structure. 
Public place means and includes any and all streets, boulevards, avenues, lanes, alleys, or other public ways, and any and all public parks, squares, spaces, plazas, grounds, and buildings. 
(Code 1985, § 111.02) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 6-32. - Purpose. 
The purposes of this article are specifically declared to be as follows: 
(1)  To protect the people against the unlawful activities or operations of dissolute persons of criminal habits or tendencies, representing themselves as solicitors, canvassers, or handbill distributors, by requiring the registration of all solicitors, canvassers, or handbill distributors, together with the names of their employers, and by regulating the business of handbill and advertising distribution through the imposition of reasonable license fees. 
(2)  To protect local residents against trespassing by solicitors, canvassers, or handbill distributors upon the private property of residents if they have given reasonable notice that they do not wish to be solicited by such persons or do not desire to receive handbills or advertising matter. 
(3)  To protect the people against the health and safety menace and the expense incident to the littering of the streets and public places by the promiscuous and uncontrolled distribution of advertising matter and commercial handbills. 
(4)  To preserve to the people their constitutional right to receive and disseminate information not restricted under the ordinary rules of decency, good morals, and public order, by distinguishing between the nuisance created by the promiscuous distribution of advertising and commercial circulars and the right to deliver noncommercial handbills to all who are willing to receive them. 
(Code 1985, § 111.01)  
Sec. 6-33. - Exemptions. 
The provisions of this article shall not be deemed to apply to the distribution of mail by the United States, nor to newspapers as defined in section 6-31. 
(Code 1985, § 111.05)  
Sec. 6-34. - License. 
(a)  Required. It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of a billposter for hire or as a handbill distributor for hire, or for any person to distribute commercial or noncommercial handbills, without first complying with the terms of this article and all other relevant laws and regulations. Nothing contained in this article shall apply to any person advertising his business or activity on his own premises, if the business or activity is regularly established at a definite location in the city, and also if a license has been obtained therefor, if a license is required under the terms of any applicable law or ordinance. 
(b)  Application; contents. Any person desiring to engage, as principal, either in the business of a billposter for hire, or in the business of distributing commercial or noncommercial handbills for hire, shall make application to and receive from the city clerk a license in the manner and for the period prescribed by the terms of this article and by all relevant provisions of this Code. The applicant shall make written application to the city clerk on a form provided for this purpose by the city clerk. The form shall contain, among other things that may be required, the name, the business address, and a brief description of the nature of the business to be conducted by the applicant, the probable number of agents and employees to be engaged, together with a request for a license for the period for which the applicant seeks to engage in the business. 
(c)  Revocation; nontransferability.
