Without excluding other just grounds for revocation, the city council may revoke any license issued under this article which has been obtained under an application containing false or fraudulent statements knowingly made by the applicant with intent to obtain a license by means of false or fraudulent representations, or for violation of this article, or for any other grounds specified by law. The application shall be accompanied by the required fee for such license. No license issued under this article shall be transferable. If any license issued under this article shall be surrendered by the licensee therein named, or shall be revoked for cause, neither the licensee named in the license, nor any other person, shall be entitled to any refund of any part of the fee. 
(d)  Fees; exemptions. The fee for a license under this article, and for any such purposes, is on file in the city clerk's office. Persons acting for licensees, as agents or employees, in the posting or distributing of any signs or handbills, shall not be required to obtain a license or pay a fee, but each person shall comply with, and be subject to, each and all of the other provisions of this article. The provisions of this article may be waived by the city council. 
(Code 1985, § 111.03) 
Cross reference— Businesses, ch. 18.  
Sec. 6-35. - Posting notices on public ways or places. 
No person shall post, stick, stamp, paint, or otherwise fix, or cause the same to be done by any person, any notice, placard, bill, card, poster, advertisement, or other paper or device calculated to attract the attention of the public, to or on any sidewalk, crosswalk, curb or curbstone, flagstone, or any other portion or part of any public way or public place, or any lamppost, electric light, telegraph, telephone line, pole, railway structure, hydrant, shade tree, or on piers, columns, trusses, girders, railings, gates, or other parts of any public bridge or viaduct, or on any other public structure or building, or on any pole, box, or fixture of the fire alarm or police telegraph system, except as authorized or required by the laws of the United States, the state, and the ordinances of the city. 
(Code 1985, § 111.10)  
Sec. 6-36. - Distributing handbills in public places. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit, place, throw, scatter, or cast any commercial handbill in or on any public place within this city. It shall be unlawful for any person to hand out, distribute, or sell any commercial handbill in any public place except to a person extending their hand in acceptance of such handbill. It shall not be unlawful for any person to hand out or distribute, without charge to the receiver thereof, any noncommercial handbill in any public place to any person willing to accept the noncommercial handbill. 
(Code 1985, § 111.11) 
Cross reference— Parks and recreation, ch. 38.  
Sec. 6-37. - Placing in vehicles. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to distribute, deposit, place, throw, scatter, or cast any commercial or noncommercial handbill in or on any automobile or other vehicle. The provisions of this section shall not be deemed to prohibit the handling, transmitting, or distributing of any handbill to the owner or other occupant of any automobile or other vehicle, who is willing to accept it. 
(Code 1985, § 111.12)  
Sec. 6-38. - Distribution on vacant premises prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to distribute, deposit, place, throw, scatter, or cast any commercial or noncommercial handbill in or on any private premises which are temporarily or continuously uninhabited or vacant. 
(Code 1985, § 111.13)  
Sec. 6-39. - Distribution prohibited where proper notice given. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to distribute, deposit, place, throw, scatter, or cast any commercial or noncommercial handbill on any premises if requested by anyone thereon not to do so, or if there is placed on the premises in a conspicuous position near the entrance thereof a sign bearing the words: "No trespassing," "No peddlers or agents," "No advertisement," or any similar notice, indicating in any manner that the occupants of the premises do not desire to be molested or to have their right of privacy disturbed, or to have any handbills left on the premises. 
(Code 1985, § 111.14)  
Sec. 6-40. - Distribution on private premises. 
No person licensed under the provisions of this article, or any other person, shall distribute, deposit, place, throw, scatter, or cast any commercial or noncommercial handbill in or on any private premises which are inhabited, except by handing or transmitting the handbill directly to the owner, occupant, or any other person then present in or on the private premises. However, in case of inhabited private premises which are not posted as provided in section 6-39, the aforesaid licensee or other person, unless requested by anyone on the premises not to do so, may place or deposit any handbill in or on the inhabited private premises, if the handbill is so placed or deposited as to secure or prevent the handbill from being blown or drifted about the premises or elsewhere. However, mailboxes may not be so used when prohibited by federal postal laws or regulations. 
(Code 1985, § 111.15)  
Sec. 6-41. - Littering. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to throw, discard, place, or deposit litter in any manner or amount in the following places: 
(1)  In or on any public highway, road, street, alley, or thoroughfare, including any portion of the right-of-way thereof, or any other public lands, except in containers or areas lawfully provided therefor. 
(2)  In or on any fresh water lake, river, or stream. 
(3)  In or on any private property, unless prior consent of the owner has been given and unless the litter will not cause a public nuisance or be in violation of any other state or local law, ordinance, rule, or regulation. 
(Code 1985, § 111.16) 
Cross reference— Environment, ch. 30.  
Chapter 10 - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Businesses, ch. 18; land use regulations, ch. 78; signs, ch. 82. 
State Law reference— Alcoholic beverage code, F.S. ch. 561 et seq. 
 
Sec. 10-1. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Alcoholic beverages, including beer, wine and mixed beverages, shall have the meanings in F.S. §§ 561.01, 563.01, 564.01 and 565.01, unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning. 
Bar means any place of business where wine, beer, or alcoholic beverages are sold or offered for sale for consumption on the premises, and where the sale of food is incidental to the sale of these beverages, or where no food is sold. Every place of business that sells or permits alcoholic beverages to be consumed on premises that is not specifically defined in this section shall be considered a bar under this chapter for the purposes of regulation. 
Cigar store and smoking lounge means a retail establishment that sells tobacco products, provides an area for smoking tobacco, and serves beer and wine for consumption on the premises. To do business within the city, a cigar store and smoking lounge must be approved as a "special exception use" by the city council under section 78-36 of the Hialeah Gardens Code of Ordinances. A cigar store and smoking lounge may be approved as a "special exception" use in the city's General business district (B-2), Commercial business district (B-3), or Light industrial business district (IN-1). The city council may condition its "special exception" approval upon whatever directives or limitations it believes are reasonably necessary to protect the interest of its citizens and property owners. Additional specific conditions precedent to "special exception" approval by the city council are: 
(1)  The "cigar store and smoking lounge" shall be not less than 1,000 square feet in size and may not be a "restaurant," "bar," "nightclub," or "show club" as defined in section 10-1 of chapter 10 of the Hialeah Gardens Code of Ordinances. 
(2)  Food service in the establishment is limited to inside service of light snacks and sandwiches incidental to the operation of the cigar store and smoking lounge. Outside service of food is not permitted. 
(3)  In the event the sale of tobacco products is discontinued or terminated, then the smoking lounge use is terminated and the sale of alcoholic beverages (beer and wine) is no longer permitted. 
(4)  The cigar store and smoking lounge shall not be freestanding and must be located in an existing shopping center, a commercial building, or a warehouse. 
(5)  Service of alcoholic beverages (beer and wine) shall be subject to all conditions and restrictions set forth in chapter 10 (alcoholic beverages) of the Hialeah Gardens Code of Ordinances as well as applicable state licensing rules and regulations governing the sale of alcoholic beverages. 
Consumption off premises means the selling of beers, wines, or alcoholic beverages in the original unbroken containers, to be taken by the purchasers off the premises where sold before being consumed. 
Consumption on premises means consumption of all beers, wines, or alcoholic beverages of every kind, or the right to sell by the drink, bottle, or can these beverages for consumption on the licensed premises only. 
Full-course meals means a meal consisting of salad, entree, dessert, beverage, and bread and butter, all prepared on the premises. Fast foods, sandwiches, frozen foods, or any other services not requiring the utilization of a full-time chef are not considered full-course meals. 
Hotel or motel bar means a bar operated in connection with a hotel, motel, or apartment hotel of more than 25 hotel or motel rooms or apartments, and operated by the same management, the bar being equipped with adequate and sanitary equipment. The sale of beer, wine and alcoholic beverages shall be strictly incidental to the principal use as a hotel or motel. 
Liquor means and includes any and all distilled or rectified spirits, brandy, whiskey, rum, gin, cordials, or similar distilled alcoholic beverages, including all dilutions and mixtures of one or more of the foregoing. 
Nightclub means any place of business operating after 9:00 p.m., where full-course meals, alcoholic beverages, and refreshments are continuously available and served and sold to the public until at least one hour before the authorized closing time in connection with dancing, vaudeville, theatrical, or similar entertainment; and where, in addition to the space occupied by chairs and tables for service of meals, there is provided a floor space of at least 400 square feet prepared for dancing, free from chairs, tables, or other obstructions at all times. Music shall be provided continuously from 9:00 p.m. except for reasonable break periods, the sum of which shall not exceed one-half of the time between 9:00 p.m. and the authorized closing time, by a live band, orchestra, or musical instruments being played by at least two musicians at the same time. However, should the band, orchestra, or musical entertainment not perform on any evening between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and the authorized closing time, the nightclub shall be regulated as a bar, as defined in this section. 
Package store license means a vendor's license to sell alcoholic beverages in sealed containers only and for consumption off the premises. The sealed package must not be broken and the contents must not be consumed in or on the premises under a package store license. 
Person or vendor includes all persons selling, offering, or keeping with the intention of selling or dealing the beverages defined in this chapter. 
Restaurant bar means a bar operated in connection with a restaurant and by the same management, where the principal business is the serving of full-course meals and where full-course meals are actually and regularly served, having accommodations for 150 or more patrons at tables and occupying more than 2,500 square feet of space, the space being provided and equipped with adequate and sanitary kitchen and dining room equipment. The restaurant bar must be directly connected with the dining room. The sale of beer, wine and alcoholic beverages shall be strictly incidental to the serving of food. The sale of beer, wine and alcoholic beverages shall be prohibited except during the time the restaurant is actually engaged in, and open to the public for, the serving of meals. 
Show club means any place of business operating after 9:00 p.m. where alcoholic beverages and refreshments or full-course meals are continuously served until at least one hour before the authorized closing time in connection with vaudeville, theatrical, or similar entertainment. Musical or theatrical performances shall be provided continuously after 9:00 p.m. except for reasonable break periods, the sum of which shall not exceed one-half of the time between 9:00 p.m. and the authorized closing time, by live performers or by a live band, orchestra, or musical instruments being played by at least two musicians at the same time. 
(Code 1985, § 110.01; Ord. No. 2015-18, § 4, 12-1-15) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 10-2. - Penalty for violation of chapter. 
Any person who shall violate any term, condition, or provision of this chapter, upon conviction before a court of competent jurisdiction, shall be punished as provided in section 1-16. 
(Code 1985, § 110.99)  
Sec. 10-3. - Consumption on premises; hours of sale. 
No person, vendor or distributor in any place of business, except those determined by the city council to comply with the requirements for an extended hours license pursuant to section 10-6, shall sell, offer for sale, deliver, or permit to be consumed upon the premises of the person, vendor or distributor in such place of business, any alcoholic beverage, including but not limited to liquor, beer, or wine, regardless of the alcoholic content, on any day of the week between the hours of 1:00 a.m. and 7:00 a.m., or on Sunday between the hours of 1:00 a.m. and 1:00 p.m. The ability to sell, offer for sale, deliver, or permit to be consumed upon the premises any alcoholic beverage beyond the hour of 1:00 a.m. on any day of the week, including Sunday, is hereby declared to be and is a privilege subject to termination by the city council, and no person may reasonably rely on a continuation of that privilege. 
(Code 1985, § 110.02(A))  
Sec. 10-4. - Revocation of privilege to operate. 
(a)  If, at any time, the city clerk, mayor, or city councilmember determines that any person, vendor or distributor in any place of business is operating in a manner harmful to the public health, safety, or welfare, based upon the criteria specified in section 10-6(b), he may place on the city council agenda the matter of revoking such operating privilege. This agenda item shall be publicly advertised in a newspaper of local circulation, and written notice of the charges against the person, vendor, distributor, or place of business shall be sent to him at least 14 days in advance. This notice shall also contain the date, time, and place of the agenda item. 
(b)  After consideration of the matter, and allowing the person to be heard, the city council may revoke or condition the privilege to operate a place of business under this chapter. The criteria to be used by the city clerk and the city council shall be the criteria specified in section 10-6(b). Should the privilege be revoked or conditioned, the person, vendor or distributor in such place of business may seek review of this action, after three months, before the city council. The council may then modify or refuse to modify its action. Only one such review shall be given within a 12-month period. 
(Code 1985, § 110.02(B), (C))  
Sec. 10-5. - Consumption off premises; hours of sale. 
(a)  No person, vendor, distributor, cafeteria or restaurant shall sell, offer for sale, or deliver any liquor, beer or wine within the commercial district (CM), regardless of the alcoholic content, by package, bottle or container, for the purpose of consumption on or off the premises, on any day of the week between the hours of 7:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. of the following day, or on Sunday between the hours of 7:00 p.m. and 1:00 p.m. of the following day, except as provided in subsection (b) of this section. 
(b)  Packaged beer and wine sales are permitted in all licensed premises of the city where alcoholic beverages are sold between the hours of 7:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. as well as between 1:00 a.m. and 7:00 p.m. 
(c)  No person, vendor, distributor, cafeteria or restaurants shall sell, offer for sale, or deliver any liquor, beer or wine within the business district (BU), regardless of the alcoholic content, by package, bottle or container, for the purpose of consumption on or off premises, on any day of the week, including Sundays, between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 10:00 a.m. of the following day. 
(Code 1985, § 110.03; Ord. No. 90-15, § 1, 5-8-90; Ord. No. 94-05, § 1, 5-17-94; Ord. No. 98-36, § 1, 1-5-99)  
Sec. 10-6. - Extended hours license. 
(a)  Any person or vendor in any place of business operating as a restaurant bar, hotel or motel bar, nightclub, or show club in the city, and duly and regularly licensed by the state to sell and dispense alcoholic beverages, wine, or beer therein, may apply for an extended hours license. The fee for the issuance of such license is on file in the city clerk's office. The extended hours license permits and extends the hours in which the licensee may remain open until 5:00 a.m. on any day; provided, however, that all extended hours licenses for restaurant bars, hotel or motel bars, nightclubs, or show clubs are hereby declared to be and are regulatory in nature. Every such license shall expire on October 1 of each and every year. The city clerk shall place all initial applications for such licenses on the agenda for the first regular city council meeting to be held in August, or as soon thereafter as may be heard, and shall notify all qualified applicants of the date on which their applications will be heard. The city council may grant or deny the extended hours license. 
(b)  The specific criteria for city council consideration in granting or denying an extended hours license are as follows: 
(1)  The amount of off-street parking in relation to the demand created by the extra hours of operation, especially with regard to the adverse impact on adjacent residential areas of any illegal or hazardous parking. 
(2)  The amount and degree of law enforcement activities generated by the extra hours of operation, both outside and inside the particular location, with particular emphasis on the vandalism, noise, vehicular use by patrons, and illegal activity of any kind by employees, patrons, or others associated with the establishment, during or immediately after the extended hours of operation. 
(3)  The adverse effects, if any, that the extended hours of operation will have on neighboring properties, especially with respect to the effect of noise, parking, and glare from headlights or exterior lighting on nearby residential properties. 
(c)  Extended hours licenses may only be granted to those establishments which are wholly enclosed, soundproofed, and air conditioned. All windows, doors, or other openings shall be kept closed, except for normal and emergency ingress and egress, in order that noise and music emanating therefrom will not disturb the peace and quiet of the neighborhood. 
(1)  The city council may require, as a condition of the privilege of extending hours of operation, compliance with any reasonable conditions deemed by the council to be necessary to mitigate or eliminate the adverse effects of the extended hours. These conditions may include, without being limited to, provision by the owner or operator of the premises to provide, at his expense, additional off-street parking, security personnel, and screening and buffering from nearby properties. 
(2)  The granting of an extended hours license to a particular licensee is a privilege subject to modification or termination by the city council each year at renewal time, and no person may reasonably rely on a continuation of that privilege. 
(d)  The renewal of any extended hours license shall first be determined by the city clerk. If, in the city clerk's opinion, based upon the criteria set forth in subsections (a) and (b) of this section, the license should be renewed, a new license shall issue upon payment of the required fee. If, however, the city clerk determines that renewal should be denied, the licensee shall have 20 days from the date of the notice of denial to appeal the city clerk's decision to the city council. The city council, in determining the appeal, shall use the criteria specified in subsections (a) through (c) of this section. 
(e)  If, prior to renewal time, the city clerk determines that any licensee has either violated a condition of renewal, or is operating in a manner harmful to the public health, safety, or welfare based upon the criteria specified in subsections (a) and (b) of this section, he may place on the city council agenda the matter of revoking the extended hours license. The agenda item shall be publicly advertised in a newspaper of local circulation and written notice of the charges against the licensee shall be sent to him at least 14 days in advance. This notice shall also contain the date, time, and place of the agenda item. 
(1)  After consideration of the matter, and allowing the licensee to be heard, the city council may revoke, modify, or condition the extended hours license. If the council determines that the actions of the licensee are of such a nature as to pose a serious harm to the health, safety, and welfare of the citizens of the city, the council may also revoke the privilege of selling, delivering, or permitting consumption of alcoholic beverages after a time established by the city council on any day of the week, including Sunday. The criteria to be used by the city clerk and city council in these matters shall be the criteria specified in subsections (a) and (b) of this section. 
(2)  Should the license or privilege be revoked, conditioned, or modified, the licensee may seek review of this action, after three months, before the city council. The council may then modify or refuse to modify its action. Only one of these reviews shall be given within a 12-month period. 
(Code 1985, § 110.04)  
Sec. 10-7. - Presence of nonlicensed persons on licensed premises after closing hour. 
No person, vendor or distributor in any place of business serving alcoholic beverages for on-premises consumption under the provisions of this chapter and licensed by the state, or any employee thereof, shall permit any person who is not a licensed vendor or employee thereof to remain in the licensed premises beyond the legally authorized closing hour. However, if the premises are divided so that the portion of the premises where alcoholic beverages are kept, stored or dispensed is separated by a partition and locked doors after the legal closing hour, the prohibition shall not apply. 
(Code 1985, § 110.05)  
Sec. 10-8. - Distance of licensed premises from existing alcoholic beverage use business. 
Unless approved as a special exception, no premises shall be used for the sale of any alcoholic beverages to be consumed on or off the premises where the structure or place of business intended for this use is located less than 1,500 feet from a place of business having an existing, unabandoned, legally established alcoholic beverage use which permits consumption on or off the premises. The 1,500-foot distance requirement shall be measured by following a straight line from the nearest portion of the structure of the place of business. 
(Code 1985, § 110.06)  
Sec. 10-9. - Distance of licensed premises from church, school. 
Unless approved as a special exception, no premises shall be used for the sale of alcoholic beverages to be consumed on or off the premises where the structure or place of business intended for this use is located less than 2,500 feet from a church or place of religious worship or school. The 2,500-foot distance requirement shall be measured and computed as follows: 
(1)  From a church or place of religious worship, the distance shall be measured by following a straight line from the front door of the proposed place of business to the nearest point of the church or place of religious worship structure. 
(2)  From a school, the distance shall be measured by following a straight line from the front door of the proposed place of business to the nearest point of the school grounds. 
(Code 1985, § 110.07)  
Sec. 10-10. - Transfer of license. 
No alcoholic beverage license shall be transferred to another person or location without notice to and approval by the city council.  
Sec. 10-11. - Consumption of alcoholic beverages in public places. 
(a)  The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Parking lot or parking area of any commercial establishment means any paved or unpaved area in, on, around, or near any store, warehouse, business, manufacturing or assembly plant, bar, lounge, skating rink, place of amusement, or other commercial activity located within the city. 
Public place means streets, sidewalks, parkways, parks, playgrounds, tennis courts, school buildings, schoolyards, city hall, and any other property owned or in the possession of the city, or any other state, county, or governmental agency, which is used or intended for use by city or governmental employees, or by members of the general public. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to drink alcoholic beverages in any public place in the city, or in, on, or upon any parking lot or parking area of commercial establishments within the city. It shall be unlawful for any person to drink alcoholic beverages in or upon any automobile, truck, motorcycle, or other vehicle while the vehicle is in or upon any public place or in or upon any parking area of any commercial establishment within the city. 
(c)  The prohibitions of this section shall not apply in parks or playgrounds at any function, party, picnic, or other occasion for which a permit has been obtained from the mayor, or the president of the city council in the absence of the mayor. 
(Code 1985, § 133.01)  
Sec. 10-12. - Nude and seminude entertainment prohibited on licensed premises. 
(a)  Intent. It is the intent of the city to: 
(1)  Prohibit nude and seminude entertainment in commercial establishments holding alcoholic beverage licenses; 
(2)  Prohibit the commercial advertisement, promotion, and exploitation of nude and seminude entertainment in commercial establishments holding alcoholic beverage licenses; and 
(3)  Proscribe conduct and activities which encourage the competitive commercial exploitation of nude and seminude entertainment in commercial establishments holding alcoholic beverage licenses. 
(b)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Advertisement means a display, notice, or other information designed to attract public attention, including, but not limited to, handbills, signs, billboards, soundtracks, placards, signboards, and written notices. 
Commercial means operated for pecuniary gain, which shall be presumed for any establishment which has received a local business tax receipt from any county or municipality. For purposes of this section, operating for pecuniary gain shall not depend on actual profit or loss. 
Establishment means a physical place or location, or the commercial activities or operations being conducted at such place or location, or both, as the context of this section may require. 
Nude or seminude entertainment consists of the following: 
(1)  The actual or simulated display of the genitals, vulva, pubic area, buttocks, anus, or anal cleft or cleavage. 
(2)  The actual or simulated display by a female of the area of the human breast at or below the areola. 
Person means any individual, firm, association, joint venture, partnership, estate, trust, business trust, syndicate, fiduciary, corporation, government official, government entity, or any other group or combination of groups. 
Premises means the area wherein alcoholic beverage sales or consumption are permitted by the license. 
(c)  Prohibited activities. 
(1)  It is unlawful for any person to engage in nude or seminude entertainment in any commercial establishment holding an alcoholic beverage license. 
(2)  It is unlawful for any female person, while on the premises of a commercial establishment holding an alcoholic beverage license, to expose to public view that area of the human female breast at or below the areola or to employ any device or covering which is intended to give the appearance of or simulate such areas of the female breast as described in this subsection. 
(3)  It is unlawful for any person, while on the premises of a commercial establishment holding an alcoholic beverage license, to expose to public view such person's genitals, pubic area, buttocks, anus, or anal cleft or cleavage, or to employ any device or covering which is intended to give the appearance of or simulate the genitals, pubic area, buttocks, anus, or anal cleft or cleavage. 
(4)  It is unlawful for any person owning, maintaining, operating, or leasing any commercial establishment holding an alcoholic beverage license to suffer or permit any person on the premises to engage in nude or seminude entertainment. 
(5)  It is unlawful for any entertainer, performer, or employee, while on the premises of a commercial establishment regulated under this section, to dance in such a manner as to simulate sexual activity with any patron, spectator, employee or other person not employed therein. 
(6)  It is unlawful for any entertainer, performer, or employee, while on the premises of a commercial establishment regulated under this section, to sit upon or straddle the leg, legs, lap, or body of a patron, spectator, or other person therein, or to engage in or simulate sexual activity while touching or being touched by such patron, spectator, or other person. 
(7)  It is unlawful for any person owning, maintaining, operating or leasing a commercial establishment regulated under this section to suffer or permit any violation of subsection (c)(3) or (c)(6) of this section. 
(8)  It is unlawful for any licensee to permit any person, while on the premises of a commercial establishment regulated under this section, to use, or be present in, any area partitioned or screened from public view that is designed to be occupied by any persons for sexual contact or private dancing performances. 
(9)  It is unlawful for any person owning, maintaining, operating or leasing a commercial establishment regulated under this section to suffer or permit the construction, maintenance or use of any area partitioned or screened from public view that is designed to be occupied by any persons for sexual contact or private dancing performances. 
(10)  It is unlawful for any person owning, maintaining, operating or leasing a commercial establishment regulated under this section to suffer or permit any outside advertisement which encourages, solicits, induces or promotes conduct or activities proscribed by this section in such establishment. 
(d)  Presumptions. The following presumptions shall apply in actions brought for violation of this section: 
(1)  Any person who owns, maintains, operates, leases or enters a commercial establishment where nude or seminude entertainment actually takes place on the premises in violation of this section is presumed to be aware that such nude or seminude entertainment is taking place in the establishment. 
(2)  Any establishment which has received a local business tax receipt from the city to operate commercially is presumed to be a commercial establishment. 
(e)  Penalty. Anyone convicted of a violation of the provisions of this section is guilty of a violation of this Code, punishable as provided in section 1-16 and by revocation of any license and the privilege of doing business for a period of one year. 
(Ord. No. 90-17, § 1, 6-12-90; Ord. No. 2008-06, § 3, 9-16-09) 
Cross reference— Sexually oriented businesses, § 18-86 et seq.; miscellaneous offenses, ch. 34.  
Chapter 11 - AMUSEMENTS AND ENTERTAINMENTS  
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Secs. 11-1—11-20. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - COIN- OR CURRENCY-OPERATED MACHINES 
 
Sec. 11-21. - Definitions. 
The following terms shall have the meanings ascribed to them herein: 
Adult only coin- or currency-operated amusement machines shall be defined as any machine which depicts an activity which is normally perceived as being an activity which is primarily for the purpose of pari mutuel wagering and/or is available primarily in a casino setting (i.e., horse racing, dog racing, poker, roulette, slot machines, etc.) 
Amusement center shall mean a place of business having at least five or more coin or currency-operated amusement machines, which are operated, for the entertainment of the general public as a bona fide amusement facility. 
Coin- or currency-operated amusement machines: Any machine operated by insertion of coin, slug, token, credit card or paper currency which provides for entertainment or amusement of any kind. This definition excludes pinball machines, pool or billiard tables, vending machines, soda machines, kiddy rides, automatic music machines and skill games. 
Operator of coin- or currency-operate amusement machines shall mean an operator of coin- or currency-operated amusement machines is hereby defined as any person who shall own, operate or control coin- or currency-operated amusement machines. 
Person shall mean any individual, firm, member of firm, partnership, member of partnership, corporation, or any officer, director or stockholder of said corporation. 
(Ord. No. 99-03, § 1, 1-19-99)  
Sec. 11-22. - License revocation. 
If the person to whom a license has previously been issued shall thereafter be convicted or plead guilty to nolo contendere to any felony or a violation of any federal, state, county or municipal statute or ordinance involving gambling or the sale, transportation, possession or use of illegal drugs or a conspiracy involving any of the foregoing (either gambling or illegal drugs), said license shall immediately thereafter be revoked by the city council after a public hearing, notice of which shall be served in writing upon the licensee at least 15 days before the date set for the hearing, if the public hearing establishes that the facts set forth in this subsection requiring a revocation of said license do indeed exist. 
(Ord. No. 99-03, § 2, 1-19-99)  
Sec. 11-23. - Operation of coin-operated and currency-operated amusement machines generally. 
Coin-operated and currency-operated amusement machines, as defined by the definitions of this article, shall not be located and operated on premises where alcoholic beverages are consumed or where alcoholic beverages are consumed and offered for sale or sold. 
(Ord. No. 99-03, § 3, 1-19-99)  
Sec. 11-24. - License; transfer prohibited. 
No license issued under and by the authority of this article shall be transferable, and such license shall be valid only for the operator to whom the license was originally issued. 
(Ord. No. 99-03, § 4, 1-19-99)  
Sec. 11-25. - Operation of amusement centers generally. 
The establishment and operation of an amusement center shall be in accordance with the following: 
(1)  No alcoholic beverages shall be sold and/or consumed in the amusement center. 
(Ord. No. 99-03, § 5, 1-19-99)  
Sec. 11-26. - Operation of amusement centers associated with a bona fide recreational facility. 
Amusement centers licensed in bona fide recreational facilities for more than five, but less than 50 coin- or currency-operated amusement machines must be operated in accordance with the following requirements: 
(1)  No alcoholic beverages shall be sold and/or consumed in an amusement center associated with a bona fide recreational facility. 
(Ord. No. 99-03, § 6, 1-19-99)  
Sec. 11-27. - Minors prohibited from playing certain machines. 
(a)  Coin- or currency-operated which fall under the definition of adult only machines shall each bear a sticker, at least three inches in diameter, which clearly and legibly says "Play Prohibited by Minors." 
(b)  It shall be the responsibility of the licensee to assure than minors are prohibited from playing such machines at all times. Failure of the licensee to monitor and prohibit play by minors of said designated machines should be sufficient cause to subject the licensee to revocation of his/her license(s) under this article. 
(Ord. No. 99-03, § 7, 1-19-99)  
Sec. 11-28. - Gambling prohibited; purpose of article. 
No person or operator licensed under this article shall permit any coin- or currency-operated machines to be used for gambling or games of chance so as to be in violation of F.S. ch. 849. The intent and purpose of this article is to license the operation of coin and currency operated machines for amusement and skill purposes only. 
(Ord. No. 99-03, § 8, 1-19-99)  
Sec. 11-29. - Money, etc., prize restrictions. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the operation of any coin- or currency-operated machine, either as operator or licensee thereof where there is a prize or reward given other than automatic replays granted by the machine. 
(Ord. No. 99-03, § 9, 1-19-99)  
Sec. 11-30. - Seizure for nonpayment of fee; release. 
In the event of nonpayment of the license fee by any operator, or the placement of unlicensed machines within the city, authority is hereby given and granted to the chief license official or his/her designee to seize any of the said operator's machines for such payment. No machines so seized shall be released until the license fee and all storage and hauling and all other expenses have been paid in full. 
(Ord. No. 99-03, § 10, 1-19-99)  
Sec. 11-31. - Same—Sale when not redeemed, etc., by owner. 
When any coin- or currency-operated machine, seized pursuant to section 9-10 has not been claimed by the owner thereof by 90 days from the date of such seizure, the city chief license inspector shall sell any such machine at public sale after ten days' notice in writing to the owner if he can be found, and by at least one advertisement in a newspaper of general circulation in the city. All proceeds of said sale shall be credited to the general fund of the city; and shall offset the fees, costs, and storage owed by the owner of said machines. 
(Ord. No. 99-03, § 11, 1-19-99)  
Sec. 11-32. - Carnival; exemption for coin- or currency-operated amusement machines. 
Coin- or currency-operated amusement machines operated in conjunction with and under the auspices of a carnival duty licensed by the City of Hialeah Gardens, Florida, to operate within the City of Hialeah Gardens, shall be exempted from the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 99-03, § 12, 1-19-99)  
Sec. 11-33. - Amusement centers. 
All amusement centers shall be located in the BU zoning district (business district) which have floor areas in excess of 1,000 square feet. No amusement center will be permitted within a distance of 1,500 feet from another center. 
(Ord. No. 99-03, § 13, 1-19-99)  
Sec. 11-34. - Penalties. 
Any person, firm or corporation convicted of violating the provisions of this article shall be punished by a fine of $300.00. 
(Ord. No. 99-03, § 15, 1-19-99)  
Chapter 14 - ANIMALS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Code compliance, § 2-211 et seq. 
State Law reference— Animal care and control, F.S. ch. 828; damage by dogs, F.S. ch. 767. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 14-1. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
At large means off the premises of the owner, and not under the control, custody, charge, or possession of the owner or other responsible person, either by leash, cord, chain, or otherwise. 
Cat means a member of the feline family and includes both male and female. 
Dog means a member of the canine family and includes both male and female. 
Fowl and poultry includes birds that are domesticated, hens, cocks, turkeys, geese, swans, ducks and other gallinaceous or similar birds. 
Owner means any person owning, harboring, keeping, or controlling a dog within the city limits. 
Wild animal is used as a term to indicate animals and reptiles of a species not usually domesticated in the United States and does not refer to the comparative docility or familiarity with man of a particular animal. Such term does not refer to pets customarily found in and about homes, such as baby turtles, small nonpoisonous lizards, and the like. 
(Code 1985, § 90.01; Ord. No. 98-18, § 1, 9-15-98) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 14-2. - Enforcement. 
The police department shall be the agency responsible for enforcing this chapter. The city council, in the manner provided by law, may promulgate rules and regulations incident to the proper administration, implementation, and enforcement of the provisions of this chapter. 
(Code 1985, § 90.08)  
Sec. 14-3. - Penalty for violation of chapter. 
The violation of any provision of this chapter for which another penalty is not specifically provided shall be punished as a civil infraction by a fine not exceeding $500.00, in the discretion of the court. Each violation shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1985, § 90.99(A)) 
State Law reference— Cruelty to animals prohibited, penalty, F.S. § 828.12.  
Sec. 14-4. - Sale of baby animals. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, offer for sale, barter, or give away baby chickens or ducklings under six weeks of age, or rabbits under two months of age, as pets, toys, premiums, or novelties. However, this section shall not be construed to prohibit the sale or display of baby chickens, ducklings, or rabbits in proper facilities by breeders or stores engaged in the business of selling them to be raised for commercial purposes. 
(Code 1985, § 90.02(A)) 
State Law reference— Artificial coloring and sale of certain animals prohibited, F.S. § 828.161.  
Sec. 14-5. - Pens and enclosures. 
No fowl, poultry or pigs shall be kept or maintained on residential property zoned LDR, MOR, MER or HDR, provided, however, nothing shall prohibit keeping or maintaining domesticated pets within a residential dwelling, provided such domesticated pets are confined to such residential dwelling and do not constitute a health hazard. No poultry, fowl, pig pen or other animal enclosure shall be situated or maintained within 25 feet of any neighboring residential dwelling. Such pens or enclosures must be kept free from odors, fly breeding and other offensive or unhealthy conditions and all food used for poultry, fowl, pigs or other animals shall be kept in suitable containers with tightfitting covers inaccessible to rats and other varmints. Commercial fowl, poultry or pig raising establishments shall be subject to those rules as are consistent with the city land development and zoning regulation and county, state and federal laws related to such enterprises. 
(Code 1985, § 90.03; Ord. No. 98-18, § 2, 9-15-98)  
Sec. 14-6. - Keeping of wild animals and reptiles; permit. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to keep any wild animal or reptile without first having obtained a permit from the city council. However, this provision shall not apply to parks, zoos, pet shops, medical or scientific institutions, or other places licensed for the showing or keeping of wild animals or reptiles. In the city council's consideration of permits for animals subject to the provisions of this section there shall be a presumption against the issuance of a permit for any animal or reptile falling within the following classifications: 
(1)  Any snake normally possessing fangs and poisonous glands and capable of inducing toxic effects through biting. 
(2)  Any snake possessing the power of constriction and in excess of ten feet in length or of a weight in excess of 25 pounds. 
(3)  Any lizard normally capable of inducing toxic effects through biting, including the gila monster and the Mexican beaded lizard. 
(4)  Any lizard in excess of eight feet in length or of a weight in excess of 25 pounds. 
(5)  Any alligator, caiman, or crocodile in excess of four feet in length. 
(6)  Any ape, including the chimpanzee, gorilla, orangutan, gibbon, or simian. 
(7)  All members of the flesh-eating order carnivora, including nondomestic dogs, cats, foxes, seals, raccoons, coatimundis, bears, civets, skunks, and related forms. 
(8)  Elephants. 
(b)  There shall be a presumption in favor of the issuance of a permit to keep animals which do not fall within the classifications set forth in this section. However, the city council may still, in the exercise of their discretion, rely upon their judgment as to when the keeping of such an animal is dangerous and harmful to human safety. 
(Code 1985, § 90.04)  
Secs. 14-7—14-35. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - DOGS AND CATS 
 
Sec. 14-36. - Running at large. 
No person owning or having possession, charge, custody, or control of any dog shall cause, permit, or allow the dog to stray, run, go, or in any other manner to be at large in or upon any public street, sidewalk, or park, or on private property of others, without the express or implied consent of the owner of the private property. This section shall not apply to any dog when the dog is actually engaged in the sport of hunting in authorized areas and supervised by and under the control of a competent person. 
(Code 1985, § 90.16)  
Sec. 14-37. - Removal of dog excrement from public areas. 
It shall be unlawful for the owner or person having custody of any dog to permit, either willfully or through failure to exercise due care or control, the dog to deposit excrement upon the sidewalk of any public street; or upon the floor of any common hall in any apartment house, tenement house, hotel, or other multiple dwelling; or upon any entranceway, stairway, or wall immediately abutting into a public sidewalk; or upon the floor of any other building used in common by the public. If such excrement is deposited by a dog, such person shall, immediately, properly pick it up and dispose of it in a proper place. 
(Code 1985, § 90.15)  
Sec. 14-38. - Rabies vaccination. 
Every person who owns and harbors any dog or cat four months of age or older in the city limits shall have the dog or cat vaccinated against rabies by a licensed veterinarian. Evidence of vaccination shall consist of a county certificate, signed by the licensed veterinarian administering the vaccine. However, no dog or cat need be vaccinated for rabies where a licensed veterinarian has examined the dog or cat and certified that at that time vaccination would endanger the animal's health because of its age, infirmity, debility, or some other physiological consideration; and the certificate is presented to the enforcing agency of the county or the city within five days of such examination. The certificate shall not be valid for more than 12 months from the date of issuance. 
(Code 1985, § 90.17) 
State Law reference— Rabies vaccination of dogs and cats required, F.S. § 828.30.  
Sec. 14-39. - Number of cats restricted in certain areas. 
No more than three cats over the age of eight weeks shall be permitted to be kept at any one time on any premises zoned for residential purposes, or on other premises within 500 feet of any such premises. 
(Ord. No. 90-06, § 1(90.24), 3-27-90) 
Cross reference— Land use regulations, ch. 78.  
Sec. 14-40. - Identification collars for cats. 
All cats owned by residents of the city shall be required to wear a collar, which shall contain the name, current address and current telephone number of the owner of such cat, or as otherwise required by applicable county ordinance or state statutes. 
(Ord. No. 90-06, § 1(90.25), 3-27-90)  
Secs. 14-41—14-65. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - LIVESTOCK 
 
Sec. 14-66. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Animal means bovine or equine animals, male and female, singular and plural. 
(Ord. No. 94-03, § 1(a), 4-19-94) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 14-67. - Restrictions on riding or leading. 
No person shall ride or lead an animal, as defined in this article: 
(1)  On any sidewalk; 
(2)  Through any service station; 
(3)  Through any shopping center; 
(4)  Upon private property without the prior consent or authorization of the property owner; 
(5)  On or along a street or roadway other than on the left side of the street or roadway facing approaching traffic, except where bridle paths are provided; 
(6)  In other than single file, except on designated bridle paths; 
(7)  Between sunset and sunrise unless the animal, and the person riding or leading it, each bears a reflector of such size and characteristics and so maintained as to be readily visible at nighttime from all distances within 500 feet to 50 feet from the animal when in front of lawful upper beams of motor vehicle headlamps. 
(Ord. No. 94-03, § 1(b), 4-19-94)  
Sec. 14-68. - Group of riders. 
A person at least 18 years of age must be placed in charge of any organized group of riders on any designated bridle path or public way, from any riding academy, stable, club or similar establishment. 
(Ord. No. 94-03, § 2, 4-19-94)  
Sec. 14-69. - Traffic regulations apply to riding animals. 
Every person riding an animal in the city shall be subject to the provisions of the traffic ordinances and regulations of the city, except those provisions which by their nature can have no application. 
(Ord. No. 94-03, § 3, 4-19-94)  
Sec. 14-70. - Exceptions. 
The police mounted patrol, as well as any mounted patrol so authorized by the chief of police, i.e., search and rescue, etc., are excluded from this article. 
(Ord. No. 94-03, § 4, 4-19-94)  
Chapter 18 - BUSINESSES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Code compliance, § 2-211 et seq.; handbills, § 6-31 et seq.; license required for distribution of handbills, § 6-34; alcoholic beverages, ch. 10; local business tax receipt, § 46-31 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 18-1. - Posting of information on front door of commercial establishments. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Commercial establishment means any establishment within the city wherein business is conducted, regardless of the frequency of such business being conducted. 
(b)  Posting of information required. 
(1)  Every owner of a commercial establishment within the city shall post in a conspicuous place on the front door of the establishment the name, address, and telephone number of a person who can be contacted at any hour of the day or night for the purpose of peaceful entry to the commercial establishment when requested to do so by any persons authorized to enter upon the premises by virtue of an emergency or otherwise. 
(2)  In lieu of utilizing the address as set forth in subsection (b)(1) of this section, the owner may post a second telephone number with the name of the person to be contacted at such telephone number in a conspicuous place on the front door of the establishment, who can be contacted at any hour of the day or night for the purpose of peaceful entry to the commercial establishment when requested to do so by any persons authorized to enter upon the premises by virtue of an emergency or otherwise. 
(c)  Enforcement. This section may be enforced by the code compliance board or judicially through the courts. 
(d)  Penalty. Should the owner of a commercial establishment fail to comply with the terms and conditions of this section, such owner shall be subject to a fine not to exceed $500.00 for each such violation. 
(Code 1985, §§ 116.01—116.03, 116.99; Ord. No. 2001-09, 6-19-01)  
Secs. 18-2—18-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - PRIVATE PARKING LOTS AND FACILITIES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Land use regulations type, density, intensity of use, § 78-126 et seq. 
 
Sec. 18-31. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Garage means a building, shed or enclosure, or any portion thereof, in which motor vehicles may be parked, stored, housed or kept, for which any charge is made. 
Motor vehicle means any automobile, truck, motor scooter, or other self-propelled vehicle not operated on tracks or from trolleys. 
Parking lot means any outdoor space, or uncovered plot, place, lot, parcel, yard or enclosure, or any portion thereof, where motor vehicles may be parked, stored, housed or kept, for which any charge is made. This definition shall specifically not apply to otherwise duly licensed and regulated businesses which charge for parking only as part of their principal business and for which such parking is appurtenant to their principal business. 
(Ord. No. 94-04, § 1, 5-3-94) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 18-32. - Penalty for violation of article. 
Any owner or operator of a parking lot or garage in the city found to be in violation of the terms of this article shall be subjected to one of the following penalties: 
(1)  Any person convicted of violating the provisions of this article shall be punished as provided in section 1-16. 
(2)  Issuance of a notice of violation by a city building official or code compliance officer requiring the owner and/or operator to appear before the city code compliance board, which shall have jurisdiction to impose penalties pursuant to the authority granted by F.S. ch. 162. 
(Ord. No. 94-04, § 25, 5-3-94; Ord. No. 2001-09, 6-19-01)  
Sec. 18-33. - License and site plan review required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct a business of storing motor vehicles for hire on property, a parking lot or garage within the city without first having obtained a site plan review approval and a license therefor in the manner set forth in this article. 
(Ord. No. 94-04, § 2, 5-3-94)  
Sec. 18-34. - Application for license and site plan review. 
Applications for licenses and site plan review required by this article shall be made upon forms provided by the zoning and code compliance department, shall be signed and verified under oath by the applicant, if an individual, or by a duly authorized agent if a partnership or corporation, and shall set forth the following: 
(1)  If a person, the name and address of the applicant; 
(2)  If a partnership, the name, residence and business address of each partner; 
(3)  If a corporation, the name, date and state under whose laws such corporation was organized, and if a foreign corporation, whether authorized to do business in this state, the names of the principal officers, directors and local representatives, their residences and business addresses; 
(4)  A site plan, as provided in section 18-35, shall be submitted with the application; 
(5)  The hours for storage or parking of such vehicles and whether night storage is to be maintained upon the licensed premises; 
(6)  The hours during which parking attendants will be on duty; 
(7)  A complete schedule of the rates to be charged for storing or parking vehicles; 
(8)  Such other information as the zoning and code compliance department may deem necessary for the issuance of such licenses. 
(Ord. No. 94-04, § 3, 5-3-94; Ord. No. 2001-09, 6-19-01)  
Sec. 18-35. - Site plan requirements. 
A site plan shall be provided, along with the license application as provided in section 18-34, for review by the zoning and code compliance department. The site plan, at a scale of no less than one inch equals 100 feet, shall include the following information: 
(1)  Location, size, construction, and type of barrier surrounding the lot or garage as provided in section 18-49; 
(2)  The location, size, and capacity of the parking garage or lot; 
(3)  The location and size of entrances and exits and kind of floor or ground surface; 
(4)  The location, size, and construction of attendant's station, wall or barriers surrounding such premises; 
(5)  The floor plans and elevation of the proposed parking garage or other building, if any; 
(6)  Drainage plan for site retention of the rainwater and the flood protection of the adjoining property; 
(7)  Lot lines, setbacks, parking space, driveway, and site analysis. 
All parking lots shall be only on property zoned for commercial use. In addition, all parking lot site plans shall have a minimum of 15 percent of the net lot area as landscape open space with eight feet width of greenbelt along all property lines. The plans shall also have a total land area sufficient to meet all land development regulations of the city, including, but not limited to, county and state requirements. 
(Ord. No. 94-04, § 4, 5-3-94) 
Cross reference— Land use regulations site plan review, § 78-271 et seq.  
Sec. 18-36. - Bond or liability insurance required. 
Every application for a license under this article shall be accompanied by a bond, approved as to form by the city attorney, executed by a bonding or surety company authorized to do business in the state, in the penal sum of $5,000.00, conditioned upon payment by the licensee of any and all final judgments for damages resulting to persons arising out of the operation or maintenance of any parking lot or garage. Such bond shall run to the city for the benefit of any person who may receive injuries, and for the benefit of any person who may claim redress for property damage or theft, resulting from the operation or maintenance of such parking lot or garage. Such bond shall remain in full force and effect for the full period of time for which the license is effective. A liability insurance policy issued by an insurance company authorized to do business in the state, conforming to the requirements of this section, may be permitted in lieu of a bond. 
(Ord. No. 94-04, § 15, 5-3-94)  
Sec. 18-37. - License fees. 
The license fees for the operation of a parking lot under this article are on file in the city clerk's office. 
(Ord. No. 94-04, § 5, 5-3-94)  
Sec. 18-38. - Issuance of license; term of license; records. 
If, after an investigation by the police department and approval of the application by the zoning and code compliance department of the city, the city council shall be reasonably satisfied that the applicant has a good reputation and that the statements set forth in the application are correct, and if the proper fee shall have been paid, the city shall issue to the applicant a license for a parking lot or garage. Such license shall continue in full force and effect for a period of one year from the date of issuance of the license, or until revoked by the city council. The city clerk shall keep a record of all applications and licenses issued under this article, indexed alphabetically and by location. 
(Ord. No. 94-04, § 7, 5-3-94)  
Sec. 18-39. - License not transferable. 
No license issued under this article shall be transferred or assigned or used by any person other than the one to whom it was issued, or at any location other than the one for which it was issued. 
(Ord. No. 94-04, § 8, 5-3-94)  
Sec. 18-40. - Revocation of license. 
The city council may revoke any parking lot or garage license if, upon a hearing and investigation after at least ten days' written notice of the time and place of such hearing, the city council finds: 
(1)  The licensee has knowingly made any false or materially incorrect statement in the application; 
(2)  The licensee knowingly violates or knowingly permits or countenances the violation of any provision of this article; 
(3)  The licensee has made any charge for parking or storing a vehicle other than those set forth in his license application; 
(4)  The licensee knowingly violates or knowingly permits or countenances the violation of any provision of any penal law or ordinance regarding theft, larceny or conversion of a motor vehicle, or the operation of a motor vehicle without the owner's consent, whether such licensee or other person has been convicted of such offense or not; 
(5)  The licensee fails to keep an attendant on duty during the times specified on his application. 
(Ord. No. 94-04, § 9, 5-3-94)  
Sec. 18-41. - Rates to be filed with clerk. 
Every licensee under this article shall file with the city clerk at the time of application for license a complete schedule of rates and charges to be made for storing or parking motor vehicles on the premises to be licensed. 
(Ord. No. 94-04, § 10, 5-3-94)  
Sec. 18-42. - Change in rates. 
Every application for a change in the schedule of rates or charges, as filed under section 18-41, shall first be submitted in writing to the city council, which shall hold hearings on such applications to determine the necessity of such change. In making its decision, the city council shall take into consideration, in each case where application is made, operating and labor costs, increases in rental or maintenance costs, and such other factors as may reasonably enter into the conduct of the business. If the city council approves the proposed change in rates and charges, the schedule as filed shall be amended. 
(Ord. No. 94-04, § 11, 5-3-94)  
Sec. 18-43. - Employee identification cards. 
Every person owning or operating a parking lot or garage shall file with the city police department the name and address of each employee employed at such parking lot or garage and shall obtain from the police department a card showing the name and address of each such employee and the name and address of the operator of such parking lot or garage at which he is employed. Such card shall be carried by the employee at all times that he is on the premises and shall be exhibited at any time on demand. The annual fee for the issuance of each parking lot employee's identification card is on file in the city clerk's office. 
(Ord. No. 94-04, § 6, 5-3-94)  
Sec. 18-44. - Signs. 
(a)  Required. Each licensee under this article shall maintain at each entrance to the parking lot or garage a permanently affixed sign suitable to apprise persons using such parking lot or garage of the name of the licensee; the hours of the day or night when such place is open for parking or storing motor vehicles; the rates charged by and the closing hours of such parking lot or garage. Where more than one rate is charged for parking, the figures for each rate shall be of the same size and dimensions and such figures shall measure not less than six inches in height. All such signs shall be subject to the approval of the zoning official or his authorized representative. 
(b)  Day and night rates. Where separate rates or charges are made for day parking and night parking, the night rate shall become effective at 6:30 p.m., and notice thereof shall be posted by the licensee on the signs described in subsection (a) of this section. 
(c)  Height above sidewalk. All signs required by this section shall be erected pursuant to the provisions of section 82-134(a) of this Code, and shall not be erected in such a manner as to interfere with, mislead or confuse traffic. 
(Ord. No. 94-04, § 12, 5-3-94)  
Sec. 18-45. - Licensee not to refuse vehicles. 
No licensee under this article shall refuse to park or store any vehicle for which there shall be accommodation in the parking lot or garage upon tender of the stated fee for such parking. 
(Ord. No. 94-04, § 13, 5-3-94)  
Sec. 18-46. - Claim checks; return of vehicle. 
(a)  When a vehicle is left for storing or parking, the licensee of the parking lot or garage, his agent, servant or employee shall furnish the owner or operator of such vehicle with a distinctive claim check, which shall have printed thereon the full name and address of the parking lot or garage, a number corresponding to a coupon placed upon the vehicle, and shall have written or stamped thereon the date and license number of the motor vehicle. The licensee shall not deliver any vehicle without the proper claim check being presented, or without satisfactory proof of ownership of such vehicle. 
(b)  This section shall not apply where vehicles are stored or parked on a weekly or monthly fee basis. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful to affix any parking coupon upon any vehicle so as to obliterate in whole or in part any portion of the license plates on such vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 94-04, § 14, 5-3-94)  
Sec. 18-47. - Entrances and exits. 
Each parking lot or garage shall have one common entrance and one common exit, which may or may not be combined, and the operator of such parking lot or garage shall keep such entrance and exit properly attended at all times during the period the parking lot or garage is in operation. 
(Ord. No. 94-04, § 16, 5-3-94)  
Sec. 18-48. - Fire protection. 
Every parking lot or garage shall be equipped with proper fire extinguishing apparatus subject to the approval of the fire department, and all vehicles shall be so parked or stored that they may be reached readily in case of fire or other emergency. 
(Ord. No. 94-04, § 23, 5-3-94)  
Sec. 18-49. - Barriers in parking lots. 
Except for places of entrance and exit, every parking lot shall be completely enclosed by barriers constructed and maintained so as to withstand the shocks and stresses to which they will normally be subjected by vehicles using the premises and shall be of such height as to engage the bumper of any motor vehicle parked on such lot so that no portion of the vehicles shall extend over the property lines. When such lot abuts on a building, barriers shall be erected as provided in this section to prevent motor vehicles from striking such building. When such lot abuts a commercial district, a barrier shall be erected consisting of a chainlink fence with aluminum slats with a minimum height of ten feet. When such lot abuts a business or residential district, a barrier shall be erected consisting of a finished block wall, stucco on block, painted, with a height of seven feet as measured by the crown of the road adjacent to the property wherein the wall is being constructed, with equal architectural treatments on both sides consistent with the surrounding area, the city's land development code and the South Florida Building Code. 
(Ord. No. 94-04, § 17, 5-3-94)  
Sec. 18-50. - Maintenance of parking lot or garage and surroundings. 
(a)  Sidewalks. Every operator of a parking lot or garage shall keep the sidewalk surrounding the premises free from dirt, and shall keep such sidewalk and the driveways in a safe condition for the travel of pedestrians. 
(b)  Dust and water. The ground or floor space of each parking lot or garage, if made of dirt, sand, cinders or other loose mixture, shall at all times be kept thoroughly sprinkled or treated with water, calcium chloride or other means, so that the dust, sand, cinders or other substance of which such ground or floor space is made will not be raised, carried or blown by the wind, movement of vehicles, or other causes, into or upon public property, or the adjacent property of others. The surface or floor of such premises shall be constructed so as to prevent retention of water thereon. 
(Ord. No. 94-04, § 18(a), (b), 5-3-94)  
Sec. 18-51. - Handbills. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to distribute literature or place handbills in or upon any vehicle which is parked in a parking lot or garage. 
(Ord. No. 94-04, § 18(c), 5-3-94)  
Sec. 18-52. - Loading or unloading of vehicles. 
The loading or unloading of passengers or drivers of vehicles across or upon a public sidewalk is hereby expressly prohibited and any operator or employee who, by receiving or delivering vehicles other than within the property line of the parking lot or garage, aids or assists in blocking any sidewalk or street shall be deemed to have violated the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 94-04, § 18(d), 5-3-94)  
Sec. 18-53. - Vendors prohibited. 
No licensee shall sublet, sublease or otherwise permit any parking lot or garage or portion thereof to be used by any vendor of goods, wares, or merchandise or services for the conduct of such vendor's business unless such use is conducted in a permanent building or structure licensed by the city for that purpose. 
(Ord. No. 94-04, § 18(e), 5-3-94)  
Sec. 18-54. - Notification of claims for damage or loss. 
Every licensee shall immediately notify the police department of every claim made by reason of loss, theft, or conversion, or any damage or injury to person or property, from the operation of a parking lot or garage, and occurring during the hours such premises are regularly open for business. The obligation created by this section shall not extend beyond the regular posted hours of attendance as posted upon the premises and printed upon the regular receipt furnished to the owner or person parking such vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 94-04, § 19, 5-3-94)  
Sec. 18-55. - Notification to police of unclaimed vehicles. 
Every licensee shall immediately notify the police department, in writing, of the license number, make, and the name of the owner, if known to him, of every vehicle left in a parking lot or garage for a period of more than 48 consecutive hours. 
(Ord. No. 94-04, § 20, 5-3-94)  
Sec. 18-56. - Unauthorized use or removal of vehicles. 
It shall be unlawful for any licensee of a parking lot or garage to make or permit any use for any purpose whatsoever of any vehicle parked in such place, unless the use shall have first been expressly authorized by the owner or person having control of such vehicle. No licensee shall transfer, or cause to be moved or transferred, any parked vehicle through or upon the streets, or alleys of the city without the written consent of the owner or person having control of such vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 94-04, § 21, 5-3-94)  
Sec. 18-57. - Vehicles left after closing time, duty of attendant. 
When vehicles are not called for at closing time, the attendant shall leave the keys and parking coupon for safekeeping at a place within a reasonable distance of the parking lot or garage, with a responsible person whose name and address shall be posted in a conspicuous place on such premises. 
(Ord. No. 94-04, § 22, 5-3-94)  
Secs. 18-58—18-85. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - SEXUALLY ORIENTED BUSINESSES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference— Nude or seminude entertainment prohibited on alcoholic beverage licensed premises, § 10-12. 
 
Sec. 18-86. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Adult arcade means any place to which the public is permitted or invited wherein coin-operated or slug-operated or electronically, electrically, or mechanically controlled still or motion picture machines, projectors, or other image producing devices are maintained to show images to five or fewer persons per machine at any one time, and where the images so displayed are distinguished or characterized by the depicting or describing of specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas. 
Adult bookstore or adult video store means a commercial establishment which, as one of its principal business purposes, offers for sale or rental for any form of consideration any one or more of the following: 
(1)  Books, magazines, periodicals or other printed matter, or photographs, films, motion pictures, videocassettes or video reproductions, slides, or other visual representations which depict or describe specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas; or 
(2)  Instruments, devices, or paraphernalia which are designed for use in connection with specified sexual activities. A commercial establishment may have other principal business purposes that do not involve the offering for sale or rental of material depicting or describing specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas and still be categorized as an adult bookstore or adult video store. Such other business purposes will not serve to exempt such commercial establishments from being categorized as an adult bookstore or adult video store so long as one of its principal business purposes is the offering for sale or rental for consideration the specified materials which depict or describe specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas. 
Adult cabaret means a nightclub, bar, restaurant, or similar commercial establishment which regularly features: 
(1)  Persons who appear in a state of nudity; 
(2)  Live performances which are characterized by the exposure of specified anatomical areas or by specified sexual activities; or 
(3)  Films, motion pictures, videocassettes, slides, or other photographic reproductions which are characterized by the depiction or description of specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas. 
Adult motel means a hotel, motel or similar commercial establishment which: 
(1)  Offers accommodations to the public for any form of consideration; provides patrons with closed circuit television transmissions, films, motion pictures, videocassettes, slides, or other photographic reproductions which are characterized by the depiction or description of specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas; and has a sign visible from the public right-of-way which advertises the availability of this adult type of photographic reproductions; 
(2)  Offers a sleeping room for rent for a period of time that is less than ten hours; or 
(3)  Allows a tenant or occupant of a sleeping room to subrent the room for a period of time that is less than ten hours. 
Adult motion picture theater means a commercial establishment where, for any form of consideration, films, motion pictures, videocassettes, slides, or similar photographic reproductions are regularly shown which are characterized by the depiction or description of specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas. 
Adult theater means a theater, concert hall, auditorium, or similar commercial establishment which regularly features persons who appear in a state of nudity or live performances which are characterized by the exposure of specified anatomical areas or by specified sexual activities. 
Escort means a person who, for consideration, agrees or offers to act as a companion, guide, or date for another person, or who agrees or offers to privately model lingerie or to privately perform a striptease for another person. 
Escort agency means a person or business association which furnishes, offers to furnish, or advertises to furnish escorts as one of its primary business purposes for a fee, tip, or other consideration. 
Establishment means and includes any of the following: 
(1)  The opening or commencement of any sexually oriented business as a new business; 
(2)  The conversion of an existing business, whether or not a sexually oriented business, to any sexually oriented business; 
(3)  The addition of any sexually oriented business to any other existing sexually oriented business; or 
(4)  The relocation of any sexually oriented business. 
Licensee or permittee means a person in whose name a license and/or permit to operate a sexually oriented business has been issued, as well as the individual listed as an applicant on the application for a license and/or permit. 
Nude model studio means any place where a person who appears in a state of nudity or displays specified anatomical areas is provided to be observed, sketched, drawn, painted, sculptured, photographed, or similarly depicted by other persons who pay money or any form of consideration. 
Nudity or state of nudity means the appearance of a human bare buttock, anus, male genitals, female genitals, or female breast. 
Person means an individual, proprietorship, partnership, corporation, association, or other legal entity. 
Seminude means a state of dress in which clothing covers no more than the genitals, pubic region, and areola of the female breast, as well as portions of the body covered by supporting straps or devices. 
Sexual encounter center means a business or commercial enterprise that, as one of its primary business purposes, offers for any form of consideration: 
(1)  Physical contact in the form of wrestling or tumbling between persons of the opposite sex; or 
(2)  Activities between male and female persons and/or persons of the same sex when one or more of the persons is in a state of nudity or seminude. 
Sexually oriented business means an adult arcade, adult bookstore or adult video store, adult cabaret, adult motel, adult motion picture theater, adult theater, escort agency, nude model studio, or sexual encounter center. 
Specified anatomical areas means the male genitals in a state of sexual arousal and/or the vulva or more intimate parts of the female genitals. 
Specified sexual activities means and includes any of the following: 
(1)  The fondling or other erotic touching of human genitals, pubic region, buttocks, anus, or female breasts; 
(2)  Sex acts, normal or perverted, actual or simulated, including intercourse, oral copulation, or sodomy; 
(3)  Masturbation, actual or simulated; or 
(4)  Excretory functions as part of or in connection with any of the activities set forth in parts (1) through (3) of this definition. 
Substantial enlargement of a sexually oriented business means the increase in floor areas occupied by the business by more than 25 percent, as the floor areas existed on February 28, 1989. 
Transfer of ownership or control of a sexually oriented business means and includes any of the following: 
(1)  The sale, lease, or sublease of the business; 
(2)  The transfer of securities which constitute a controlling interest in the business, whether by sale, exchange, or similar means; or 
(3)  The establishment of a trust, gift, or other similar legal device which transfers the ownership or control of the business, except for transfer by bequest or other operation of law upon the death of the person possessing such ownership or control. 
(Ord. No. 90-09, § II, 4-10-90) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 18-87. - Purpose and intent.
