This Pension Plan shall not merge or consolidate with any other pension plan, nor transfer any assets or liabilities to any other pension plan, unless each Participant in this Pension Plan will receive a benefit immediately after such merger, consolidation or transfer (if the Pension Plan then terminated) which is at least equal to the benefit the Participant was entitled to immediately before such merger, consolidation or transfer (if the Pension Plan had terminated). 
(Ord. No. 90-33, Ch. II, § 16-5, 5-21-91)  
Sec. 40-396. - Termination of Pension Plan. 
In the event of termination of the Pension Plan, the Board of Trustees shall follow the procedures contained in Florida Statutes, the Internal Revenue Code, and all other applicable laws. 
(Ord. No. 90-33, Ch. II, § 16-6, 5-21-91)  
Sec. 40-397. - Incorporation by Reference. 
This Pension Plan is maintained for the exclusive purpose of providing benefits to Participants and beneficiaries, and is intended to satisfy all the requirements of Florida Statutes and the Internal Revenue Code. Except as specifically provided in this Pension Plan, no part of the funds shall revert to the City. In the event any requirements of such laws have been omitted, they shall be deemed to be incorporated herein by reference. 
(Ord. No. 90-33, Ch. II, § 16-7, 5-21-91; Ord. No. 2017-14, § 6, 8-15-17)  
Sec. 40-398. - Amendment of Pension Plan. 
This Pension Plan may be amended at any time by vote of the Board of Trustees and the Hialeah Gardens City Council prospectively or retroactively, provided that such amendment complies with the Internal Revenue Code, Florida Statues, all other applicable laws, and the purposes as set forth in the Ordinance and Declaration of Trust. Additionally, and not by way of limitation, the City Council, upon the recommendation the Board of Trustees, may amend this Pension Plan when it is deemed necessary to maintain its tax exempt status, or to preserve compliance with the Internal Revenue Code, Florida Statutes, and all other applicable laws. However, no amendment which reduces the accrued benefits of any Participant shall take effect. 
(Ord. No. 90-33, Ch. II, § 16-8, 5-21-91)  
Sec. 40-399. - Federal Tax Provisions. 
(a)  USERRA. Notwithstanding any provision of this Pension Plan to the contrary, effective as of December 12, 1994, contributions, benefits and service credit with respect to Qualified Military Service will be provided in accordance with Section 414(u) of the Internal Revenue Code, USERRA or Chapter 185, Florida Statutes, as applicable. 
(1)  Death Benefit. In the case of a death or disability occurring on or after January 1, 2007, if a participant dies while performing Qualified Military Service the survivors of the participant are entitled to any additional benefits (other than benefit accruals relating to the period of Qualified Military Service) provided under the plan as if the participant had resumed and then terminated employment by the City on account of death. 
(b)  Rollover of Distributions. This section applies to distributions made on or after January 1, 1993. Notwithstanding any provision of the Pension Plan to the contrary that would otherwise limit a distributee's election under this section, a distributee may elect, at any time and in any manner prescribed by the Board of Trustees, to have any portion of an eligible rollover distribution paid directly to an eligible retirement plan specified by the distributee in a direct rollover. For the purposes of this section the following definitions shall apply: 
(1)  DIRECT ROLLOVER. A payment by the Pension Plan to the eligible retirement plan specified by the distributee. Effective as of January 1, 2008, a non-spouse Beneficiary may make a direct rollover only to an ""inherited"" individual retirement account as described in Section 408(b) of the Internal Revenue Code. If a non-spouse Beneficiary receives a distribution from the plan, the distribution is not eligible for a 60-day (non-direct) rollover. 
(2)  DISTRIBUTEE. An employee or former employee. In addition, the employee's or former employee's surviving spouse is a distributee with regard to the interest of the spouse. Effective as of January 1, 2008, a Member's or former Member's non-spouse Beneficiary is a distributee with regard to the interest of the Member or former Member. 
(3)  ELIGIBLE RETIREMENT PLAN. An individual retirement account described in Section 408(a) of the Internal Revenue Code, an individual retirement annuity account described in 408(b) of the Internal Revenue Code, an individual retirement plan described in Section 403(a) of the Internal Revenue Code, or a qualified trust described in Section 401(a) of the Internal Revenue Code that accepts the distributee's eligible rollover distribution. Effective for distributions made after December 31, 2001, an eligible retirement plan shall also mean an annuity contract described in Section 403(b) of the Internal Revenue Code and an eligible plan under Section 457(b) of the Internal Revenue Code which is maintained by a state, political subdivision of a state, or any agency or instrumentality of a state or political subdivision of a state and which agrees to separately account for amounts transferred into such plan from this Pension Plan. 
(4)  ELIGIBLE ROLLOVER DISTRIBUTION. Any distribution of all or any portion of the balance to the credit of the distributee, except that an eligible rollover distribution does not include any distribution that is one of a series of substantially equal periodic payments (not less frequently than annually) of the distributee and the distributee's designated beneficiary, for a specified period of ten years or more; any distribution to the extent such distribution is required under Section 401(a)(9) of the Internal Revenue Code; and the portion of any distribution that is not includable in gross income. 
(c)  Upon the termination of the Pension Plan or on the complete discontinuance of contributions under the Pension Plan, each Member shall have nonforfeitable, 100 percent vested rights to benefits accrued to date of the termination or discontinuance to the extent funded at that time. 
(d)  Notwithstanding anything herein to the contrary, a Member's benefits shall commence no later than April 1 of the calendar year following the later of (i) the calendar year in which he or she attains age 70½ or (ii) the calendar year in which he or she retires (the "Required Beginning Date"). All distributions from the Pension Plan (including the DROP) shall conform to the regulations issued under Section 401(a)(9) of the Internal Revenue Code, including the incidental death benefit provision of Section 401(a)(9)(G) of the Internal Revenue Code. Further, such regulation shall override any plan or DROP provision that is inconsistent with Section 401(a)(9) of the Internal Revenue Code. 
(e)  Notwithstanding any other provisions of this Pension Plan, the retirement benefit of a member shall be reduced to the extent that is exceeds amounts specified in Section 415 of the Internal Revenue Code. 
(f)  Differential Wage Payments. For years beginning after December 31, 2008, (i) an individual receiving a differential wage payment, as defined in Section 3401(h)(2) of the Internal Revenue Code, shall be treated as an employee of the employer making the payment, (ii) the differential wage payment shall be treated as compensation, and (iii) the plan shall not be treated as failing to meet the requirements of any provision described in Section 414(u)(1)(C) of the Internal Revenue Code by reason of any contribution or benefit which is based on the differential wage payment. 
(Ord. No. 2015-03, § 2, 6-2-15; Ord. No. 2017-14, § 7, 8-15-17)  
Sec. 40-400. - Share Plan Established. 
(a)  The City of Hialeah Gardens Police Pension Trust Fund Share Plan (hereinafter "Share Plan") is hereby established. The purpose is to implement the provisions of F.S. ch. 185, and to provide a mechanism to pay required "special benefits" pursuant to F.S. § 185.35. The Share Plan may be funded exclusively with available premium tax revenue received from the State of Florida pursuant to F.S. ch. 185 and shall be in addition to the monthly defined benefit payable by the City of Hialeah Gardens Police Pension Trust Fund. The Share Plan shall be administered by the Board of Trustees of the City of Hialeah Gardens Police Pension Trust Fund (hereinafter the "Fund"). 
(b)  Rule-Making Authority. The Board of Trustees of the Fund shall be authorized to adopt any rules necessary for the administration of the Share Plan. 
(Ord. No. 2017-13, § 1, 8-15-17)  
Chapter 42 - SOLID WASTE[1] 

Footnotes:

Sec. 42-1. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, unless otherwise provided, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
City approved collector means an entity which has contracted with the city to provide garbage and trash collection within the city limits. 
Commercial establishments means any hotel, motel, apartment house, roominghouse, or tourist court which contains three or more service units, and any other building, business, or establishment of any nature or kind whatsoever other than a residential unit. 
Container means a galvanized metal, durable plastic, or other suitable material container of the type commonly sold as a garbage can, having a tightfitting metal or plastic top with handle, a waterproof bottom, and constructed so as to permit the free discharge of its contents. 
Garbage means every refuse accumulation of animal, fruit, or vegetable matter that attends the preparation, use, cooking, dealing in, or storage of edibles, and any other matter of any nature whatsoever which is subject to decay, putrefaction, and the generation of noxious or offensive gases or odors, or which, during or after decay, may serve as breeding or feeding material for flies or other germ-carrying insects or as an attraction to animals. 
Garbage can means a plastic or galvanized metal container of the type commonly sold as a garbage can, of a capacity not less than 20 gallons and not to exceed 30 gallons, unless otherwise issued by the city, having two handles upon the sides thereof, or a bail by which it may be lifted, and a tight fitting metal or plastic top with handle, and so constructed as to permit the free discharge of it contents. 
Garden trash means all accumulations of leaves, grass, shrubbery, cuttings, and other refuse attending the care of lawns, shrubbery, vines, and trees. 
Health nuisance means any condition which exists and affects or could affect the state of being hale, sound or whole in body or mind of any resident of the city or relates to a sanitary condition or infectious or deleterious health influence. 
Health officer means a person appointed by the mayor, ratified by the city council, who may be a building official or code compliance officer. 
Industrial wastes means the waste products of canneries, slaughterhouses, or packing plants, condemned food products, agricultural waste products, wastes and debris from brick, concrete block, roofing shingle or tile plants, debris and wastes accumulated from land clearing, excavation, building, rebuilding, and altering of buildings, structures, roads, streets, sidewalks, or parkways, and any waste materials which, because of their volume or nature, do not lend themselves to collection and incineration commingled with ordinary garbage and trash, or which, because of their nature or surrounding circumstances, should be, for reasons of safety and health, disposed of more often than the city collection service schedule provided for in this chapter. 
Mobile container means a garbage and waste container which is flyproof, ratproof, and leakproof, and which shall be fitted with covers. The container shall be mounted on four wheels or metal slides and be capable of fitting hydraulic attachments for unloading. 
Noncombustible refuse means refuse materials that are unburnable at ordinary incinerator temperatures (800 degrees to 1,800 degrees Fahrenheit) such as metals, mineral matter, large quantities of glass or crockery, metal furniture, auto bodies or parts, and other similar materials or refuse not usual to housekeeping or to operation of stores or offices. 
Plastic bag means a polyethylene or other heavy-duty plastic bag with securing twist-tie. 
Residential unit means any structure or shelter or any part thereof used or constructed for use as a residence for one family. 
Rubbish means refuse, accumulations of paper, excelsior, rags, or wooden or paper boxes or containers, sweepings, and all other accumulations of a nature, other than garbage, which are usual to housekeeping and to the operation of stores, offices, and other business places; also, any bottles, cans, or other containers which, due to their ability to retain water, may serve as breeding places for mosquitoes or other water-breeding insects. Such term shall not include noncombustible refuse, as defined in this section. 
Service unit means four sleeping rooms, or a fraction thereof, where no cooking privileges are provided, located in any commercial establishment. 
Trash means items or material, other than so defined as garbage in this section, of a nonperishable nature. 
Waste means garbage, rubbish, garden trash, noncombustible refuse, and industrial wastes, as defined in this section. 
(Code 1985, § 94.01; Ord. No. 90-71, § 1, 7-21-92; Ord. No. 93-01, § 1, 4-6-93; Ord. No. 2005-53, § 2, 11-15-05) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 42-2. - Garbage containers. 
(a)  No person shall leave for street side pickup any garbage unless contained in a container as that term is defined in section 42-1. No person shall leave for street side pickup any trash unless contained in a container or plastic bag as those terms are defined in section 42-1. Persons desirous of having garbage or trash picked up by collection services shall place the garbage or trash in an area designated by the collection service on the morning of the scheduled collection date. 
(b)  Each commercial establishment located in the city shall have a sufficient number of garbage cans to accommodate all garbage and waste to be removed by the city or other approved agency and each residential unit in the city shall have a minimum of one garbage can for that purpose. Collection service may be discontinued where containers have been condemned as unfit for garbage receptacles until proper containers are provided, and the owners or users thereof may be subject to the provisions of section 1-16. Garbage cans shall be kept tightly covered at all times, shall be capable of being closed so that water, flies, and other insects cannot enter, and shall be easily accessible to the refuse collectors on the property from which the refuse originated. All garbage which is placed therein shall be thoroughly drained of all liquid matter and well wrapped in paper before being placed in the garbage can or mobile container. 
(c)  Where an alley exists and is normally used for the collection of garbage, garbage cans shall be placed on the owner's property as near to the alley as is practicable. If no alley exists, or use of the alley is not practical by reason of the existence of physical obstacles to the placement of the garbage can or mobile container on the edge of the alley, the garbage can or mobile container shall be placed at a point to be designated by the director of the sanitation department. 
(d)  It shall be a violation of this chapter to place or cause to be placed in a garbage can or refuse container for collection any acid, explosive material, inflammable liquids, or any dangerous or highly corrosive material of any kind. 
(Code 1985, § 94.02)  
Sec. 42-3. - Transportation of waste. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to haul, convey, or cause to be hauled or conveyed any waste including discarded building material or discarded furniture upon or along public streets, roads, or alleys except when the material transported is adequately secured in such a manner as to prevent the material from falling or being blown from the transporting vehicle. It shall be a violation of this chapter for any person not holding a valid contract under this chapter to haul any garbage or rubbish within any area of the city in which waste collection service is maintained by the city. 
(Code 1985, § 94.04)  
Sec. 42-4. - Garbage collection and disposal. 
No person shall remove garbage or waste from any premises in the city or transport garbage or waste through the streets, alleys, or public ways of the city to dump, incinerate, or in any other manner dispose of garbage or waste originating within the limits of the city, or contract for or permit himself to be employed or engaged for such removal, transportation, or disposal, without first having secured a contract and approval for such services from the city council. 
(Code 1985, § 94.05(A))  
Sec. 42-5. - Duty of owner and tenant. 
(a)  Accumulations prohibited. It shall be the duty of the owner and the tenant of each lot, tract or parcel of land, residence, commercial establishment or other property within the city limits to prevent the continued excessive and unsightly accumulation of garbage, garden trash, or other types of trash, waste, rubbish, construction debris or refuse upon the property owned or occupied by the owner. Failure to comply with the provisions of this section shall constitute a violation of this chapter. 
(b)  Collection service required. It shall be the duty of the owner and the tenant of each occupied lot, residence, commercial establishment, parcel of land or other property within the city limits to obtain regular garbage and trash collection services from the city-approved collector. Failure to comply with the provisions of this section shall constitute a violation of this chapter. 
(Code 1985, § 94.06; Ord. No. 90-71, § 2, 7-21-92; Ord. No. 93-01, § 2, 4-6-93)  
Sec. 42-6. - Garden rubbish. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to place garden trash and rubbish on public or private property, except in the rear of the property and adjoining existing alleys, or if no alleys exist, then at some place on the property previously designated by the director of the sanitation department as being a place from which trash will be collected. 
(Code 1985, § 94.07)  
Sec. 42-7. - Rubbish accumulations prohibited; nuisance. 
Any person who shall suffer or permit any filth, straw, hay, excelsior, rubbish, paper, trash, dry goods, boxes, building material of an inflammable nature, building material from any building, or any other materials that are offensive to the public health, or are a menace to the public welfare, either by reason of the danger of fire or otherwise, to be or remain upon the premises of the person or upon the streets, avenues, or alleys adjoining the premises, shall be deemed guilty of keeping and maintaining a nuisance. 
(Code 1985, § 94.08)  
Sec. 42-8. - Bringing garbage, rubbish into city. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to bring or cause to be brought into the corporate limits of the city any waste materials described in subsection (b) of this section for the purpose of depositing, burning, or dumping such waste materials, or for any reason whatever not expressly approved by the city council and so expressly licensed with the purposes spelled out completely on the license. Any license issued by the city is limited to those express purposes so noted on the license. A new license must be secured upon approval of the city council for any purposes falling under sections 42-8 through 42-11 not encompassed within the terms and express wording of any previous license issued. Any license issued by the city is expressly limited to those purposes so noted on the license. Any act encompassed within sections 42-8 through 42-11 and not expressly noted on any license issued is a violation of sections 42-8 through 42-11 and is punishable as such. 
(b)  Those matters and materials encompassed under this section which are forbidden to be brought or caused to be brought into the city limits are waste materials including but not limited to trash, garbage, cuttings, compost, stumps, old boards, lumber, wood, tires, garbage, or any materials allied with or atypical of these materials. This section shall apply to any person, including any agent or employee, who shall be found violating this section within the corporate limits of the city. This section further applies to any person who shall cause others to violate or come within the purview and terms of sections 42-8 through 42-11. 
(Code 1985, § 94.09)  
Sec. 42-9. - Dumping, burning, or abandoning garbage. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit or cause to be deposited within the city limits for the purpose of dumping, burning, abandoning, storing, or filling therein, without express approval of the city, any materials known or designated as waste material, without the express consent and licensing by the city council. Any such license issued shall be expressly limited to the purposes noted on the license. For the purposes of this section, waste materials shall include but are not limited to trash, refuse, cuttings, compost, garbage, abandoned materials, stumps, old boards, wood, tires, garbage, or any other materials allied with or atypical of these materials. 
(Code 1985, § 94.10)  
Sec. 42-10. - Clean fill. 
Sections 42-8 through 42-11 expressly exempt, for the purposes of filling, only that fill known as clean fill, which under these sections means dirt, sand, brick, hard stone and other materials, but not including abandoned automobiles, which are not subject to decomposition. 
(Code 1985, § 94.11)  
Sec. 42-11. - Use of premises as dump. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to operate, use, or allow to be operated or used such person's premises so as to constitute a dump within the city limits. For the purposes of sections 42-8 through 42-11 it is not necessary that a dump indicate payment given or received by the person operating or allowing to be operated the premises in the manner of a dump. It is sufficient under these sections that the premises are in fact being used for dumping purposes. This section, as well as section 42-9, shall apply to any agent, servant, or employee of any of the landowners or persons causing the violation of sections 42-8 through 42-11. The prosecution or arrest of any agent, servant, or employee of any person allowing or causing the violation of sections 42-8 through 42-11 shall not render that person above the application of these sections but such person may be arrested or prosecuted in addition to the agent, servant, or employee. 
(Code 1985, § 94.12)  
Sec. 42-12. - Trash receptacles required at construction sites. 
(a)  The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Receptacle means a container wherein trash can be received and contained, and containing a bottom, four sides, and a top. 
Trash means rubbish, waste, or refuse as is normally found at construction sites. 
(b)  If in the opinion of the building inspector or code compliance officer a condition exists at any construction site wherein trash is not self-contained, then and in that event, the building inspector or code compliance officer, as the case may be, may by written notice to the general contractor, person or entity whose name appears on the building permit, given by mail or personal delivery, advise the person or entity that such trash must be placed in a receptacle as defined in this section. 
(c)  If, within ten days after the notice is deposited in the U.S. mail, or within seven days after the notice is personally delivered, the general contractor, person or entity whose name appears on the building permit should fail to comply with the notice, the building inspector or code compliance officer, as the case may be, shall notify the city council of such failure to comply with the terms and conditions of the notice. The general contractor, person or entity whose name appears on the building permit shall be notified in writing, by mail or personal delivery, of the fact that there has not been compliance with this section and shall at the next regular council meeting, but no sooner than ten days from the mailing of the notice, or seven days from personal delivery of the notice, appear before the council to show cause why the penalty provision, as set forth in this section, should not be invoked. 
(d)  If there is a violation of this section, the city council may revoke the building permit issued and prohibit further construction at the construction site wherein the violation exists, until this section is complied with. 
(Code 1985, § 94.13)  
Sec. 42-13. - Garbage, rubbish, and trash prohibited in Samari Lake. 
(a)  The placing, keeping, maintaining, or storing on or in Samari Lake of garbage, garden trash, industrial waste, rubbish, abandoned boats or boat parts, and abandoned vehicles or vehicle parts is prohibited. 
(b)  If there is found on or in Samari Lake garbage, garden trash, industrial waste, rubbish, abandoned boats or boat parts, or abandoned vehicles or vehicle parts, the owner of that portion of Samari Lake wherein the garbage, garden trash, industrial waste, rubbish, abandoned boats or boat parts, or abandoned vehicles or vehicle parts are found shall be given notice of the existence of the condition by registered mail addressed to the owner or owners as their names and addresses appear upon the city tax roll, or at the option of the city may be personally given notice. The notice shall specifically set forth the nature of the condition as it exists, a request for removing or abating the condition within a period of 20 days from the date of the notice to remove the condition, and a statement that if in fact the condition is not abated or removed within 20 days, the city will proceed to remedy the condition, and that if the city does in fact undertake to remedy and abate the condition, that the cost of the work, including all administrative costs and other expenses related to abating or remedying the condition, constitutes a lien on the property if not otherwise paid within 30 days after mailing of a notice setting forth the amount due. 
(Code 1985, § 94.14)  
Sec. 42-14. - Scavenging of recyclable materials; theft of recycling containers. 
(a)  In accordance with the state recycling mandates, the city has established a curbside recycling program for certain areas of the city, in compliance with the 1988 Florida Solid Waste Management and Recycling Statute. The purpose of this section is to encourage recycling activities and to promote the development of a comprehensive recycling program within the city. 
(b)  From the time of placement of recyclable materials for collection, such materials shall become the property of the city or its authorized agents. No person shall be permitted to collect or pick up, or cause to be collected or picked up, any recyclable material which has been placed in curbside recycling containers at any residential, commercial, or industrial property, unless with the prior written consent of the city. 
(c)  No person shall be permitted to collect or pick up, or cause to be collected or picked up, any recycling container placed at any residential property, unless with the prior written consent of the city. 
(d)  This section may be enforced in accordance with F.S. ch. 162, pt. 1 (Local Government Code Enforcement Boards), or F.S. ch. 162, pt. 2 (Supplemental County or Municipal Code or Ordinance Enforcement Procedures). 
(e)  Revenues derived from funds resulting from this section shall be utilized to develop the city's recycling program. 
(f)  Any person convicted of violating the provisions of this section shall, upon conviction, be punished as provided in section 1-16. 
(Ord. No. 90-37, § 1(94.15), 4-16-91; Ord. No. 2001-09, 6-19-01)  
Sec. 42-15. - Security deposit. 
All commercial establishments that are users of solid waste (garbage and waste) and/or recycling services of the city shall be required by the city to post a security deposit with the city to secure payment for such services. The amount of the security deposit and the time and method by which it shall be paid shall be set by resolution. 
(Ord. No. 98-27, § 1, 11-17-98)  
Sec. 42-16. - Termination of water and sewer service. 
The water and sewer department is authorized to terminate the water and sewer service to any garbage and waste (solid waste) and/or recycling customer who is delinquent in payment of solid waste and/or recycling charges, in accordance with the procedure as set forth below. 
(Ord. No. 98-27, § 2, 11-17-98)  
Sec. 42-17. - Procedure for termination of water and sewer service. 
Delinquent solid waste and/or recycling customers will be provided a written statement to the effect that water service will be terminated for delinquent solid waste and recycling charges. The written notice provided such customer shall apprise such customer that, upon request, the city clerk or his designee will set a hearing before the council and notify the customer of the time and place of said hearing to consider any complaint of erroneous or incorrect billing and to review any disputed bill and to rectify any error. The decision of the council shall be final and binding. If such customer either fails for a period of ten days from receipt of notice to pay the outstanding bill, or to seek such hearing or fails to pay any sum determined to be properly due as a result of such procedures within ten days from the council's determination, such water and sewer service to such customer in arrears shall be immediately disconnected and shall not be reconnected until all past due bills for solid waste and/or recycling charges are paid in full, together with any reconnection charge. All notices shall be mailed by certified mail or posted at the address where the solid waste and/or recycling bills are sent, provided any solid waste and/or recycling customers may, by writing provided to the city clerk, designate another address for such writing. 
(Ord. No. 98-27, § 3, 11-17-98)  
Sec. 42-18. - Other remedies related to delinquencies. 
The above stated remedy for the collection of delinquencies is in addition to all other remedies provided for by the solid waste collection provider franchise agreement and the City Code. The water and sewer department may promulgate rules and regulations consistent with the intent of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 98-27, § 4, 11-17-98)  
Sec. 42-19. - Fee for collection of recyclables. 
There shall be imposed a fee of $1.50 per month for each single-family dwelling as a charge for the collection and disposing of recyclable matter. Such fee shall, at the option of the city, be added to and made a part of either the waste and trash bill or the water and sewer bill applicable to such single family dwelling. 
(Ord. No. 98-08, § 1, 2, 6-16-98)  
Chapter 46 - TAXATION AND FINANCE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference— Financial matters, art. IV. 
State Law reference— Finance and taxation, F.S. § 166.101 et seq.; adoption of budget, F.S. § 200.065. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 46-1. - Additional homestead exemption for qualifying senior citizens. 
(a)  According to section 6 Article VII of the Florida Constitution and F.S. § 196.075 any person 65 years or over who has legal or equitable title to real estate located within the city and maintains thereon his or her permanent residence which qualifies for and receives homestead exemption pursuant to section 6(f), Article VII of the Florida Constitution and whose household income does not exceed $27,030.00 shall be entitled to make application for an additional homestead equal to the assessed value of the property to an owner who has title to real estate in Florida with a just value less than $250,000.00, has maintained permanent residence on the property for not less than 25 years, is 65 or older and whose household income does not exceed the income limitation. 
(b)  Every person claiming the additional homestead exemption provided herein must file an application with the Miami-Dade Property Appraiser not later than March 1 of each year for which such exemption is claimed. Such application shall include a sworn statement of household income for all members of the household and shall be filed on a form prescribed by the Florida Department of Revenue. On or before June 1 of each such year every applicant must file supporting documentation with the county property appraiser. The documentation shall include copies of all federal income tax returns, wages and earning statements and such other documentation as required by the county property appraiser and the Florida Department of Revenue including documentation necessary to verify the income received by all of the members of the household for the prior year. 
(c)  Failure to file the application and sworn statement by March 1 or failure to file the required supporting documentation by June 1 of any given year shall constitute a waiver of the additional exemption privilege for that year. 
(d)  This additional exemption shall be available commencing with the year 2001 tax roll. 
(e)  Commencing January 1, 2002 and each January 1 thereafter, the $20,000 annual income limitation provided herein shall be adjusted annually and applicable as of January 1 of that year. The annual income limitation shall be adjusted by the percentage of change in the average cost-of-living index calendar year for the immediately prior to that year. As used herein "index" shall be the average of the monthly consumer price index figures for the stated period for the United States as a whole issued by the United States Department of Labor. 
(f)  City retains the right to conduct a periodic audit to verify compliance if the city is not satisfied with county or state verification of eligible property owners. 
(Ord. No. 2001-18, § 1, 11-6-01; Ord. No. 2012-38, § 2, 12-18-12; Ord. No. 2012-39, § 1, 12-18-12)  
Secs. 46-2—46-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - LOCAL BUSINESS TAX RECEIPTS[2] 

Footnotes:

No. 98-35, adopted Jan. 5, 1999, repealed §§ 46-32—46-50 and reenacted §§ 46-32—46-73 as herein set out. No. 90-24, adopted Aug. 28, 1990; §§ 1 and 2 of Ord. No. 92-02, adopted Sept. 28, 1992; §§ 1 and 2 of Ord. No. 90-27, adopted Nov. 27, 1990; § 1 of Ord. No. 93-17, adopted Nov. 16, 1993; § 1 of Ord. Sec. 46-31. - Levy. 
The city council does hereby levy a local business tax for the privilege of engaging in or managing any business, profession, or occupation within the city. The local business tax is levied on: 
(1)  Any person who maintains a permanent business location or branch office within the city, for the privilege of engaging in or managing any business within the city. 
(2)  Any person who maintains a permanent business location or branch office within the city, for the privilege of engaging in or managing any profession or occupation within the city. 
(3)  Any person who does not qualify under subsection (1) or subsection (2) and who transacts any business or engages in any occupation or profession in interstate commerce, if the license tax is not prohibited by section 8, article I of the United States Constitution. 
(Ord. No. 2008-06, § 3, 9-16-08)  
Sec. 46-32. - Definitions. 
[The following words, terms and phrases, as used in this article, shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them in this section, unless the context clearly indicates otherwise:] 
Accessory use means a use incidental to, and on the same lot as a principal one. 
Alley means a minor way not intended for general traffic circulation which is used primarily for vehicular service access to the back or the side of properties otherwise abutting on a street. 
Amusement arcade means a building or a part of a building in which five or more pinball machines, video games, or other similar player-operated amusement devices are maintained. 
Automobile wrecking yard (See also "junkyard") means a site at which the dismantling or wrecking of used motor vehicles or trailers, or the storage, sale, or dumping of dismantled or wrecked vehicles or their parts takes place. 
Business, profession or occupation defined as (insert definition). The aforementioned does not include the customary religious, charitable or educational activities of nonprofit religious, nonprofit charitable and nonprofit educational institutions in this state; which institutions are more particularly defined and limited as follows: 
Religious institutions shall mean churches and ecclesiastical or denominational organizations, church cemeteries or established physical places for worship in this state at which nonprofit religious services and activities are regularly conducted and carried on, and who have registered with the state and have been approved as not-for-profit organizations by the Internal Revenue Service of the United States. 
Educational institutions shall mean state tax-supported or parochial, church, and nonprofit private schools, colleges or universities conducting regular classes and courses of study required for accreditation by or membership in the Southern Association of Colleges and Secondary Schools, Department of Education or the Florida Council of Independent Schools. Nonprofit libraries, art galleries, and museums open to the public are defined as educational institutions and eligible for exemption, if in compliance with state and federal laws and regulations for not-for-profit organizations. 
Charitable institutions shall mean only nonprofit corporations operating physical facilities, registered with the state, and approved by the Internal Revenue Service, at which charitable services are provided, and a reasonable percentage of which shall be without cost to those unable to pay. 
Business district. See: Land Development Regulations. 
Chief zoning and code compliance official means a designated authority, charged with the administration and enforcement of the local business tax receipt department and this Code. He or she shall not be removed from office except for cause after full opportunity has been given to be heard on specific charges before each applicable governing authority. 
Code compliance officer means an authorized employee of the city whose duty it is to assure code compliance; See Ordinance No. 97-21. 
Concurrency is a condition where specified facilities and services have or will have the necessary capacity to the adopted level of service standards at the time of impact of the development project. 
Commercial district. See: Land development regulations. 
District means a portion of the territory of the city, exclusive of streets and other public ways, within which certain uses of land, premises, and buildings are not permitted. 
Drive-in facility means any portion of a building or structure from which business is transacted, or is capable of being transacted, directly with customers located in a motor vehicle during such business transactions. 
Garage, repair means a building designed and used for the storage, care, repair, or refinishing of motor vehicles including both minor and major mechanical overhauling, paint, and body work (see also service station). 
Home occupation. See: Land development regulations. 
Junkyard means a parcel of land or structure on which waste material or inoperative vehicles and other machinery are collected, stored, salvaged, or sold. 
Kennel means an establishment licensed to operate a facility housing dogs, cats, or other household pets and where grooming, breeding, training, or selling animals is conducted as a business. 
Land use district. See: land development regulations. 
License or valid license is a license that was properly issued for a period of time that has not yet expired, that has not been revoked, was not obtained by providing wrong/false information in the application and that in being used exclusively for the classification for which it was issued. 
New business is that for which a license is issued for the first time, whose owner or owners did not operate a business of the classification in the city prior to the issuing of such license. Change of ownership of a place of business, even if the new owner(s) did not have a previous license in Hialeah Gardens, shall not be considered a new business for the purpose of exemption of part or a total of the license fee. 
Nightclub means a commercial establishment dispensing alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises and in which dancing is permitted and includes the term "cabaret." Also bar, restaurant, coffeehouse, or similar establishment where a dance floor or entertainment is provided. 
Nonconforming building means any building that does not meet the limitations on building size and location on a lot, for the district in which such building is located. 
Nonconforming use means a lawful use of land that does not comply with the use regulations for its land use district but which complied with applicable regulations at the time the use was established. 
Owner means any person, agent, firm or corporation having a legal or equitable interest in the property, and responsibility for any violation in the property. 
Parking space for business or commercial district, see the Land Development Regulations. 
Person means any individual, firm, partnership, joint venture, syndicate, or any other group or combination acting as a unit, association, corporation, estate, trusts, business trust, trustee, executor, administrator, receiver or other fiduciary and shall include the plural as well as the singular. 
Right-of-way means a strip of land occupied or intended to be occupied by. See: Land Development Regulations. 
Sign. See: Land Development Regulations. 
Site plan means a document or group of documents, in blue or black print containing sketches, text, drawings, maps, photographs, and other material intended to present and explain certain elements of proposed development, including physical design, siting of buildings and structures, interior vehicular and pedestrian access, the provision of improvements, and the interrelationship of these elements. 
Special exception uses. See: Land Development Regulations. 
Variance means a relaxation of the technical regulations of the code where such action will not be contrary to the public interest and where, owing to conditions peculiar to the property and not the result of actions or the situation of the applicant, a literal enforcement of this code would result in unnecessary and undue hardship. 
Establishment or expansion of a use otherwise prohibited shall not be allowed by variance, nor shall a variance be granted because of the presence of nonconformities in the district or uses in an adjoining district. 
(Ord. No. 98-35, § 1(113.01), 1-5-99; Ord. No. 2008-06, § 3, 9-16-08)  
Sec. 46-33. - License required. 
(a)  No person shall engage in or manage any business, profession, service or occupation, for which a local business tax receipt and fee are required in this Code in the City of Hialeah Gardens, without first obtaining a certificate of use and such license and paying the required fee except for those exempt businesses, professions and occupations as defined in section 46-34. 
(b)  Separate licenses will be required for each place of business or by each separate classification of business at the same location. 
(c)  All persons must comply with the fee schedule by paying the certificate of use prior to being issued a local business tax receipt. If a certificate of use has been issued by the zoning department, the applicant must pay an annual renewal fee for zoning inspection. 
(Ord. No. 98-35, § 1(113.02), 1-5-99; Ord. No. 2008-06, § 3, 9-16-08)  
Sec. 46-34. - Application. 
(a)  The applicant will file an application for certificate of use using the form prescribed by the local business tax receipt department and such license will not be issued unless all applicable required information, review and approvals are provided with the application. In cases in which the approval of a governing agency is required the applicant shall also file proof of approval from such governing agency. 
(b)  Every person engaged in or managing any business, profession, service or occupation in the City of Hialeah Gardens referred to in this article, is required to procure a city license as herein provided and shall, on or before October 1 of each year, and always before engaging in any business, profession, service or occupation, file an application on the prescribed form with the local business tax receipt department, signed by an officer, partner, or owner of the business. 
(c)  All licenses shall be applied for and issued in the real name of the applicant. In cases where the applicant has qualified under Florida laws for the use of a "fictitious name," the license, if issued, shall show the real name as well as the "fictitious" name of the applicant. In such application, the applicant shall set forth the name of the owner; if a firm, the names of all members of the firm; if a corporation, the names, addresses and telephone numbers of all officers of the corporation; the location of the business, the full nature of the business, additional information or approvals as prescribed in the application and the certificate of use; where the fee is based on inventory, number of vehicles, seats, employees, gasoline pumps, apartments units, trailers, square footage or any other unit used as base for the calculation of the license or regulation established by the local business tax receipt department. 
(d)  The code compliance department will inspect the business premises to verify other information in the application such as numbers of vehicles, seats, employees, gasoline pumps, apartments units, trailers, square footage or other units used in the calculations of the license fee, declared by the applicant. 
(Ord. No. 98-35, § 1(113.03), 1-5-99; Ord. No. 2008-06, § 3, 9-16-08)  
Sec. 46-35. - Reciprocity. 
Any person who has obtained a professional certification license by or through examination by the Department of Professional Regulation, State of Florida and has obtained a Certificate of Competency in Dade County, Florida, which has requirements similar to those in the various provisions of this Code of Ordinances and other ordinances of the City of Hialeah Gardens with respect to the issuance and granting of license for the several business or occupations, may, without the formality of an examination, be granted a certificate or license by reciprocity, upon the payment of the local business tax receipt fee or charge applicable to such business or occupation. 
(Ord. No. 98-35, § 1(113.04), 1-5-99; Ord. No. 2008-06, § 3, 9-16-08)  
Sec. 46-36. - Determination of classification and applicable fee. 
In the event of disagreement between the applicant and the city on the question of proper classification of any business, occupation, profession, service for license purpose, the chief zoning and code compliance official shall decide the proper classification. 
Any person who wishes to appeal any decision of the local business tax receipt department, will have the right to appear before the city council, provided a petition is made, in writing, to the city clerk, within ten working days of the notification of the determination by the local business tax receipt department. 
The provisions of this section, does not include matters pertaining to code compliance or to notice of violations, civil citations or code compliance board orders. 
(Ord. No. 98-35, § 1(113.05), 1-5-99; Ord. No. 2008-06, § 3, 9-16-08)  
Sec. 46-37. - Term and duration fractions and transfer of the local business tax receipt. 
(a)  Except as otherwise provided, licenses shall expire on the thirtieth day of September. Those licenses not renewed by October first, shall be considered delinquent and subject to a delinquency penalty of ten percent for the month of October plus an additional five percent for each month of delinquency thereafter until paid; provided that the total delinquency fee shall not exceed 25 percent of the yearly local business tax receipt fee for the delinquent establishment. 
(b)  When a person applies after receiving a civil citation by a City of Hialeah Gardens Code compliance officer for opening a business without first obtaining a local business tax receipt, the code compliance department is hereby authorized to charge an administrative fee of $250.00 to any individual or entity that fails to comply with any provisions of this article. The fee of $250.00 will be additional to the 25 percent of delinquency fee. 
(c)  No license shall be issued for more than one year. 
(d)  All licenses provided for herein, shall be issued for and apply to only one place of business in the City of Hialeah Gardens. 
(Ord. No. 98-35, § 1(113.06), 1-5-99; Ord. No. 2008-06, § 3, 9-16-08) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2008-06, § 3, adopted Sept. 16, 2008, amended § 46-37 as herein set out. Former § 46-37 pertained to term and duration fractions and transfer of the occupational license. See the Code Comparative Table for complete derivation.  
Sec. 46-38. - License for fractional part of the year. 
Unless otherwise provided, new licenses obtained between November first and September thirtieth, will pay one-twelfth of the yearly fee for every month between the month of issue and September inclusive of both the months in which the license is issued and the month of September. Except that when new licenses are issued between September first and September thirtieth, applicants are required to pay for the September fraction of that year's license and the full fee of the license for the license year to begin the following October first. When a person applies after receiving a civil citation for opening a business without first obtaining a local business tax receipt, no fractional fee license will be issued, regardless of the opening date. A full year's fee plus penalties will be required. New application between May first and September first will pay half of the yearly fee. 
(Ord. No. 98-35, § 1(113.07), 1-5-99; Ord. No. 2008-06, § 3, 9-16-08)  
Sec. 46-39. - Transfer of location, ownership or change of name. 
(a)  All business licenses may be transferred to a new owner when there is a bona fide sale of the business, upon payment of transfer fee of $25.00 provided such original license has not been revoked or invalidated by actions of the previous owners or decision of the Hialeah Gardens City Council, Miami-Dade County or the State of Florida, except in cases prohibited by ordinance. 
(b)  Upon the written request and presentation to the local business tax receipt department, the original license and evidence of sale (such as, but not limited to, bill of sale, warranty deed and others.) Any license may be transferred from one location to another location in the same land use district of the City of Hialeah Gardens by the same licensee upon payment of transfer fee of $25.00. 
(c)  Licenses issued may be transferred subject, to the following conditions: 
(1)  The seller of the business shall present the license to the local business tax receipt department with the endorsement on the reverse side thereof, assigning all right, title, and interest to the purchaser; 
(2)  The purchaser shall file an application for a license, and shall qualify in all respects as provided by law, and by the provisions of this article and ordinances of the City of Hialeah Gardens as an applicant for a license, as if he had applied for the license in the first instance; 
(3)  A fee shall be paid to the City of Hialeah Gardens in connection with the transfer, amounting to ten percent of the amount that would have been required as a license tax had the purchaser, independent of the transfer, commenced business on the date of the transfer. In those cases where a special investigation of the transferee is required, a minimum fee of $25.00 shall be paid in addition to the transfer fee; 
(4)  Where the licensee has been exempted from payment of all or any part of the license tax therefor, the license shall not be transferable under this section; 
(5)  In the case of alcoholic beverage licenses, it shall require the approval of the chief zoning and code compliance officer and the Hialeah Gardens City Council. 
(Ord. No. 98-35, § 1(113.08), 1-5-99; Ord. No. 2001-09, 6-19-01; Ord. No. 2008-06, § 3, 9-16-08)  
Sec. 46-40. - Posting of license. 
(a)  Every license shall be posted in a conspicuous place in the place of business for which it is issued. The holder of any license shall exhibit it to the City of Hialeah Gardens Code Compliance Officer, county inspector, state inspector or any law enforcement officer upon being requested to do so by any of them. 
(b)  Failure to comply with the posting of the license shall be punishable with a payment of a fine of $50.00 and shall not excuse any further failure to comply with the provisions of this section or any amendment thereto. 
(Ord. No. 98-35, § 1(113.09), 1-5-99; Ord. No. 2001-09, 6-19-01)  
Sec. 46-41. - Multiple licenses at one location. 
(a)  When activities are carried out at the same location that are of a different classification, not necessary to the operation of the business for which a license was issued, a license is required for each business even if conducted under a single ownership. 
(b)  Every person operating what is commonly known as a "sublease" in any store shall pay a license fee for the operation of each business so leased according to the proper classification of the business or occupation as set forth therein. 
(c)  When several owners conduct business at the same location, or operate what is commonly known as a "sublease" in store, business must obtain a certificate of use from zoning. 
(Ord. No. 98-35, § 1(113.10), 1-5-99)  
Sec. 46-42. - Termination on notice of bankruptcy. 
When any person engaged in mercantile or other business in the City of Hialeah Gardens shall make an assignment for the benefit of creditors, or when that person is adjudicated a voluntary or an involuntary bankruptcy or declared insolvent, any license theretofore issued authorizing the person to do business in the city, shall immediately be terminated and, upon the assignment for the benefit of creditors or upon the adjudication in bankruptcy, immediately become null and void. 
(Ord. No. 98-35, § 1(113.11), 1-5-99)  
Sec. 46-43. - Suspension and revocation of local business tax receipt. 
The city council shall either revoke or temporarily suspend the license of any person when it is, determined by the city that: 
(1)  The licensee misrepresented or failed to disclose material information required by this article to be included in the license application form or presented upon request of the license department. 
(2)  The licensee, as part of the licensee's business activity within the city, is engaged in conduct, which is an actual threat to the public health, welfare or safety. 
(3)  Habitual conduct by licensee, his employee or patrons has occurred at the licensee's premises, which violates city, county, state or federal law. Habitual conduct is understood as frequent need for police, code compliance departments of the City of Hialeah Gardens and Metro-Dade Fire to act at the premises because of such conduct. Frequent is deemed to be more than three times a year. 
(4)  The license issued by the city depended upon the licensee's compliance with specific provisions of federal, state, county law or city ordinance or resolution and the licensee has violated such specific provisions of law. 
(5)  The licensee has violated any provision of this article and has failed or refused to cease or correct the violation after notification thereof. 
(Ord. No. 98-35, § 1(113.12), 1-5-99; Ord. No. 2001-09, 6-19-01; Ord. No. 2008-06, § 3, 9-16-08) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2008-06, § 3, adopted Sept. 16, 2008, amended § 46-43 as herein set out. Former § 46-43 pertained to suspension and revocation of occupation licenses. See the Code Comparative Table for complete derivation.  
Sec. 46-44. - Standards/rule-making authority/penalties. 
A suspension not exceeding six months may be imposed in cases where the licensee's violation is shown to be inadvertent and can be promptly corrected by the licensee; a revocation of the license shall be imposed in all other cases. The procedures for insuring the closing of an establishment whose license is revoked, will be in the following terms described as follows: 
The chief zoning and code compliance official will issue a "cease and desist" order allowing reasonable time, but not less than five working days for compliance, after which, the city will initiate legal proceedings to insure the closing of the place of business and/or arrest of violators if continued to operate without a valid license. These actions may include impounding of vehicles, equipment, and other property as well as placing liens to insure the recovery of fees, penalties, fines and legal costs. 
Any person, firm or corporation convicted of violating the provisions of this article shall be punished by a fine, not exceeding $500.00 per day for a first time violation or $500.00 dollars per day as a result of a repeat violation. 
(Ord. No. 98-35, § 1(113.13), 1-5-99; Ord. No. 2001-09, 6-19-01) 
State Law reference— Delinquent penalties, F.S. § 205.053.  
Sec. 46-45. - Hearing when licensee or permittee fails to comply with notice. 
If a licensee or permittee fails to comply with any notice issued, an order in writing to the licensee will be sent by certified mail, notifying the licensee to appear before an administrative officer as specified in Ordinance No. 97-21 at a time to be fixed in such order, which date shall be not less than five days after service thereof. In the event a licensee fails to comply with a lawful order of the city, code compliance master may as per Ordinance No. 97-21, order the closing of the offending business and enforce this order by action of the police department. 
(Ord. No. 98-35, § 1(113.14), 1-5-99; Ord. No. 2001-09, 6-19-01)  
Sec. 46-46. - False statements. 
Any license obtained under the provisions of this article upon a misrepresentation of a material fact shall be deemed null and void and the licensee, who has thereafter engaged in any business under such license, shall be subject to prosecution for conducting business without a valid local business tax receipt, to the same effect and degree as though such license had never been issued. 
(Ord. No. 98-35, § 1(113.15), 1-5-99; Ord. No. 2008-06, § 3, 9-16-08)  
Sec. 46-47. - Replacing lost or destroyed licenses. 
For the purpose of replacing any mutilated, destroyed, or lost Hialeah Gardens local business tax receipt, certificate of use, decal or receipt relating to any local business tax receipt granted by the city. The chief zoning and code compliance official is hereby authorized and empowered to cause to be executed and delivered an appropriate duplicate license certificate or receipt, upon the submission of evidence satisfaction the chief zoning and code compliance official that the original certificate or receipt was mutilated, destroyed or lost, and upon the holder of such mutilated, destroyed or lost license furnishing the city with indemnity satisfactory to the licenses department and upon the payment of a fee of $20.00 for each such duplicate, such duplicate, such sum being hereby declared to be a reasonable amount to reimburse the city for the expense incidental to executing and delivering each such duplicate license certificate, decal or receipt. 
(Ord. No. 98-35, § 1(113.16), 1-5-99; Ord. No. 2001-09, 6-19-01; Ord. No. 2008-06, § 3, 9-16-08)  
Sec. 46-48. - License fee a debt. 
The amount of any license tax and penalty imposed by the provisions of this article is hereby declared to be a debt due to the city. Any person carrying on any business without first having procured a license from the city to do so, shall be liable to the city for the amount of such license tax recoverable in any court of competent jurisdiction. 
(Ord. No. 98-35, § 1(113.17), 1-5-99)  
Sec. 46-49. - Roadside vendors and peddlers. 
(a)  No roadside vendor shall engage in or manage any business, without first obtaining a certificate of use and such license and paying the required fee. 
(b)  Roadside vendors who become stationary and wait for customers to approach them for an unreasonable period of time, unreasonable defined as five minutes or more, are in violation of this article. It's illegal to sell merchandise from parked vehicles or open stands along a public street or right-of-way. There is an exception for vendors who keep on the move and stop on the swale area, where are not posted "NO PARKING OR STOPPING ANY TIME" only long enough to serve one customer at the customer's request. 
(c)  Habitual violation by licensee, his employee or patrons has occurred more than two times, the code compliance officer, hereby authorized to charge an administrative fee of $50.00 to any individual or entity that fails to comply with any provisions of the section. If there has occurred a violation of this article of the ordinance the code compliance officer is hereby authorized to issue a civil citation fee of $50.00 to any individual or entity that fails to comply with any provisions of the section. 
(d)  If habitual conduct by licensee, his employees or patrons has occurred, which violates section 46-52(3) and requires frequent need for police or code compliance departments to act at the premises because of such conduct. The city council shall have grounds for suspension or revocation of the local business tax receipt. 
(Ord. No. 98-35, § 1(113.01), 1-5-99; Ord. No. 2001-09, 6-19-01; Ord. No. 2008-06, § 3, 9-16-08)  
Sec. 46-50. - Development orders and certain types of permits. 
Development orders or development activity sets forth the local business tax receipt department for the application review procedures required for obtaining a local business tax receipt of the following activities: 
(1)  Building, installing, enlarging, replacing or substantially restoring a structure, impervious surface, including long-term storage of materials; 
(2)  Erection of a permanent sign unless expressly exempted by the land development regulations pertaining to the City of Hialeah Gardens; 
(3)  Alteration of any bay on the warehouse area, increasing the minimum requirements for off-street parking established by the land development regulations pertaining to the City of Hialeah Gardens; 
(4)  Any reduction of parking requirements on existing warehouse or conflict with the loading spaces; 
(5)  In the event that any question arises concerning the application, the use, regulations, performance standards, definitions, development criteria, or any other provisions of this article, the chief zoning and code compliance official shall be responsible for interpretation and shall look to the city comprehensive plan for guidance. Responsibility for interpretation by the said official shall be limited to standards, regulations and requirements of this Code, but shall not be construed to include interpretation of any technical codes adopted by reference in this Code, nor be constructed as overriding the responsibilities given to any council, board or official named in other sections or articles of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 98-35, § 1(113.19), 1-5-99; Ord. No. 2001-09, 6-19-01; Ord. No. 2008-06, § 3, 9-16-08)  
Sec. 46-51. - Rules and regulations as to enforcement of article. 
(a)  The chief zoning and code compliance official may make such rules and regulations, not inconsistent with this article, as may be necessary or proper for the enforcement of these provisions hereof. 
(b)  Duties and responsibilities of the chief zoning and code compliance official as designated authority, charged with the administration and enforcement of the local business tax receipt and this Code, shall include, but not to be limited to: 
(1)  Reviews all local business tax receipt applications to assure that the license requirements of this article have been satisfied. 
(2)  Advise the applicant that additional federal, state, county or city may be required, and if specific federal or state permit requirements are known, require that copies of such permits be provided and maintained on file with the local business tax receipt application. 
(3)  Where interpretation is needed as to location of boundaries of the areas of special exception use, where there appears to be conflict between comprehensive plan boundary and actual field conditions the chief zoning and code compliance official shall make the necessary interpretation. 
(4)  All records pertaining to the provisions of this article shall be maintained in the office of the city clerk and shall open for public inspection. 
(Ord. No. 98-35, § 1(113.20), 1-5-99; Ord. No. 2001-09, 6-19-01; Ord. No. 2008-06, § 3, 9-16-08)  
Sec. 46-52. - Denial of license. 
An application for a local business tax receipt under this article may be denied on the following grounds: 
(1)  That the applicant has failed to disclose or misrepresented information required in the application; 
(2)  That the applicant currently has a license under suspension or revocation. Whenever any business license has been suspended or revoked by the City of Hialeah Gardens for any cause whatsoever, no subsequent business license for a similar business shall be issued by the city to the person, firm or corporation whose business license has been revoked or suspended; 
(3)  That the applicant desiring to engage in the business as described in the application has selected a proposed site or type of business activity which conflicts with the land use or other laws of the City of Hialeah Gardens; 
(4)  No local business tax receipt under the same classification, will be issued for a period of one year in a location where a business of the same classification was closed by revocation of license by state, county or city, unless the new owners are approved by the city council, after a background investigation of the applicant by the police department; 
(5)  Any person whose application for a license is denied by the local business tax receipt department may initiate a special exception process with the city. Requirements for special exceptions are outlined in the land development regulations; 
(6)  Any person, firm or corporation whom is found to have issued a payment via a check yet whose check is categorized by the banking authority as to not have sufficient funds shall have the city's local business tax receipt revoked and in addition shall be assessed a delinquency fee of $25.00. 
(Ord. No. 98-35, § 1(113.21), 1-5-99; Ord. No. 2008-06, § 3, 9-16-08)  
Sec. 46-53. - Exemptions. 
Exemption from the payment of the local business tax set forth herein shall be allowed in those cases provided for in this article, and in the following cases as provided for by Florida Statutes: 
(1)  Disabled veterans, as defined by Florida Statutes, and the unmarried spouse of the deceased disabled veteran of any war in which the United States Armed Forces participated, exempted up to $50.00 annually. 
(2)  Persons with a confirmed disability or physical impairment not capable of manual labor, widows with minor dependents, and persons 65 years of age or older, who meet the requirements of the Florida Statutes. 
(3)  Charitable, religious, fraternal, civil, and service organizations who are chartered as nonprofit organizations by the State of Florida, and who have a valid federal tax exemption number, may upon approval of their request on their application, be exempt from a fee for their city local business tax receipt. This section shall not apply to the certificate of use, licensing and sale of alcoholic beverage. 
(Ord. No. 98-35, § 1(113.22), 1-5-99; Ord. No. 2008-06, § 3, 9-16-08)  
Sec. 46-54. - Bills or notice declared unnecessary. 
(a)  All license renewals are due on October first of each year. Therefore, it is hereby declared to be unnecessary for the city to send out bills or notices to persons engaged in business in the City of Hialeah Gardens. 
(b)  It is unnecessary for the City of Hialeah Gardens Local Business Tax Department to call in advance for appointment to new or existing business in the city with respect to any inspection. 
(Ord. No. 98-35, § 1(113.23), 1-5-99; Ord. No. 2008-06, § 3, 9-16-08)  
Sec. 46-55. - Home occupations and professional offices. 
A home occupation or professional office shall be allowed in bona fide dwelling unit, subject to the requirements on section 78-310 and section 78-131(1) through (5) of the land development regulations. 
(Ord. No. 98-35, § 1(113.24), 1-5-99)  
Sec. 46-56. - Investigations and referrals. 
The chief zoning and code compliance official or his designee shall be empowered to investigate alleged violations of this article. In the event the city finds that probable cause exists to believe that a violation has occurred, he shall issue a civil citation to the violator. 
Any person who engages in a course of business activity consisting of repeated or egregious, unfair or deceptive trade practice(s) shall have his local business tax receipt revoked by the city in addition to any other criminal or civil penalties authorized by this article. 
(Ord. No. 98-35, § 1(113.25), 1-5-99; Ord. No. 2001-09, 6-19-01; Ord. No. 2008-06, § 3, 9-16-08)  
Sec. 46-57. - Construction of article. 
Neither the fact of the adoption of this article nor the fact of its superseding or repealing any portion of any other ordinance of the City of Hialeah Gardens, shall in anyway be construed to affect or waive prosecution for violation of any other ordinances which may have been consummated prior to the effective date hereof, nor shall they be construed as a waiver of any license or of any penal provision applicable to any such violation; nor shall they be construed to affect the validity of any portion of the cash deposit required by any ordinance to be posted, filed or deposited and all rights and obligations hereto appertaining shall continue in full force and effect. 
(Ord. No. 98-35, § 1(113.26), 1-5-99)  
Sec. 46-58. - Regulatory provisions remain in effect. 
Unless otherwise herein specifically excepted, changed, or differentiated, all qualifying or regulatory provisions of this Code or other ordinances of the city applicable to or affecting any of the business operations, occupations or classifications covered by this article shall be and remain in full force and effect. 
(Ord. No. 98-35, § 1(113.27), 1-5-99)  
Sec. 46-59. - Reinspection fees. 
When extra inspection trips are necessary due to wrong information being given, prior rejection of work due to faulty construction, occupancy not being ready for inspection at the time specified, required corrections not being made or completed at time specified, a fee of $25.00 for each reinspection shall be charged to the application for local business tax receipt. 
(Ord. No. 98-35, § 1(113.31), 1-5-99; Ord. No. 2008-06, § 3, 9-16-08)  
Sec. 46-60. - Schedule of local business taxes. 
The amount of local business tax to be paid by each classification of business or occupation shall be as set forth in the Schedule of Local Business Taxes which shall be maintained by the city clerk and available for review during normal business hours at the office of the city clerk. These taxes shall be computed and charged annually unless otherwise specified. Regulatory requirements applicable to specific business activities are as listed in the schedule as well as the amount of the tax. 
Schedule of Local Business Tax: 
Additional to the basic local business tax. 
This schedule sets forth the annual business tax charge. In addition to the basic local business tax for any business, charges will be added as they apply according to the following: Employees, warehouse space and inventory. 
Inventory, as used in and for purposes of this section, shall not include the value of personal or business property of the business, such as fixtures, furniture, machinery, and equipment regularly used in the operation of business and which are not offered for sale as part of the normal business activity of the business being licensed under this section. 
*The local business tax section will require documentation (audits, copies of report to federal, state and local government, affidavits or any other documents needed to verify the amount of inventory reported). Inventory changes must be reported every year at renewal time by the business. Failure to do so will be a violation of this Code. There will be no local business tax for vehicles needed for delivery of goods provided they are used exclusively for products sold by the business. A retail local business tax will be required if retail sales are part of the operation of the business (i.e., outlet store).

Editor's note— Ord. No. 2008-06, § 2(1)—(3)(Att. A), adopted Sept. 16, 2008, deleted former § 46-60, and enacted a new § 46-60 as set out herein. The former § 46-60 pertained to schedule of fees. See the Code Comparative Table for complete derivation.  
Sec. 46-61. - Alcoholic beverages license. 
Any new application, location or owner transfer for alcoholic beverage license will not be issued without city council approval additionally: 
(1)  The applicant will file an application for State of Florida Department of Alcohol and Tobacco and with the chief zoning and code compliance official for zoning review and approval. 
(2)  The applicant shall not appear before city council, unless all applicable required information (according to chapter 10), review and approvals is provided with the application. 
(3)  Any restrictions with the approval of the alcohol beverage license by the city council, shall be part of the application to the state. 
(4)  It shall be illegal for a restaurant or cafeteria to sell alcoholic beverages without the serving of a full-course meal. The chief zoning and code compliance official will issue a "cease and desist" order. 
(Ord. No. 98-35, § 1(113.41), 1-5-99)  
Sec. 46-62. - Sexually oriented business. 
For zoning regulating regulations pertaining to sexually oriented businesses, see Ordinance No. 90-09 [sections 18-87 et seq. of this Code]. 
(Ord. No. 98-35, § 1(113.42), 1-5-99)  
Sec. 46-63. - North American Industry Classification System (NAICS). 
(a)  For the purpose of classifying all occupations and economic activities in the newly annexed area of the city (see Ch. 78, Art. IV, Div. 2 of this Code), the city hereby adopts the North American Industry Classification System (NAICS) as issued by the internal revenue service and will, from time to time update and clarify definitions of economic activities, as it may become necessary, by ordinance of the city council. The NAICS manual will be used for definitions. 
(b)  The amount of license fees due and to be paid by the different classifications of licenses shall be as set forth in section 46-60, Schedule of Fees. Such fees shall be due and paid annually unless otherwise specified. The schedule follows the order and numerical sequences of the North American Industry Classification System (NAICS). Regulatory requirements for specific business activities are listed in the schedule as well as the fees. 
(Ord. No. 2005-18, §§ 1, 2, 5-3-05)  
Secs. 46-64—46-75. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - INSURANCE PREMIUM TAXES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference— Insurance premium tax authorized, F.S. § 185.08. 
 
Sec. 46-76. - Excise tax on insurers. 
There is hereby assessed, imposed, and levied on every insurance company, corporation, or other insurer now engaged in or carrying on, or which shall hereafter engage in or carry on, the business of insuring with respect to casualty risks, as shown by the records of the insurance commissioner of the state, an excise or license tax in addition to any license or excise tax levied by the city which shall be in the amount of 0.85 percent of the gross amount of receipts of premiums from policyholders on all premiums collected on casualty insurance policies within the corporate limits of the city. The license or excise tax so levied shall be due and payable annually on March 1 of each year. In the case of multiple peril policies with a single premium for both property and casualty coverage in such policies, 30 percent of such premium shall be used as the basis for the 0.85 percent tax. 
(Code 1985, § 35.03; Ord. No. 90-34, § 1, 4-2-91)  
Secs. 46-77—46-105. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - PURCHASING PROCEDURES[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference— Consultants competitive negotiations, F.S. § 287.055. 
 
Sec. 46-106. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Contractual services means and includes all utility services, cleaning and maintenance services, insurance, leases of property and the rental, repair, or maintenance of equipment, machinery and other city-owned property in excess of $10,000.00. The term shall exclude such professional services as are controlled under the Competitive Consultants Negotiation Act (F.S. § 287.05) and audit services rendered by accountants under F.S. § 473.317. 
Supplies means and includes all supplies, materials, and equipment having a value of $10,000.00 or more. 
Using agency means any department, agency, board (including the autonomous pension board established pursuant to F.S. ch. 185), or other units of the city government using supplies or procuring contractual services, as provided for in this article. 
(Code 1985, § 35.12; Ord. No. 99-17, § 1, 8-17-99) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 46-107. - Applicability. 
This article shall be applicable to all purchases by the city for goods and materials or services excluding, however, the following: 
(1)  Professional services. 
(2)  Goods, materials, or services obtained from or through the federal government, the state, the county, or other municipalities. 
(3)  Goods, materials, and services, excluding contracts for construction, which do not exceed $2,000.00. 
(4)  Contracts for any type of construction the sum of which does not exceed $4,000.00. 
(Code 1985, § 35.10)  
Sec. 46-108. - Responsibility of officials. 
(a)  The mayor, or such employee of the city whom he may designate, shall be the person responsible for implementing the provisions of this article. 
(b)  Except as provided under the provisions of this article, it shall be unlawful for any city officer, employee, or agent of the city to order the purchase of any supplies or make any contract, and any attempt to do so shall not be binding upon the city. 
(c)  The mayor shall, when possible and practical, do the following: 
(1)  Classify all supplies used by the various departments of city government. 
(2)  Prepare and adopt written specifications of all standard supplies. 
(3)  Prepare written specifications for all contractual services required by the city. 
(Code 1985, § 35.11)  
Sec. 46-109. - Specifications for bids.
