Specifications for bids shall be issued for all goods, materials, or services subject to this article and shall include but not be limited to the following: 
(1)  Instructions and information to bidders concerning the bid submission requirements, including the time and date set for receipt of bids, the address of the office to which bids are to be delivered, the maximum time for bid acceptance by the city, the right of the city to reject all offers of bids and any other special information. 
(2)  The purchase description, qualification factors, delivery or performance schedule, and such inspection and acceptance requirements as are not included in the purchase description. 
(3)  The contract terms and conditions including warranty and bonding or other security requirements as applicable. 
(4)  The date, time, and place at which any prebid conference may be held and whether attendance at such conference is a condition for bidding. 
(5)  The place where any documents incorporated by reference may be obtained. 
(Code 1985, § 35.13)  
Sec. 46-110. - Public notice inviting bids. 
(a)  Notice inviting bids shall be published at least once in a newspaper of general circulation in the city a reasonable time prior to bid opening but, in any event, at least 15 calendar days shall intervene between the last date of publication and the final date for submitting bids, except if, by resolution, the council desires to shorten the period of time. The notice shall state the general description of the goods and services to be purchased, the place where a copy of the specification for the bids may be obtained and the time and place for the opening of bids. In addition, bids may be solicited from all responsible, prospective suppliers by sending such bidders copies of the notice to acquaint them with the proposed purchase. 
(b)  The city clerk shall maintain a list of vendors or contractors who wish to bid on city business and shall submit to them notice of the invitation to bid for supplies or services in which they have expressed an interest. 
(Code 1985, § 35.14)  
Sec. 46-111. - Bid deposits. 
The mayor may require, when he deems it to be expedient, bid deposits, as prescribed in the specifications and the invitation to bid. Unsuccessful bidders shall be entitled to the return of such deposit. Successful bidders shall forfeit such deposit or bid bond if they fail to enter into the contract when it is awarded. 
(Code 1985, § 35.15)  
Sec. 46-112. - Bid openings. 
(a)  All bids shall be submitted to the city clerk within the time provided in the invitation to bid and shall be clearly designated as a sealed bid. The clerk shall retain custody of such bids and ensure that they remain sealed until they are to be opened by the city council. The amount of each bid and other relevant information as may be deemed desirable together with the name of each bidder shall be open to public inspection. 
(b)  All bids are to be opened before a meeting of the city council at a time and place as announced in the invitation to bid. Such meeting shall be held in accordance with F.S. § 286.011. In the absence of a quorum, however, those members of the council present may convene as a committee of the whole for the exclusive purpose of opening and tabulating the bids. 
(Code 1985, § 35.16)  
Sec. 46-113. - Qualified bidders list. 
Bidders may prequalify with the city by completing the form which is on file in the city clerk's office and made a part of this article by reference. Bidders who are not prequalified may be rejected if staff or the council, in its discretion, determine that such bidder is not qualified to perform the work. 
(Code 1985, § 35.17; Ord. No. 95-01, § 1, 5-2-95; Ord. No. 99-17, § 2, 8-17-99)  
Sec. 46-114. - Bid acceptance and evaluations. 
(a)  Bids shall be evaluated based on the requirements set forth in the invitation for bids, which may include criteria to determine acceptability such as inspection, quality, workmanship, delivery, and suitability for a particular purpose. No criteria may be used in bid evaluation which were not set forth in the invitation for bids except information contained in the prequalification form referred to in section 46-113. The results of the evaluation and tabulation of bid prices shall be announced at a public hearing within a reasonable time after the bid opening. 
(b)  The city council may request the mayor to make his recommendations regarding the award of the contract and advise the council regarding the results of the prebid qualification conference. After opening the bids, the council may refer the bids to the mayor and his staff for evaluation and recommendation at a later meeting of the council. 
(Code 1985, § 35.18)  
Sec. 46-115. - Award of contract. 
(a)  Any contracts awarded by the city shall be awarded with reasonable promptness by written notice to the lowest qualified, responsible, and responsive bidder. The decision of the city council shall be final. All contracts shall be approved as to form and correctness by the city attorney and a copy thereof shall be filed with the city clerk. 
(b)  In determining the lowest responsible bidder, in addition to price, the city council may consider: 
(1)  The ability, capacity, and skill of the bidder to perform the contract or provide the service required; 
(2)  Whether the bidder can perform the contract or provide the service promptly, or within the time specified, without delay or interference; 
(3)  The character, integrity, reputation, judgment, experience, and efficiency of the bidder; 
(4)  The quality of performance of previous contracts or services; 
(5)  The previous and existing compliance by the bidder with laws and ordinances relating to the contract or service; 
(6)  The sufficiency of the financial resources and ability of the bidder to perform the contract or provide the service; 
(7)  The quality, availability, and adaptability of the supplies, or contractual services, to the particular use required; 
(8)  The ability of the bidder to provide future maintenance and service for the use of the subject of the contract; 
(9)  The number or scope of conditions attached to the bid. 
(c)  When the award of a bid is not given to the lowest bidder, the city council shall incorporate into the motion or resolution awarding the contract a full and complete statement of the reasons for making the award to other than the low bidder. 
(Code 1985, § 35.19)  
Sec. 46-116. - Rejection of bidders; waiver. 
(a)  Notwithstanding anything to the contrary contained in this article, the city council may reject all bids. The council shall have the right to waive informalities and irregularities in the bid or prequalification form in making any award. 
(b)  Waiver of bid procedure. The city council is authorized to waive requirements of the bid procedures set forth in this article by a four-fifths vote. 
(c)  Only the city council shall have the power to reject bids and to award contracts, by no less than three affirmative votes. The council may, either before or after the bids are opened, reject any or all bids, including parts of all bids for any one or more supplies or contractual services included in the proposal, when the public interest will be served thereby. 
(Code 1985, § 35.20)  
Sec. 46-117. - Prequalifications. 
(a)  The condition of prequalification of bidders may be met by any bidder who has completed the prequalification form and who has delivered a copy of such completed form to the city clerk at least three days prior to the opening of bids. 
(b)  The mayor, or his designee, may require a prebid qualification conference at which all persons who are submitting bids must respond to questions regarding their qualifications and ability to provide the services or supplies under the bid. Such qualifications will include their experience in other contracts in both the public and private sectors. 
(Code 1985, § 35.21)  
Sec. 46-118. - No subdivision of purchases. 
No contract or purchase shall be subdivided to avoid the requirements of this article. 
(Code 1985, § 35.22)  
Sec. 46-119. - Open market purchases. 
The mayor is authorized to make open market purchases of supplies or contractual services where the amount involved is less than $2,000.00 or $1,000.00, respectively. In addition, upon the request of the mayor and by resolution, the city council may authorize the mayor to purchase supplies or negotiate for contractual services on the open market, and upon receipt thereof, the council may authorize a contract therefor. 
(Code 1985, § 35.23)  
Sec. 46-120. - Sale of surplus property. 
The sale of surplus property may be authorized by the city council upon recommendation of the mayor. Such sale shall be by sealed bid as provided in this article or may be by public auction. 
(Code 1985, § 35.24)  
Sec. 46-121. - State, county or other governmental agency bids or contracts. 
Whenever advantageous to the city, the city may utilize bids that have been awarded or under contract by the state, county or other governmental agencies. If the city utilizes state, county or other governmental agency bids competitive bidding will not be required. 
(Ord. No. 2002-54, §§ 1, 2, 11-19-02) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2002-54, §§ 1, 2, adopted Nov. 19, 2002, set out provisions intended for use as § 46-119. For purposes of clarity, and at the editor's discretion, these provisions have been included as § 46-121.  
Secs. 46-122—46-145. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - IMPACT FEES[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference— Public safety impact fee, § 78-60. 
 
Sec. 46-146. - Findings and purpose. 
(a)  Planning and census projections indicate that the population of the city will substantially increase during the next five years, resulting in new development. The increase in new development will directly and adversely impact the existing public safety service network located within the city. 
(b)  In order to maintain adequate law enforcement protection for the existing population and to accommodate the impact of the projected increase in population due to new development, the law enforcement network will have to be expanded. 
(c)  The sources of revenue presently available to the city will be inadequate to fund the entire cost of acquisition of additional public safety service and the acquisition of capital equipment required to accommodate the impact of the new development. 
(Ord. No. 90-08, § 1, 4-10-90)  
Sec. 46-147. - Rules of construction. 
(a)  The provisions of this article shall be liberally construed so as to effectively carry out its purpose in the interest of the public health, safety and welfare. 
(b)  For the purposes of administration and enforcement of this article, unless otherwise stated in this article, the following rules of construction shall apply to the text of this article: 
(1)  If there is any conflict between the text of this article and any table, summary table or illustration, the text shall control. 
(2)  The word "shall" is always mandatory and not discretionary; the word "may" is permissive. 
(3)  Words used in the present tense shall include the future; and words used in the singular number shall include the plural, and the plural the singular, unless the context clearly indicates the contrary. 
(4)  The phrase "used for" includes arranged for, designed for, maintained for, or occupied for. 
(5)  The word "person" includes an individual, a corporation, a partnership, an incorporated association, or any other similar entity. 
(6)  Unless the context clearly indicates the contrary, where a regulation involves two or more items, conditions, provisions, or events connected by the conjunction "and," "or" or "either…or," the conjunction shall be interpreted as follows: 
a.  "And" indicates that all the connected terms, conditions, provisions, or events shall apply. 
b.  "Or" indicates that the connected terms, conditions, provisions, or events may apply singly or in any combination. 
c.  "Either…or" indicates that the connected items, conditions, provisions, or events shall apply singly but not in combination. 
(7)  The word "includes" shall not limit a term to the specific example but is intended to extend its meaning to all other instances or circumstances of like kind or character. 
(8)  The word "he" means "he or she"; "his" means "his" or "hers." 
(Ord. No. 90-08, § 2, 4-10-90)  
Sec. 46-148. - Definitions. 
The definitions contained in chapters 28 and 33, Code of Metropolitan Dade County, shall apply to this article except as otherwise provided in the following definitions: 
(1)  Applicant means the person who applies for a building permit or submits a plat or waiver of plat. 
(2)  Building means any structure having a roof entirely separated from any other structure by space or by walls in which there are no communicating doors or windows or any similar opening and erected for the purpose of providing support or shelter for persons, animals, things or property of any kind. 
(3)  Building permit means an official document or certificate issued by the city building department under chapter 33 of the Code of Metropolitan Dade County, authorizing the construction, siting, or change of use of any building. For purposes of this article, the term "building permit" shall also include tie-down permits for those structures or buildings, such as mobile homes, that do not require a building permit in order to be occupied. 
(4)  Development activity, development or activity means any activity for which a building permit is required pursuant to the South Florida Building Code or city ordinance. 
(5)  Development of regional impact means any development which because of its character, magnitude or location would have a substantial impact on the health, safety or welfare of the citizens. 
(6)  Dwelling unit means a building or portion of a building designed for or the primary purpose of which is for residential occupancy, and consisting of one or more rooms which are arranged, designed or used as living quarters for one or more persons. The term also includes mobile homes, motels, hotels, roominghouses or any such units converted to condominiums, servants' quarters or congregate living facilities as that term is defined by F.S. § 400.402. 
(7)  Feepayer means a person intending to commence a proposed development for which an impact fee computation is required under this article, or a person who has paid an impact fee. 
(8)  Existing development means the lawful land use physically existing as of the effective date of the ordinance from which this article derives, and any development or additional development for which the landowner holds a valid building permit as of the effective date of this article. Existing development shall also include that maximum level of development activity for which a previous impact fee was paid under the provisions of this article. 
(9)  Impact means the effect of the new development, including additional residential and nonresidential units, on the public safety services in a given area. 
(10)  Nonresidential development means any development not providing for residential dwelling units. 
(11)  Owner means the person holding legal title to the real property. 
(12)  Person, for the purpose of this article, means individuals, partnerships, trusts, corporations, and all other legal entities authorized by state law to own and develop real property. 
(13)  Residential development means any buildings designed to be used as dwelling units. Dwelling unit may be one single-family dwelling unit or two or more dwelling units in a planned project or subdivision. 
(14)  Site means a legally described parcel of property capable of development pursuant to applicable county or city ordinances and regulations. 
(15)  Unit of development means a quantifiable increment of development activity dimensioned in terms of dwelling units or other appropriate measurements contained in the impact fee schedule. 
(Ord. No. 90-08, § 3, 4-10-90) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 46-149. - Public safety impact fee imposed. 
(a)  All development is deemed to create an impact and therefore create a demand for increased public safety service capacity. As such, the cost of new facilities should be borne by new users to the extent new uses require new facilities. Therefore, any application for a building permit for development activity within the city after the effective date of the ordinance from which this article derives shall be subject to the imposition of a public safety impact fee in the manner and amount set forth in this article. Any person who, after the effective date of this article, seeks to develop land located in the city by applying for a building permit to develop such land shall be required to pay a public safety impact fee in the manner and amount set forth in this article. 
(b)  No building permit shall be issued by the building department until payment has been received for the required impact fee. Payment shall be by cash, cashier's check or money order, payable to the city. 
(c)  Valid building permits issued prior to the effective date of this article and which have not expired or been revoked will not be subject to an impact fee. Permits which have been applied for but have not been issued prior to the effective date of this article will require payment of an impact fee. 
(d)  If a building permit encompassing feepaying development expires or is revoked prior to final inspection, the feepayer shall be entitled to a refund without interest of the impact fee which was paid as a condition for the building permit, less the five percent general administrative charge. If there is a reissuance of the permit, the feepayer shall pay the impact fee in effect at the time the new building permit is issued. If a refund is authorized but not issued before the reissuance of the building permit, the amount of the refund shall be retained by the city and the feepayer shall pay the remainder of the impact fee due for the new permit. The feepayer shall be required to submit a written request for refund to the building official or code compliance officer before a refund can be authorized. 
(Ord. No. 90-08, § 4, 4-10-90; Ord. No. 2001-09, 6-19-01)  
Sec. 46-150. - Exemptions. 
(a)  The following shall be exempt from the impact fee imposed under section 46-149: 
(1)  Governmental or public facilities are exempt from the requirement of the public safety impact fees. Such facilities are those parcels, grounds, buildings or structures owned by municipal, county, state, and federal governments, the county school board and the South Florida Water Management District and related to the operation of those entities and used for governmental purposes, including, but not limited to, governmental officers, police and fire stations, airports, seaports, parking facilities, equipment yards, sanitation facilities, water control structures, schools, parks and similar facilities in or through which general government operations are conducted. Privately owned properties or facilities leased by these governmental entities and used for general government operations and activities and private residential, commercial or industrial activities constructed or operated through lease agreements on public lands or in public facilities shall not be considered governmental or public facilities and shall be subject to this article. 
(2)  A building replacement meeting the requirements of section 104.3(D), South Florida Building Code (replacement necessitated by partial destruction), is exempt. 
(3)  Any development activity which is under a total of 200 square feet is exempt. 
(4)  The issuance of a tie-down permit on a mobile home, on which the applicable impact fee can be documented as having been paid or for which documentation can be provided to determine whether the mobile home was legally in place on the lot, parcel or space prior to the effective date of this article is exempt. 
(5)  A house move originating with this county is exempt. 
(b)  In applying for the exemptions authorized by this section, it shall be the feepayer's responsibility to furnish, as required by the building official or code compliance officer, all materials and information necessary to validate the exemption including, but not limited to, the following: 
(1)  Current opinion of title; 
(2)  Official document from affected governmental owner stating the proposed land use; 
(3)  Master plan; 
(4)  Official zoning hearings; 
(5)  Old and new construction plans; 
(6)  Official certificate of occupancy records; and 
(7)  Statements from the owner stating past and proposed land use. 
(Ord. No. 90-08, § 5, 4-10-90; Ord. No. 2001-09, 6-19-01)  
Sec. 46-151. - Fee schedule. 
The impact fee schedule to compute the amount of the impact fee to be paid is on file in the city clerk's office. The five percent general administrative charge portion of the fee is nonrefundable. 
(Ord. No. 95-12, § 2, 7-18-95)  
Sec. 46-152. - Public safety impact fee trust fund. 
The city may receive and deposit, from time to time, additional moneys and funds from other sources, including grants and donations. The public safety impact fee trust fund shall be administered by the chief of police, subject to the approval of the mayor and city council. Such funds shall be subject to audit requirements, as provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 90-08, § 7, 4-10-90)  
Secs. 46-153—46-170. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VI. - TELECOMMUNICATIONS TAX 
 
Sec. 46-171. - Levied amount. 
Pursuant to the authority and provisions of F.S. § 166.231, there is hereby levied and imposed by the city upon each and every purchase of telecommunications service as defined by F.S. § 203.012 which occur within the city and originates and terminates in this state, a telecommunications tax in the amount of seven percent. Such tax shall apply to the total amount charged for any telecommunications service provided within the city or, if the location of the telecommunications service provided cannot be determined, the total amount billed for such telecommunications service to a telephone or telephone number, a telecommunications number of device, or a customer's billing address located within the city, excluding public telephone charges collected on site, charges for any foreign exchange service or any private line service except when such services are used or sold as a substitute for any telephone company switched service or dedicated facility by which a telephone company provides a communication path, access charges, and any customer access line charges paid to a local telephone company. However, telecommunications service as defined in F.S. § 203.012(5)(b), shall be taxed only on the monthly recurring customer service charges excluding variable usage charges. 
(Ord. No. 98-12, Art. I(§ 1), 8-18-98)  
Sec. 46-172. - Seller to collect, pay over, discount for sellers. 
It shall be the duty of every seller of such telecommunications service, in acting as the tax collection medium or agency for the city as established by F.S. § 166.231, to collect from the purchaser at the time of payment for such service any tax imposed and levied pursuant to the provisions of this article. It shall be the responsibility of the seller/collector to remit all such taxes collected pursuant to the provisions of this article accompanied by a form as determined by the seller. 
(1)  For the purpose of compensating the seller, the seller shall be allowed one percent of the amount of the tax collected and due to the city in the form of a deduction from the amount collected for remittance. The deduction shall be allowed as compensation for the establishment of record keeping systems, the keeping of the records, and for the collection and remittance of the tax. 
(Ord. No. 98-12, Art. I(§ 2), 8-18-98)  
Sec. 46-173. - Sellers failing to collect, report or pay over to city. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to continue to provide any telecommunications service within the city who shall fail to collect, report and pay over to the city the taxes imposed and levied pursuant to the terms of this article. 
(1)  If such tax collections as described in section 46-171 above are not paid to the city clerk within 30 days after the first of each month after collection, they will be considered delinquent. All such taxes due from the preceding month shall be subject to interest on the unpaid amount at a rate of one percent per month, or any fraction thereof, from the due date until such time as the payment is received. 
(2)  The penalties set forth for willful noncompliance with this article will be in accordance with those imposed by F.S. § 212.15. 
(Ord. No. 98-12, Art. I(§ 3), 8-18-98)  
Sec. 46-174. - Exemption for governmental entities and churches. 
(a)  Purchases of telecommunications services by: 
(1)  The United States government, the State of Florida, and all counties, school districts, and municipalities of the state, and by public bodies exempted by law or court; 
(2)  Any other public body as defined in F.S. § 1.01; 
(3)  Any recognized church in this state if used exclusively for church purposes, and by any religious institution that possesses a consumer certificate of exemption issued under F.S. ch. 212, 
are hereby exempt from the taxes levied by this article. 
(b)  Purchases of local telephone services or other telecommunication services for use in the conduct of telecommunication service for hire or otherwise for resale, are exempted from taxation under this article. 
(Ord. No. 98-12, Art. I(§ 4), 8-18-98)  
Sec. 46-175. - Audit and remittance of taxes. 
(a)  Remittance of tax to the city by seller: Every seller is hereby required to execute and file with the finance department a return setting forth the amount of such public service tax to which the city became entitled under provisions hereof on account of amounts billed to purchasers, less uncollectibles, during the preceding fiscal month on the date returns and payments are required under F.S. ch. 212. The payment shall be made contemporaneously with the filing of the return. 
(b)  Audit: Providers of telecommunications services taxable in accordance with this chapter shall provide to the city, upon 60 days written notice of intent to audit by the city, access to all applicable records for such telecommunication services except an extension of this 60-day period shall be granted if reasonably requested by the provider. Any additional extension by the seller or the city shall be granted only upon 30 days written notice prior to the expiration of the existing extension for the requesting party except in cases of bona fide emergency or waiver of the notice requirement by the other party. The audit shall be conducted in accordance with Florida Statutes, including the determination of any underpayments and/or overpayments of tax due and the assessment of interest and penalties. Any information received by the city in connection with an audit by the city of any such providers' records is confidential and is not subject to the provisions of F.S. § 119.07(1), and in accordance with F.S. § 166.231(9)(e). No company records shall be duplicated or removed from the premises. 
(Ord. No. 98-12, Art. I(§ 5), 8-18-98)  
Sec. 46-176. - Rules and regulations authorized. 
The city clerk is hereby authorized to promulgate and establish reasonable rules and regulations for the reporting and payment of the tax imposed and levied pursuant to the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 98-12, Art. I(§ 6), 8-18-98)  
Secs. 46-177—46-190. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VII. - PUBLIC SERVICE TAX[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Cross reference— Utilities, ch. 54. 
 
Sec. 46-191. - Levied; amount. 
(a)  Pursuant to the authority and provisions of F.S. § 166.231, there is hereby levied and imposed by the city upon each purchase of electricity, water, and metered or bottled gas within the corporate limits of the city a public service tax in the amount of ten percent. Such tax shall be calculated, levied and imposed upon each separate bill or statement for purchase rendered by the seller of the taxable item to each purchaser of such service. 
(b)  Pursuant to the authority and provisions of F.S. § 166.231, there is hereby levied and imposed by the city upon each purchase of fuel oil within the corporate limits of the city a public service tax in the amount of $0.04 per gallon. 
The purchase of fuel oil by a public or private utility for use as a fuel in the generation of electricity or the purchase of fuel oil for use as an aircraft engine fuel or propellant or for use in internal-combustion engines is exempt from taxation hereunder. 
(Ord. No. 98-12, Art. II(§ 7), 8-18-98)  
Sec. 46-192. - Seller to collect, pay over, discount for sellers. 
It shall be the duty of every seller of such utility service, including the city, in acting as the tax collection medium or agency for the city as established by F.S. § 166.231, to collect from the purchaser at the time of payment for such service any tax imposed and levied pursuant to the provisions of this article. It shall be the responsibility of the seller/collector to remit all such taxes imposed and levied pursuant to the provisions of this article, whether or not such taxes were collected from the purchaser by the seller, to the city by the twentieth of the month following the month of collection. If such collections are received by the city clerk and clerk by the twentieth of the month in accordance with the provisions of this article, the seller collector will be allowed a discount equal to the lesser of one percent of the taxes collected or $1,000.00, as compensation for collecting such tax. If such tax collections do not reach the city clerk and clerk until after the twentieth of the month, the full amount of such tax imposed and levied will be due. Taxes not received 30 days after collection will be considered delinquent. All such taxes due from the preceding month shall be subject to interest on the unpaid amount at the rate of one percent per month or any fraction thereof, from the due date until such time as the payment is received. 
(Ord. No. 98-12, Art. II(§ 8), 8-18-98)  
Sec. 46-193. - Sellers failing to collect, report or pay over to city. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to continue to sell or deliver any electricity, water, or gas within the city who shall fail to collect, report and pay over to the city the taxes imposed and levied pursuant to the terms of this article. 
(Ord. No. 98-12, Art. II(§ 9), 8-18-98)  
Sec. 46-194. - Exemption for governmental entities and churches. 
The tax imposed by this article shall not apply to purchases of electricity, water, or gas by the United States government, the State of Florida and its political subdivisions, or to any recognized church for use exclusively for church purposes. 
(Ord. No. 98-12, Art. II(§ 10), 8-18-98)  
Sec. 46-195. - Audit and remittance of taxer. 
(a)  The city may at its sole discretion conduct an audit of a seller/collector at such times as it deems necessary, to determine the tax imposed and levied has been properly collected and remitted pursuant to the provision of this article. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of the seller/collector to remit all such taxes whether collected or not. The city reserves the right to bill and collect from the seller/collector for unremitted taxes as may be discovered from an audit for 24 months prior to the most recent fiscal year end. 
(Ord. No. 98-12, Art. II(§ 11), 8-18-98)  
Sec. 46-196. - Rules and regulations authorized. 
The city clerk is hereby authorized to promulgate and establish reasonable rules and regulations for the report and payment of the tax imposed and levied pursuant to the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 98-12, Art. II(§ 12), 8-18-98)  
Sec. 46-197. - Declared additional. 
The tax herein assessed and imposed shall be in addition to all other license taxes now levied by the city. 
(Ord. No. 98-12, Art. II(§ 13), 8-18-98)  
Sec. 46-198. - Payment and collection. 
The excise or license tax herein provided for shall be payable and collected in the manner provided for by F.S. ch. 175 and as otherwise provided by law and the city shall be entitled to reasonable attorneys' fees and costs for collection. 
(Ord. No. 98-12, Art. II(§ 14), 8-18-98)  
Sec. 46-199. - Information regarding telecommunications and public service tax. 
The name and address of the person to contact regarding inquiries concerning this tax is Charles Blazek, City Clerk, City of Hialeah Gardens, 10001 NW 87 Ave., Hialeah Gardens, Fl. 33016. 
(Ord. No. 98-12, Art. II(§ 15), 8-18-98)  
Secs. 46-200—46-215. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VIII. - INTERIM PROPRIETARY AND GENERAL SERVICES FEE[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 96-04, §§ 1—8, adopted June 4, 1996, established an interim proprietary and general services fee. Said ordinance did not specify manner of codification; hence, inclusion herein as Art. VIII, §§ 46-216—46-223. 
Cross reference— Buildings and building regulations, ch. 54; land use regulations, ch. 78. 
 
Sec. 46-216. - Establishment. 
A fee to be known henceforth as the "interim proprietary and general services fee" is hereby established. 
(Ord. No. 96-04, § 1, 6-4-96)  
Sec. 46-217. - Purpose. 
(a)  It is recognized that the city provides police protection, and other municipal services that escalate when a new building or home is completed. It is further recognized that the cost of municipal services that are provided, from the time that a new building or structure is completed and occupied until the improvements are reflected on the tax roll as of January 1 of the year following the date when the improvements were completed, are not compensated. 
(b)  The purpose of the interim proprietary and general services fee is to defray the cost of municipal services provided to newly-improved property prior to the imposition of ad valorem taxes on the property. The fee is neither intended as an ad valorem tax, directly or indirectly, nor is the amount of the fee related to the valuation of the property receiving municipal services. 
(Ord. No. 96-04, § 2, 6-4-96)  
Sec. 46-218. - Applicability. 
There is hereby imposed an interim proprietary and general services fee which shall apply to those properties for which a certificate of occupancy is issued, either permanent or temporary, for full or partial use of the premises. The interim proprietary and general services fee shall be payable upon the issuance of a certificate of occupancy until the ensuing January 1, or until such time as the improvements necessitating the certificate of occupancy is assessed by the Dade County Property Appraiser and extended on the tax roll. 
(Ord. No. 96-04, § 3, 6-4-96)  
Sec. 46-219. - Charges. 
For the purpose of this article, a "unit" shall be defined as a single-family residence; each dwelling unit of a townhouse, duplex or multifamily dwelling; a single tenant industrial space; a retail store or a single tenant space in an office or commercial building; or a warehouse bay, except those warehouse facilities subdivided and used primarily as leased storage units, which shall be considered one unit per structure. The term shall not include additions to units, such as additional rooms, improvements involving maintenance, pools, fences or remodeling. The fee shall be $0.03 cents per square foot per month. The fee shall be paid upon the issuance of a certificate of occupancy, either permanent or temporary. No certificate of occupancy shall be issued until such time as the interim proprietary and general services fee has been paid. 
(Ord. No. 96-04, § 4, 6-4-96)  
Sec. 46-220. - Exemption. 
The interim proprietary and general services fee shall not be imposed upon the following properties: 
(1)  Properties requiring a certificate of occupancy solely for the purpose of change of use; 
(2)  Properties used primarily for tax-exempt purposes; and 
(3)  Properties owned by governmental entities used for governmental purposes or leased to organizations that use the property primarily for tax-exempt purposes. 
(Ord. No. 96-04, § 5, 6-4-96)  
Sec. 46-221. - Revisions. 
The amount of the fee may be revised on an annual basis, with the approval of the city council, in order to reasonably cover the cost of providing municipal services to the improved properties. 
(Ord. No. 96-04, § 6, 6-4-96)  
Sec. 46-222. - Collections and deposit. 
All interim proprietary and general services fees shall be collected by the building and zoning department and shall be deposited into the general fund. 
(Ord. No. 96-04, § 7, 6-4-96)  
Sec. 46-223. - Lien provisions. 
All such fees becoming due and payable after October 1, 1996 shall constitute, and are hereby imposed as, special assessment liens against real property, and until fully paid and discharged, or barred by law, shall remain liens equal in rank and dignity with the lien of city and county ad valorem taxes and superior in rank and dignity to all other liens, encumbrances, titles, and claims in, to or against the real property containing the building, structure or dwelling unit. Such fees shall become delinquent if not paid within 60 days after the due date. All delinquent fees shall bear an interest charge of one percent per month, on any or all of the outstanding balance of such fees due, and if not fully paid with all accrued interest by the due date of the next interim proprietary and general services fee payment, will continue to accrue interest. Unpaid and delinquent fees, together with accrued interest, shall remain and constitute special assessment liens against the real property involved. Such liens may be enforced by any of the methods provided in F.S. ch. 85, alternatively, by foreclosure proceedings instituted under the provisions of F.S. ch. 173, or by other legal methods of collection and enforcement of payment thereof. The owner shall pay all costs of collections, including reasonable attorney fees, court costs, abstracting and related lien expenses incurred by the city. 
(Ord. No. 96-04, § 8, 6-4-96)  
Chapter 50 - TRAFFIC AND VEHICLES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference— Uniform traffic control law, F.S. ch. 316. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 50-1. - Certain size vehicles prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any motor vehicle, except local traffic, in excess of 6,000 pounds gross weight to be driven or travel on any road within the corporate limits of the city, which has a sign posted prohibiting this use. All signs so posted shall be erected in such a manner that they are fairly visible to any motorist about to enter the roadway. Designation of the roads upon which the aforesaid motor vehicles are prohibited shall be made in writing by the mayor to the chief of police of the city. The supervision of the erection and maintenance of the signs will be at the direction of the chief of police. Special permission for exemption from this section, on good cause shown, may be granted in writing for a specified time by the mayor or chief of police. 
(Code 1985, § 70.01)  
Sec. 50-2. - Penalty for violation of chapter. 
Any person violating any provision of this chapter or causing any provision of this chapter to be violated shall be fined as provided in section 1-16. 
(Code 1985, § 70.99)  
Secs. 50-3—50-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - STOPPING, STANDING AND PARKING OF COMMERCIAL VEHICLES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Authority to regulate, F.S. § 316.008. 
 
Sec. 50-31. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings given in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Code compliance board means the city's code compliance board, established pursuant to F.S. ch. 162, known as the Local Government Code Enforcement Boards Act. 
Code compliance department means the city's code compliance department and shall include all individuals employed by the department as code compliance officers who have been designated by the city as such and whose duty it is to enforce the land development code and ordinances enacted by the city and the provisions of the South Florida Building Code, and statutes of the state and the ordinances of the county and the city, including the city building official. 
Commercial district means any area of the city which is zoned for usage other than residential and shall include those areas zoned CM. 
Commercial vehicle means a truck, bus, trailer, semitrailer, truck tractor and semitrailer combination, recreational unit or camper primarily designed as temporary living quarters, which either has its own motor power or is mounted on or drawn by another vehicle being operated or capable of being operated on the highways of the city, and designed to be used to transport cargo or passengers in commerce. 
Highway means any public thoroughfare including streets, alleys, avenues, roads, rights-of-way and any other area which is open for vehicular travel by the general public unless otherwise excluded in this article. 
Off-street parking areas means those areas of real property including parking spaces, loading spaces, driveway areas and other areas which have been designated for the purpose of temporary parking when the keeping or parking of commercial vehicles is necessary to the operation of the business enterprise located on such property, or any other appropriate storage place or lot maintained in a location so designated for the purpose of parking. 
Operator means any person who is in actual physical control of a motor vehicle upon the highway or who is exercising control or steering a vehicle being towed by a motor vehicle. 
Overnight parking means those hours between 6:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. daily. 
Parked means the state of a vehicle being temporarily left unattended by its owner and/or operator. 
Passenger vehicle means only those vehicles designed, used or maintained primarily to transport private passengers and which are currently licensed for travel on the public highways and are capable of and equipped to be lawfully operated in such fashion under their own power. 
Person means any individual, firm, partnership, joint venture, syndicate or other group or combination acting as a unit of economic organization or activity and shall include the plural as well as the singular. 
Police department means any member of the city police department who is certified pursuant to state law and who has the authority to make arrests and to enforce the penal, criminal, traffic or highway laws of the state. 
Private property means all land and improvements and personal property not owned by the state, the county or the city and lying within the geographical boundaries of the city. 
Property owner means that person who exercises dominion and control over private property, real or personal, including, but not limited to, the legal titleholder of a commercial vehicle as defined in this section, a lessee or any person authorized to exercise or share dominion and control over private property. 
Public property means all land and improvements owned by the state, the county or the city, including, but not limited to, buildings, grounds, parks, playgrounds, streets, sidewalks, parkways, rights-of-way, easements and other similar real property lying within the geographical boundaries of the city. 
Right-of-way means the outside boundaries of a highway, whether such right-of-way has been established by usage, dedication, by the city's official right-of-way map or records or in any other fashion recognized by law. 
Weekend means and includes all hours between 7:00 p.m. on Friday and 7:00 a.m. on the following Monday. 
(Ord. No. 93-05, § 1, 2-16-93; Ord. No. 2001-09, 6-19-01) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 50-32. - Prohibited parking on public property. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to park a commercial vehicle on any public property located within the geographical boundaries of the city, or to otherwise obstruct any public street, parkway, highway, road, right-of-way or other similar public property unless otherwise permitted by this article. 
(b)  No overnight or weekend parking of commercial vehicles shall be permitted on public property during the times set forth in the definitions of weekend and overnight parking in section 50-31. Any owner and/or operator of any commercial vehicle so parked will be subject to the enforcement provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 93-05, § 2, 2-16-93)  
Sec. 50-33. - Mechanical work on commercial vehicles prohibited on public property. 
It shall be unlawful for any owner and/or operator of a commercial vehicle to park such commercial vehicle on any public property for the purpose of performing any work upon such commercial vehicle, including, but not limited to, repairs, mechanical work, maintenance or any other work similar in nature, nor any work involving the use of any types of fluids, oils, solvents or their liquid substances except under such circumstances where the repairs are of an emergency nature which have rendered the vehicle inoperable, and immediately upon completion of such emergency repairs the vehicle shall be removed from the public property and any parts or other debris utilized in conducting such emergency repairs shall be cleaned up by the owner and/or operator of the commercial vehicle or the person performing such emergency repairs thereon. Under no circumstances, however, shall any commercial vehicle so disabled be permitted to remain parked on public property overnight or over a weekend. 
(Ord. No. 93-05, § 3, 2-16-93)  
Sec. 50-34. - Permitted parking. 
(a)  This article shall not apply with regard to any commercial vehicle which is lawfully on the off-street parking area of a property owner when the parking of such commercial vehicle is necessary to the operation of the property owner's business, including employee parking, customer parking and parking for deliveries and services necessary to the operation of such business. 
(b)  All property owners and/or persons having or conducting business in the geographical boundaries of the city shall provide an off-street parking area for their customers and for any deliveries which might be required by such business and shall not use or permit to be used any public property for such purposes. 
(Ord. No. 93-05, § 4, 2-16-93)  
Sec. 50-35. - Commercial parking on private property unrelated to business. 
No commercial vehicles of three axles or more shall be permitted to be parked on any private property located within the geographical boundaries of the city unless such private property is occupied and used by a business located thereon, which business shall have a valid local business tax receipt issued by the city, shall otherwise be in compliance with all other ordinances and resolutions of the city, and shall be actively involved in the conducting of a properly and lawfully licensed business activity. No private property shall be used solely for the purpose of parking of commercial vehicles unconnected with any business or business activity being conducted on the property. No private property shall be used solely for the purpose or use as a parking lot for commercial vehicles or as an area for the performance of mechanical work on such vehicles as prohibited by section 50-33. 
(Ord. No. 93-05, § 5, 2-16-93; Ord. No. 2008-06, § 3, 9-16-09)  
Sec. 50-36. - Penalties for violation of article; procedure for enforcement. 
Any owner and/or operator parking a commercial vehicle or performing mechanical work in violation of the terms of this article shall be subjected to one of the following penalties: 
(1)  Issuance of a traffic citation by a member of the city police department for obstruction of public streets, highways and roads pursuant to the provisions of F.S. § 316.2045 and county ordinances. If the commercial vehicle constitutes a danger to vehicular traffic using the highway, it may be ordered removed to the nearest place of safety, with the cost of such removal to be borne by and be a lien against such commercial vehicle, as provided in subsection (3) of this section. 
(2)  Issuance of a notice of violation by a city building official or code compliance officer requiring the owner and/or operator to appear before the city code compliance board, which shall have jurisdiction to impose penalties pursuant to the authority granted by F.S. ch. 162. 
(3)  Towing of the commercial vehicle parked in violation of the terms of this article by the city or its authorized agents to a secure location at the expense of the owner and/or operator, who shall also be responsible for any and all costs related to the storage of such commercial vehicle. The commercial vehicle shall not be released until the cost of such towing and related expenses have been paid and any code compliance fine imposed has also been paid to the city. Upon such towing and storage, the city code compliance division shall make a reasonable effort to determine the name and current address of the owner and/or operator and to inform such owner and/or operator of the fact that the vehicle has been towed, the location where it is being stored and the amount of all fees and penalties which must be paid before the vehicle will be released. For purposes of notification, the code compliance division shall be entitled to rely upon the last-known name and address of the owner and/or operator as reflected in the official records of the state department of motor vehicles or any other official state records containing such information. 
(Ord. No. 93-05, § 6, 2-16-93; Ord. No. 93-08, § 1, 6-15-93; Ord. No. 2001-09, 6-19-01)  
Chapter 54 - UTILITIES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Solid waste, ch. 42; public service tax, § 46-191 et seq.; zoning regulations regarding utilities, § 78-175. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 54-1. - Authority of the water and sewer department. 
(a)  There is hereby established a department of water and sewer. The department shall be administered by a department head appointed in accordance with the provisions of the Charter. 
(b)  The department of water and sewer shall exercise exclusive supervisory control over the operation of the water distribution of the city, together with any extensions thereof, and the sanitary sewer system of the city, as well as the treatment and disposal of sewage thereof. 
(c)  The water and sewer department shall operate the water and sewer systems as an enterprise. All costs, expenses, capital improvements, salaries, fees and other appropriate and necessary expenditures shall be paid out of the revenues generated by the sale of water and sewer services and other moneys resulting from the operation of the water and sewer systems. The water and sewer department shall maintain a separate budget as may be approved by the city council. All revenues of the water and sewer systems shall be segregated and deposited in a fund separate and apart from the general funds of the city and used to meet the operation, maintenance, depreciation, labor, interest, bond retirement, sinking funds requirements and additions and improvements or other necessary expenses and indebtedness properly assigned to the operation of the water and sewer systems including personnel, salaries, advisory fees, engineering fees, attorney fees, and other appropriate matters. 
(d)  Contracts for water and sewer services may be entered into in the name of the city by the water and sewer department as may from time to time be authorized by the city council and approved by the mayor. 
(e)  The water and sewer department shall operate within the framework as set forth in the ordinances and resolutions of the city. 
(f)  The water and sewer department may establish rules and regulations governing efficient operation of the water distribution system and the sewer system of the city. Rules and regulations shall be submitted to the water and sewer board at public hearing after at least ten days' notice published in a newspaper of general circulation within the city. The water and sewer board may approve, delete, amend, change, or modify any proposed rule or regulation after public hearing thereon. All rules and regulations adopted by the water and sewer board shall be submitted for approval to the city council who may adopt, reject, or amend such rules and regulations by ordinance. No rules or regulations shall become effective until adopted by ordinance by the city council. 
(Code 1985, § 50.25(a)—(d), (j), (k)). 
Charter reference— Water and sewer department, art. VIII, §§ 1—4, 6, 7. 
Cross reference— Water and sewer board, § 54-1.1.  
Sec. 54-1.1. - Water and sewer advisory board. 
(a)  There is hereby established a water and sewer advisory board in accordance with the provisions of the Charter, article VIII, section 5. A member shall be an individual of outstanding reputation for integrity, responsibility and business ability. No person who is an officer or employee of the city in any other capacity shall be a member of the water and sewer board. The advisory board shall assist the city council in all matters relating to the operation and maintenance of the water and sewer systems, rates, condition of the system, efficiency of its operations, capital requirements, financing, costs and expenses and other appropriate and necessary matters as may be requested by the mayor or city council by resolution. 
(b)  The water and sewer advisory board shall meet monthly in regular meeting and in special meetings as may be requested by the mayor or city council. The board shall inquire into the management of the water and sewer systems of the city, financial requirements, rates, and all policy matters relating thereto and advise the city council and the mayor as to their findings and recommendations. 
(c)  The water and sewer board shall advise the mayor and the water and sewer department head as to all matters relating to the water and sewer systems of the city, including but not limited to capital requirements, financing, rate structure, and management of the system. The board shall advise the city council of its findings and recommendations relating thereto. In addition, the board shall recommend rules and regulations relating to the efficient operation of the water and sewer systems which shall be effective upon adoption by the city council by ordinance. 
(d)  Rates for water and sewer services shall be established in the following manner: 
(1)  The mayor or city council shall request the water and sewer board to consider the appropriateness of water and sewer rates and charges. The board shall hold a public hearing at which time it shall receive evidence relating to the need and necessity of rates and charges. The board shall permit all members of the public to request information, comment on the appropriateness of the proposed rates, and present other matters in relation thereto. 
(2)  The board shall recommend appropriate rates and charges to the city council together with such findings and recommendations that it deems appropriate. 
(3)  The city council shall hold a public hearing as to the need and necessity of the proposed rates and charges. At the public hearing the city council shall hear the recommendations of the mayor or department head and the recommendations of the water and sewer board and the comments of all interested members of the public. Thereafter the city council shall establish the rates and charges by resolution. 
(4)  All rates and charges for water and sewer services shall be sufficient to defray all costs and expenses of the water and sewer systems, including but not limited to bond issue requirements, capital improvements, salaries, expenses, maintenance, depreciation, interest payments, and other necessary expenses and indebtedness of the water and sewer systems. 
(e)  Bonds, special assessments, and other financing of water and sewer systems shall be approved by the city council. 
(Code 1985, §§ 50.25(e)—(i), 155.65.02B) 
Charter reference— Water and sewer board, art. VIII, §§ 5—7.  
Sec. 54-2. - Water and sewer department regulations adopted. 
(a)  The city council hereby adopts the rules and regulations of the city department of water and sewer, which is made a part of this chapter, and referred to as exhibit A, rules and regulations—general; exhibit B, rules and regulations—sewer service; and exhibit C, rules and regulations—water service, which are not printed in this Code, but are on file in the city clerk's office. Further, the city council hereby adopts the form agreements as set forth in exhibit D, agreement for construction of sanitary sewage facilities, and exhibit E, agreement for construction of water facilities, which are not printed in this Code, but are on file in the city clerk's office. The water and sewer board shall have the power and authority to act in accordance with the rules, regulations and agreements as incorporated in this section by reference. 
(b)  Nothing contained in this section shall in any way limit the power of the city to establish policies in accordance with the Charter applicable to the department of water and sewer, or to amend the rules, regulations and agreements adopted in this section, or to limit the powers of the water and sewer board provided by ordinance in accordance with the Charter. 
(Ord. No. 90-46, §§ 1—5, 12-20-91)  
Sec. 54-3. - Water and sewer board resolutions. 
Competent evidence, for the purpose of this section, means testimony or writings which, in the opinion of the city council, enable it to determine questions of fact presented. Such testimony evidence need not be sworn to and may contain heresay, and any writings need not be authenticated. All resolutions of the water and sewer board shall come to the city council with a presumption of correctness, and the city council shall not overrule, reverse or amend such resolutions or rules without there existing, at a hearing on the matter, competent evidence supporting the decision to overrule, reverse or amend such resolution or rule of the water and sewer board. 
(Ord. No. 90-70, §§ 1, 2, 6-16-92)  
Sec. 54-4. - County water pollution regulations adopted by reference. 
The provisions of section 24-11 of the Code of Metropolitan Dade County, pertaining to prohibitions against water pollution, are hereby adopted by reference as fully as if set out at length in this section. 
(Code 1985, § 50.20)  
Sec. 54-5. - Penalty for violation of chapter. 
(a)  Any person or business association failing to comply with the regulatory requirements or prohibitions of this chapter shall be penalized in the sum of $100.00 per day for every day of failure to comply with this chapter, except as provided in subsection (b) of this section. 
(b)  Any individual or entity who allows the conditions prohibited by section 54-72 to exist, be permitted or maintained, shall be fined in an amount not to exceed $500.00 per day for each day during which such condition exists. 
(Code 1985, § 50.99)  
Sec. 54-6. - Water and sewer service charges. 
The rates and charges for water and sewer service are not printed in the Code but are on file in the city clerk's office.  
Secs. 54-7—54-35. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - WATER[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Code compliance, § 2-211 et seq. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Secs. 54-36—54-50. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - CONNECTIONS 
 
Sec. 54-51. - Required. 
The owner of each lot or parcel of land within the city on which any building or other improvement is now located or situated, or shall hereafter be located or situated, to be used or intended for human habitation or occupancy for residential, commercial, industrial, or other use and which lies within 250 feet from any water main located in the city shall be required to connect or cause to be connected the building or improvement with the water main in such a manner as to meet the requirements of the South Florida Building Code and the Dade County Public Works Manual. The connection shall be made and done within 30 days of the completion of the water main or on completion of the construction or erection of the building or improvement. 
(Code 1985, § 50.01)  
Sec. 54-52. - City authorized to make connection. 
If any owner of any lot or parcel of land so improved within the city shall fail or refuse to connect with the water main when required to do so by the terms of section 54-51, then the city shall be authorized to make the connection and enter on the lot or parcel of land for the purpose of making the connection. 
(Code 1985, § 50.02)  
Sec. 54-53. - Recovery of costs. 
The city shall be entitled to recover the cost of making the connection provided for in section 54-52, together with reasonable penalties, interest, and attorney's fees by suit in any court of competent jurisdiction. In addition and as an alternative means of collecting the costs of making the connection, the city shall have a lien on the lot or parcel of land for the costs, penalties, interest, and attorney's fees, which shall be of equal dignity with the lien of state and county municipal taxes. The lien may be foreclosed by the city in the same manner as provided by the laws of the state for the foreclosure of mortgages on real estate. 
(Code 1985, § 50.03)  
Sec. 54-54. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - CROSS-CONNECTION CONTROL PROGRAM 
 
Sec. 54-54.1. - Scope and intent. 
Unless otherwise provided herein, this article applies to water customers of the Hialeah Gardens Water and Sewer Department, as defined herein. The purpose of this article is to implement the provisions of section 62-555.360 of the Florida Administrative Code, promulgated under authority of F.S. ch. 403, pt. VI, by the department of environmental protection, which requires public water systems to establish a cross-connection control program to detect and prevent cross-connections that create or may create an imminent and substantial danger to public health. In addition to internal isolation required by the Florida Building Code, new water customers shall provide approved backflow preventers next to the service connection for the containment of their premises. 
(Ord. No. 2018-01, § 3(Exh. A), 1-16-18)  
Sec. 54-54.2. - Definitions. 
The following definitions shall apply in this article: 
ANSI shall mean American National Standards Institute, Inc., 1430 Broadway, New York, N.Y. 10018. 
Approved backflow preventer shall mean a backflow preventer as defined herein that is approved by the department in accordance with applicable state and local regulations including the Florida Building Code. 
ASME shall mean American Society of Mechanical Engineers, 345 E. 47 St., New York, N.Y. 10017. 
ASSE shall mean American Society of Sanitary Engineering, 28901 Clemens Rd., Westlake, Ohio 41445. 
Auxiliary water supply shall mean any water supply on or available to the premises other than the public potable water supply. Auxiliary water supplies include, but are not limited to, another provider's potable water supply; a private water supply such as a well for domestic, irrigation or fire flow purposes; natural source(s) such as a spring, lake, river, stream, canal or ocean; used water; reclaimed water; and industrial fluids. 
AWWA Manual M14 4th Ed. shall mean American Water Works Association Manual of Water Supply Practices "Recommended Procedure for Backflow Prevention and Cross-Connection Control," as amended. 
AWWA shall mean the American Water Works Association, 6666 W. Quincy Ave., Denver, Colorado 80235. 
Backflow shall mean the reversal of flow of water or inflow of other substances into a potable water distribution system through a cross-connection. Backflow may degrade the quality of the potable water below required standards. 
Backflow preventer shall mean a mechanical assembly or device or means that prohibits backflow into a potable water system. Only the following types may be approved: 
(1)  Air gap separation (AG) shall mean unobstructed vertical physical separation between the free-flowing discharge end of a potable water supply pipeline and the flood level rim of an open or non-pressure receiving vessel. An approved air gap separation shall be at least double the diameter of the supply pipe measured vertically above the top of the rim of the vessel. In no case shall an air gap separation be less than one inch. 
(2)  Double check detector assembly (DCDA) shall mean a specially designed assembly composed of a line-size approved double check valve assembly with a bypass containing a specific water meter and an approved double check valve assembly. The meter shall register accurately for only very low rates of flow up to three gallons per minute (gpm) and shall show a registration for all rates of flow. The DCDA is used only on fire systems. 
(3)  Double check valve assembly (DC) shall mean an assembly composed of two single, independently acting approved check valves, including tightly closing resilient seated shutoff valves located at each end of the assembly, and fitting with properly located resilient seated test cocks suitable for testing the water tightness of each check valve. A check valve is a valve that is drip-tight in the normal direction of flow when the inlet pressure is one psi and the outlet pressure is zero. The check valve shall permit no leakage in a direction reverse to the normal flow. The closure element (e.g., clapper) shall be internally weighted or otherwise internally loaded to promote rapid and positive closure. This assembly shall be used only to protect against a nonhealth hazard. 
(4)  Dual check valve (DuC) shall mean a device consisting of two single, independently acting check valves. The closure element (e.g., poppet) shall be internally weighted or otherwise internally loaded to promote rapid and positive closure. This assembly shall be used only to protect against a nonhealth hazard. 
(5)  Pressure vacuum breaker (PVB) shall mean an assembly consisting of an independently operating internally loaded check valve and an independently operating loaded air inlet valve located on the discharge side of the check valve, with properly located resilient-seated test cocks and tightly closing resilient-seated shutoff valves attached at each end. The PVB prevents backsiphonage, but it is not effective, and should not be used, in backpressure conditions. 
(6)  Reduced pressure detector assembly (RPDA) shall mean a specially designed assembly composed of a line-size approved reduced pressure principle backflow prevention assembly with a bypass containing a specific water meter and an approved reduced pressure principle backflow preventer. The meter shall register accurately for only very low rates of flow up to three gpm and shall show a registration for all rates of flow. The RPDA is used only on fire systems. 
(7)  Reduced pressure principle backflow preventer (RP) shall mean an assembly containing within its structure a minimum of two independently acting approved check valves, together with an automatically operating pressure differential relief valve located between the two check valves. The first check valve reduces the supply pressure by a predetermined amount so that during normal flow and at cessation of normal flow the pressure between the checks shall be less than the supply pressure. In case of leakage of either check valve, the differential relief valve, by discharging to the atmosphere, shall operate to maintain the pressure between the checks less than the supply pressure. These units are equipped with tightly closing resilient seated shut-off valves located at each end of the assembly, and with properly located resilient seated test cocks. 
Backpressure shall mean any elevation of pressure in the downstream piping system above the supply pressure at the point of consideration, which could cause a reversal of the normal direction of flow. 
Backsiphonage shall mean a form of backflow due to a reduction in system pressure which causes a subatmospheric pressure to exist at a site in the water system. 
Building official shall mean that official designated by the appointing authority, as defined in the Florida Building Code. 
Certified backflow preventer tester shall mean a person who has satisfactorily completed a nationally recognized backflow preventer testing training program that meets or exceeds any existing Florida Department of Environmental Protection (FDEP) standards or that is determined by the City of Hialeah Gardens to meet the requirements of the latest edition of AWWA M14 Manual. After satisfactorily completing a backflow preventer testing training program, as described above, the person shall be required to pass a written examination administered under the direction of Miami-Dade County Construction Trades Qualifying Board (CTQB). All testers are required to be re-certified by Miami- Dade County CTQB every two years. 
Code inspector or Code compliance officer shall have the meaning and powers defined in section 2-250.3 of the city Code. 
Cross connection shall mean any temporary or permanent physical connection or arrangement between a public water system and any other system or source through which it is possible, given pressure differentials, for any substance other than potable water to flow into the public water system. 
Department shall mean the Hialeah Gardens Water and Sewer Department, including its director, employees, agents, designees, and successors. 
Existing water customer shall mean a water customer as defined herein for which a water meter is installed and operating on or before the effective date of this article. 
Florida Fire Prevention Code shall mean rule 69A-60 Florida Administrative Code. 
Industrial fluid shall mean any fluid or solution which is intended to be or has been used in or results from activities of manufacture, production, fabrication, repair, packaging, processing or sale of goods or services or growing of agricultural crops or for fire suppression purposes. This may include, but is not limited to: polluted used waters; polluted auxiliary water; all types of process waters; chemicals in fluid form, including pesticides and fertilizers; fuels and oils; acids and alkalies; circulated cooling waters connected to an open cooling tower and/or cooling waters that are chemically or biologically treated or stabilized with toxic substances. 
Internal isolation shall mean fixture isolation and/or isolation of an area or zone within a customer's premises, downstream of the service connection. Fixture isolation means installing an approved backflow preventer at the source of the potential contamination. Area or zone isolation is confining the potential source of contamination within a specific area. 
NFPA shall mean National Fire Protection Association, Quincy, Massachusetts. 
New water customer shall mean a water customer, as defined herein, who applies for the provision of water service after the effective date of this article. 
Nonhealth hazard shall mean substances which, although not dangerous to health, may impart offensive solids, color, odor or taste to the public water supply. 
Reclaimed water shall mean waste water which has received at least secondary treatment and basic disinfection and is approved for reuse in compliance with regulations of state agencies. 
Residential service connection shall mean any service connection, including any dedicated irrigation or fire service connection, that is two inches or less in diameter and that supplies water to a building or premises, containing only dwelling units. Non-residential service connection is any other service connection. 
Service connection shall mean the terminal end of water delivery from the public water system, that is, where the utility loses jurisdiction and sanitary control over the water at its juncture with the customer's water system. If a meter is installed at the end of the service connection, then the service connection shall mean the downstream end of the meter. Service connection shall also include water service connection from a fire hydrant and all other temporary or emergency water service connections from the potable water system. 
State agencies shall mean the department of environmental protection, the department of health, the state fire marshal, their successors, and any other instrumentality of the State of Florida charged under provisions of F.S. ch. 403, pt. VI, or other statute or regulation with testing, inspecting, certifying, enforcing, or otherwise assuring compliance with environmental, health and safety standards, especially those for safe drinking water. 
Tampering shall mean dismantling, removal, or rendering ineffective after installation, testing and certification, except in order to effect an approved replacement. 
Used water shall mean any water supplied to a customer's water system after it has passed through the service connection. 
Water customer shall mean any individual, municipality, corporation, partnership, firm, association or other entity receiving water service from the department for consumption or usage within its premises or for resale to ultimate consumers. 
(Ord. No. 2018-01, § 3(Exh. A), 1-16-18)  
Sec. 54-54.3. - Prohibition of uncontrolled cross-connections. 
It shall be unlawful for any water customer to install or maintain any cross connections without providing backflow prevention to protect the public water supply. To the extent required by law, educational materials shall be provided by the department to water customers and to relevant businesses and employees, alerting them to the dangers of backflow through cross-connections and to prevention measures. 
(Ord. No. 2018-01, § 3(Exh. A), 1-16-18)  
Sec. 54-54.4. - Backflow preventers required. 
Certain water customers of the department shall install a backflow preventer as provided herein. Backflow preventers installed in the facilities listed in [subsection] (3) below shall be tested by a certified backflow preventer tester. 
(1)  Water customers who own or operate or use or engage in the types of businesses, facilities, substances, and activities listed in [subsections] (3) or (4) below shall install an approved backflow preventer of the type indicated below at the service connection entering their property, within the deadlines listed herein. The same deadlines apply to installation of backflow preventers on Classes 3, 4 and 5 fire suppression systems, as defined in section 54-54.5 serving the premises. New water customers who own or operate or use or engage in the types of businesses, facilities, substances, and activities listed in [subsections] (3) or (4) below shall have an approved backflow preventer as a condition of issuance of building permits or of a certificate of occupancy, and the permanent installation of a water meter. This requirement is not limited to those facilities, premises, uses or situations listed herein but also applies to any others distinctly determined by the department to require such protection. Failure to install a required backflow preventer as required herein, will result in civil penalties to be levied against the responsible party. In the event that the customer provides proof that a plumbing permit has been obtained from the applicable building department, and installs the required backflow preventer, within 90 days of notice of the violation, the Hialeah Gardens Water and Sewer Department may choose to waive the applicable penalties. 
(2)  In the event that the use of a property is changed to one listed in [subsections] (3) or (4) below, and such property does not have a backflow preventer, the property owner must notify the department of the new use and comply with this article. 
(3)  Backflow preventers shall be installed by existing water customers in the following facilities within six months after the effective date of this article. 
Category of Customer 	Backflow Preventer 
Beverage processing plant, including any brewery 	RP 
Cannery, packing house, rendering plant, or any facility where fruit, vegetable, or animal matter is processed, excluding any premises where there is only restaurant or food service facility 	RP 
Car wash 	RP 
Chemical plant or facility using water in the manufacturing, processing, compounding, or treatment of chemicals, including any facility where a chemical that does not meet the requirements in paragraph 62-555.320(3)(a), F.A.C., is used as an additive to the water 	RP

Premises where there is a cooling tower 	RP

Radioactive material processing or handling facility or nuclear reactor 	RP

Wastewater treatment plant or wastewater pumping station 	RP

Exterminating companies 	RP

Radioactive materials present 	RP

(d)  When an addition is made to an existing building and the addition is 25 percent or more of the area of the existing building, a water customer who owns, operates, uses or engages in a business, facility, substance or activity of a type listed in [subsection] (3) above shall install an approved backflow preventer of the appropriate type. When repairs and alterations amounting to more than 50 percent of the value of the existing building are made during any 12-month period, a water customer who owns, operates, uses or engages in a business, facility, substance or activity of a type listed in [subsection] (3) above shall install an approved backflow preventer of the appropriate type. The value of a building or structure shall be the estimated cost of constructing a new building of like size, design and materials at the site of the original structure, assuming such site to be clear. Cost of additions, alterations and repairs shall be construed as the total cost of labor, materials and services based on current prices for new materials. 
(e)  Any customer that is found to have a backflow preventer installed, that is not in accordance with the type required in section 54-54.4(3) and section 54-54.5(b) will be required to replace the existing backflow preventer with one of the appropriate type, as specified in section 54-54.4(3) and section 54-54.5(b) including the small low lying three-sided barrier wall. 
(Ord. No. 2018-01, § 3(Exh. A), 1-16-18)  
Sec. 54-54.4.1. - Reclaimed water regulations. 
All customers of properties using reclaimed water as an auxiliary source of water supply shall install an appropriate backflow preventer, as listed in section 54-54.4(3) on the potable water service connection, immediately adjacent to the water meter serving the property. Existing customers must effect this installation within six months after the effective date of this article. New water customers who own or operate such facilities shall install an appropriate backflow preventer, as listed in section 54-54.4(3), as a condition to permitting, issuance of a certificate of occupancy, and installation of a water meter. The department shall set forth specific limitations and requirements, in accordance with all rules and regulations promulgated by state agencies, in each customer agreement for use of reclaimed water. No reclaimed water shall be provided by the department except under terms of an agreement with the customer. 
(Ord. No. 2018-01, § 3(Exh. A), 1-16-18)  
Sec. 54-54.5. - Fire suppression systems. 
(a)  Fire suppression systems will be classified on the basis of water source and arrangement of supplies as follows:
