Class 1. Direct connections from public service connection only; no pumps, antifreeze or other additives of any kind; all sprinkler drains discharging to atmosphere, dry wells, or other safe outlets. 
Class 2. Same as Class 1 except that booster pumps may be installed in the connections. (Booster pumps do not affect the potability of the system.) It is necessary that pressure in the water main is not reduced below 20 psi to avoid drawing too much water from the main. 
Class 3. Direct connection from the service connection, plus one or more of the following: elevated storage tanks; fire pumps taking suction from aboveground covered reservoirs or tanks; pressure tanks. (All storage facilities are filled or connected to public water only; the water in the tanks is to be maintained in a potable condition. Otherwise, Class 3 systems are the same as Class 5.) 
Class 4. Similar to Class 1 and Class 2, but with an auxiliary water supply dedicated to fire department use and available to the premises, such as an auxiliary supply located within 1,700 feet (518m) of the pumper connection. 
Class 5. Directly supplied from the service connection and interconnected with auxiliary supplies, such as pumps taking suction from reservoirs exposed to contamination, or rivers and ponds; driven wells; mills or other industrial water systems; or where antifreeze or other additives are used. 
(b)  New water customers and existing water customers who are installing new fire suppression systems shall install backflow preventers on all fire suppression systems in accordance with the table below: 
Class 	Minimum Level of Protection * 
Class 1 	DCDA 
Class 2 	DCDA 
Class 3 	DCDA 
Class 4 	RPDA 
Class 5 	RPDA 
 
* Abbreviations refer to types of preventers described in section 54-54.2. 
DCDA = double check detector assembly 
RPDA = reduced pressure detector assembly 
(c)  Existing water customers with Class 1 and Class 2 fire suppression systems are not required to install backflow preventers. 
(d)  All existing systems being modified or upgraded shall have provision for any additional head loss caused by inclusion of the required backflow preventer in the modification design. 
(e)  Exemptions may be granted to water customers with existing systems who can demonstrate to the satisfaction of the department and the Miami-Dade Fire Rescue Department that installation of a backflow preventer would degrade the effectiveness of the fire protection system to a level unacceptable for fire suppression purposes. 
(f)  All installations, testing, maintenance, repairs and replacements of backflow preventers used for fire suppression systems shall be performed by a certified fire protection contractor as defined in F.S. § 633.021(5), and certified in accordance with F.S. § 633.521. 
(g)  In accordance with NFPA-13, all fire department connections shall be on the street side of buildings and shall be located and arranged so that hose lines can be readily and conveniently attached to the inlets without interference from any nearby objects including buildings, fences, posts, or other fire department connections. 
(Ord. No. 2018-01, § 3(Exh. A), 1-16-18)  
Sec. 54-54.6. - Technical requirements. 
All approved backflow preventers shall conform to specifications set forth in the applicable building code and to rules and regulations promulgated by state agencies. The following specifications are adopted until and unless superseded: 
(1)  Air gap (AG) shall conform to ANSI/ASME standard A 112.1.2-1991. 
(2)  All other preventers shall have satisfactorily passed a laboratory and field evaluation in accordance with the latest editions of either Section 10 of the ninth edition of the University of Southern California's Manual of Cross-Connection Control and been approved by the University of Southern California Foundation for Cross Connection Control and Hydraulic Research (USC-FCC & HR); or with ANSI/AWWA Standard C510-97 or C511-97. They are required to be testable in line. 
(3)  Reduced pressure principal backflow prevention assembly (RP) shall conform to ASSE Standard 1013 or ANSI/AWWA Standard C511-97. 
(4)  Double check valve assembly (DC) shall conform to ASSE Standard 1024 or ANSI/AWWA Standard C510-97. 
(5)  Dual check valve (DuC) shall conform to ANSI/ASSE Standard 1024. 
(6)  Pressure vacuum breaker assembly (PVB) shall conform to ANSI/ASSE Standard 1020-1990. 
(7)  Double check detector assembly (DCDA) shall conform to ANSI/ASSE Standard 1048-1995. 
(8)  Reduced pressure detector backflow assembly (RPD) shall conform to ANSI/ASSE Standard 1047-1995. 
(9)  Further specifications for backflow preventers and their installation, and additional and modified ones for specific purposes, may be provided in standard details and/or written specifications issued by the department, in accord with standards adopted by the Florida Building Code and any regulations promulgated by state agencies. 
(Ord. No. 2018-01, § 3(Exh. A), 1-16-18)  
Sec. 54-54.7. - Installation of backflow preventer. 
(a)  Water customers, at their own expense, shall prepare plans and shall obtain a permit for the required backflow preventer. For properties located in the City of Hialeah Gardens, the City of Hialeah Gardens Building Official shall review said plans and charge a fee in accordance with the building department's fee schedule, as may be modified from time to time, for the review of each backflow preventer and the issuance of a permit. In the case of fire suppression systems, the Miami-Dade Fire Rescue Department shall charge a fee in accordance with Administrative Order No. 4-45 of Miami-Dade County to review and inspect each installation. Permitting procedures and standard details shall be established and modified from time to time by means of agreements between and among applicable county, municipal and state agencies. 
(b)  The backflow preventer installer must be a validly licensed contractor possessing a certificate of competency appropriate for the preventer type and location involved. 
(c)  The backflow preventer shall be installed at the customer's expense on the customer's property immediately adjacent to the water meter serving that property. The customer shall provide adequate space for a backflow preventer on the customer's property. The backflow preventer shall be readily accessible for maintenance and testing. No part of it may be beneath the ground surface or submerged under water, and it must not be subject to flooding by a ten-year storm. 
(d)  The installation shall be located at the front property line at one side of the property in accordance with the department's standard details. All backflow preventers that are installed where visible from an area accessible to the public shall be shielded from public view by a visual barrier as listed below: 
(1)  A barrier wall not more than six inches above the highest point of the body of the assembly whereas the stems of the shutoff valves are visible from outside of the wall structure; or 
(2)  A recessed covered space which is part of the building envelope; or 
(3)  A manufactured cover for small diameter assemblies up to two inches. 
Such barriers shall be at least two feet apart from the backflow preventer and must not obstruct access for maintenance and testing. Existing backflow preventer installations, shall be exempt from the installation of a visual barrier. Additionally, any such barrier shall be a minimum of seven and one-half feet apart from any fire department connection including, but not limited to siamese connections and post indicator valves. Said fire department appliances are to be installed in accordance with the Florida Fire Prevention Code, and NFPA standards 13 and 24. 
(e)  Upon completion of the installation, satisfactory testing shall be performed as provided in section 54-55.3(b). Testing requires a water shutdown usually lasting five to 30 minutes. For facilities that require an uninterrupted supply of water, and when it is not possible to provide water service from two separate meters, provisions shall be made for a parallel installation of backflow preventers. The existence of any unprotected bypass around a backflow preventer when the apparatus is in need of testing, repair or replacement is unlawful. 
(f)  The customer shall install plumbing lines of sufficient size to compensate for pressure losses which may result from operation of a backflow preventer. Provision must be made for thermal expansion. 
(g)  It shall be unlawful for any water connections to exist between the water meter and the backflow preventer. 
(h)  It shall be unlawful for any person to remove a backflow preventer from service without the express written consent of the Hialeah Gardens Water and Sewer Department, except for the purposes of replacement, as described in section 54-55.4(c). Unauthorized removal will be considered tampering, as described in section 54-55.2 of the Code of City of Hialeah Gardens. 
(Ord. No. 2018-01, § 3(Exh. A), 1-16-18)  
Sec. 54-54.8. - Exemptions. 
(a)  Buildings of four stories or less without booster pumps which contain only dwelling units (including single family residences, town homes, small apartment buildings), and all other structures or facilities not listed in section 54-54.4, shall be exempt from the requirement of installation of a backflow preventer, provided that: 
(1)  No cross-connections exist or are subsequently installed on the property; 
(2)  No uses or facilities listed in section 54-54.4 receive water through the same service connection; and 
(3)  Any auxiliary water supply is not cross-connected. 
(b)  Exemptions from or exceptions to the department's standard details may be granted by the applicable building official or his designee for installation of backflow preventers where physical limitations are present, provided that the preventer as installed is tested satisfactorily and certified. 
(Ord. No. 2018-01, § 3(Exh. A), 1-16-18)  
Sec. 54-54.9. - Fire hydrants. 
Except for the use of fire hydrants for fire suppression purposes, any use of fire hydrants and fire systems by any person other than the department or the applicable county or municipal fire department without the prior written approval of both, is prohibited and such person may be ordered to cease and desist by the applicable fire department. 
(Ord. No. 2018-01, § 3(Exh. A), 1-16-18)  
Sec. 54-55. - Access required. 
(a)  Any code inspector, certified backflow preventer tester, or authorized representative of the department, at any reasonable time upon reasonable notice and presentation of proper credentials, and upon consent by the property owner or person in charge of the property, building or place, may enter, monitor, sample, test, and inspect, as often as may be necessary, any structure, property, premises, building or place, public or private, residential or nonresidential within the water distribution system of the department, for the purpose of assuring that no cross connections exist and that approved backflow preventers are in place where required. This right of access includes the right to effect any emergency actions necessary, including but not limited to disconnecting water service. Inspections of the facilities listed in section 54-54.4, which pose the greatest potential hazard to the public water supply, are deemed to be a public necessity. 
(b)  No person shall refuse reasonable entry or access to the duly authorized representative who requests entry for any of the purposes set forth in [subsection] (a) above and who presents appropriate credentials identifying himself. 
(c)  No person shall obstruct, hamper, or interfere with any such inspection, entry, monitoring, testing, or sampling. 
(d)  An inspection, entry, monitoring, testing and sampling, pursuant to this section may be conducted only after: 
(1)  Consent for the entry, inspection, testing, monitoring and sampling is received from the owner or person in charge of the property, building, premises or place; or 
(2)  An inspection warrant as provided in this section or by law is obtained. 
(e)  An inspection warrant is authorized by this article and may be issued by a judge of any county court or circuit court of this state which has jurisdiction of the place or thing to be searched. 
(f)  The department director or his designee is hereby authorized and empowered to obtain all search or inspection warrants reasonable and necessary to carry out the responsibilities, powers and duties set forth in this article, in accordance with the requirements of the Constitutions of the United States of America and the State of Florida. 
(Ord. No. 2018-01, § 3(Exh. A), 1-16-18)  
Sec. 54-55.1. - Obstruction prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any water customer to maintain or place anything on or near a backflow preventer or other related equipment which obstructs access to the backflow preventer. 
(Ord. No. 2018-01, § 3(Exh. A), 1-16-18)  
Sec. 54-55.2. - Tampering prohibited. 
The intentional tampering with a backflow preventer, rendering it out of compliance with this article, is prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 2018-01, § 3(Exh. A), 1-16-18)  
Sec. 54-55.3. - Testing. 
(a)  Testing standards. All required tests of backflow preventers shall be accomplished in accordance with the procedures in the latest editions of Chapter 8 of AWWA Manual M14 and Section 9 of the University of Southern California's Manual of Cross-Connection Control. 
(b)  Initial. All backflow preventers shall be installed under a plumbing, mechanical or fire permit obtained from the building official. The backflow preventer shall be tested by a certified backflow preventer tester as defined herein and certified as testing satisfactory prior to final plumbing approval being granted and prior to the installation of the permanent water meter. Where a permanent water meter is not yet installed, the certified tester shall obtain water for testing the backflow preventer via a method approved by the department. 
(c)  Routine testing. 
(1)  All backflow preventers installed on a non-residential or multi-family residential property with service size greater than two inches must be tested at least annually to assure that they are performing satisfactorily by a certified backflow preventer tester. 
(2)  All backflow preventers installed on a residential property with service size no greater than two inches must be tested at least biennially to assure that they are performing satisfactorily by a certified backflow preventer tester. 
(3)  The first routine testing of each backflow preventer installed subsequent to enactment of this article shall occur within 12 months of installation for non-residential, and within 24 months for residential customers. 
(d)  Change of occupancy or ownership. Inspection of premises and satisfactory testing of an existing backflow preventer may be required before initiation of water service to a new customer or issuance of a new certificate of occupancy. 
(e)  Deficiencies. If deficiencies are identified during any testing, the tester shall provide the water customer and the department with a listing of the defects, on a form acceptable to the department, within five days of the test, which warns the customer that defects must be repaired within 35 days of the department's receipt of the report. Retesting shall be performed at or before the end of that period. 
(Ord. No. 2018-01, § 3(Exh. A), 1-16-18)  
Sec. 54-55.4. - Repairs and replacement. 
(a)  It is the customer's responsibility to assure that all defects listed by backflow preventer testers are corrected. 
(b)  Failure to complete repairs and have the backflow preventer certified as testing satisfactory within 35 days of the department's receipt of the report listing any deficiency shall result in a civil violation notice. The time allowed for correction shall be ten days. Failure to correct the defect and comply with the civil violation notice may result in a civil action by the city. 
(c)  If a backflow preventer cannot be repaired to test satisfactorily, the customer shall replace it with the type required in section 54-54.4 and have the replacement tested and certified. 
(d)  All repairs and replacement of a backflow preventer shall be done with a valid permit. 
(Ord. No. 2018-01, § 3(Exh. A), 1-16-18)  
Sec. 54-55.5. - Test reporting. 
Upon completion of testing, a test report form approved by the department shall be completed by the certified backflow preventer tester and submitted to the customer and to the department, no later than ten days following the test. If the backflow preventer required repair before testing satisfactorily, that fact shall be indicated. 
(Ord. No. 2018-01, § 3(Exh. A), 1-16-18)  
Sec. 54-55.6. - Modifications of facilities. 
Water customers shall notify the department of any change of use of their premises or installation of fixtures or facilities which may affect the performance of existing backflow preventers or which may require installation of new backflow preventers. An evaluation of cross-connection protection needs must be performed by the department before any such new uses or fixtures or facilities receive water service. 
(Ord. No. 2018-01, § 3(Exh. A), 1-16-18)  
Sec. 54-55.7. - Reporting and recordkeeping. 
(a)  All incidents of suspected or actual backflow shall be reported to the department by all persons with knowledge. 
(b)  The department shall retain all records incident to the cross-connection control program which are mandated by this article and by rules and regulations promulgated by state agencies pursuant to provisions of F.S. ch. 403, pt. VI. 
(Ord. No. 2018-01, § 3(Exh. A), 1-16-18)  
Sec. 54-55.8. - Enforcement. 
The following enforcement actions are authorized separately or in combination. 
(1)  The department may take emergency action to eliminate a cross connection involving a health hazard, or to stop and prevent backflow, by any practicable means, including disconnection of water service and installation of an approved backflow preventer, billing the customer for the cost of labor, applicable permit fees, and materials (including overhead and fringe benefits). 
(2)  The department may refuse water service to a customer in violation of the provisions of this article, or to a customer who does not pay costs of department emergency action to prevent backflow within 60 days. Water service may be withheld until the violation is corrected, the costs paid, fines for violations of this chapter under city Code paid, and the affected premises or facilities are certified to be in compliance with all requirements stated herein. 
(3)  The department may add any costs of emergency action to prevent backflow which remain unpaid after 60 days to the customer's bill for services and record and enforce a lien when and as authorized by city Code. 
(4)  Any person who violates any provision of this article or any lawful rule, regulation or written order promulgated under it is liable for any damage caused by such violation to the City of Hialeah Gardens, including, but not limited to damage to the public water supply and costs of rectifying harm, and is also liable directly or indirectly for all damage to other parties. The city may undertake court actions to recover its damages, to restrain, abate or correct violations of this article, to permit access and corrective action, and to prevent use and occupancy of any premises where a probable violation of this article could endanger human health. The term "damages" herein shall be understood to include all those which may be recoverable in civil actions in the courts of Florida. 
(5)  This article may be enforced by code, invoking all applicable provisions of the city Code, and the Florida Building Code, including, but not limited to, civil violation notices, administrative hearings, court appeals, and assessment of fines and costs with further penalties for non-payment. 
(6)  In addition to any civil penalty or court award of damages, any violator shall be liable for the reasonable costs and expenses incurred by the city in enforcing the provisions of this article including, but not limited to, the labor and material costs (including overhead and fringe benefits) of emergency enforcement actions, inspections, permit fees, preparation of enforcement reports, photographs, title searches, postage, court or hearing attendance time, and other demonstrable administrative costs for enforcement and collection. All such sums shall become delinquent if not paid within 30 days after receipt by the violator of the department's bill itemizing the costs incurred in enforcing the provisions of this article, or after a hearing officer or court order becomes final (the "due date"). All such delinquent sums shall bear interest at the rate of 12 percent per annum after the due date. 
(7)  In lieu of the lien for unpaid civil penalties, if the violator is a water customer, the department may include the amount of any ordered civil penalty including costs and expenses in the water customer's bill for service. 
(8)  Upon the rendition of a judgment or decree by any of the courts of this state, including appellate courts, against any person and in favor of the city to enforce compliance with this article or to award damages to the city, the court shall adjudge a reasonable sum as fees for the attorney acting on behalf of the city in that civil action, in addition to court costs. 
(Ord. No. 2018-01, § 3(Exh. A), 1-16-18)  
Sec. 54-55.9. - Fees and charges. 
Fees and charges imposed herein shall be subject to annual review and modification. The city mayor is hereby authorized to establish future modifications to the department's fees by separate implementing order, which fees shall not become effective until approved by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 2018-01, § 3(Exh. A), 1-16-18)  
Secs. 54-56—54-70. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - SEWAGE DISPOSAL SYSTEMS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference— Code compliance, § 2-211 et seq. 
 
Sec. 54-71. - Injurious conditions—Enumerated. 
The following conditions existing, permitted, maintained, kept, or caused by any individual or entity shall constitute a condition injurious to health: 
(1)  Untreated or improperly treated human waste, offal, dead animals or parts thereof, human parts, waste derived from hospitals, or dangerous waste materials from manufacturing processes harmful to human or animal life, and air pollution and gasses which are harmful to human or animal life. 
(2)  Improperly built or maintained septic tanks, water closets, or privies. 
(3)  Discharging or allowing the discharge of septic tank pump-out waste or the discharge of any other product, chemical, or waste which can damage underground aquifers into streams or surface waters or underground aquifers, or into ditches, drainage structures, or on the ground surface. 
(4)  Radioactive material. 
(Code 1985, § 50.35)  
Sec. 54-72. - Same—Prohibited. 
No individual or entity shall allow any conditions enumerated in section 54-71 to exist or be maintained or kept within the city limits of the city. 
(Code 1985, § 50.36)  
Sec. 54-73. - Evidence of violation. 
It shall be prima facie evidence that an individual or entity is allowing an injurious condition prohibited by section 54-72 to exist if, in fact, the condition is found on property that such individual or entity has control of, leases, or owns. 
(Code 1985, § 50.37)  
Secs. 54-74—54-100. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - STORMWATER UTILITY MANAGEMENT[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 96-06, § 1, adopted June 4, 1996, established provisions authorizing a stormwater utility management program. Said ordinance did not specify manner of codification; hence, inclusion herein as Art. IV, §§ 54-101—54-132 was at the discretion of the editor. 
Cross reference— Environment, ch. 30; taxation and finance, ch. 46. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 54-101. - Authority and general provisions. 
The city is authorized by the Florida Constitution and the provisions of F.S. ch. 166 and § 403.0893, reconstruct, repair, improve and extend stormwater management systems and to establish just and equitable rates, fees and charges for the services and facilities provided by the system. This article shall hereinafter be known and may be cited as the Stormwater Utility Management Program (SUMP) Ordinance of the city. 
(Ord. No. 96-06, 6-4-96)  
Sec. 54-102. - Findings of fact and statement of purpose. 
(a)  The city operates and maintains a system of storm and surface water management facilities, including but not limited to inlets, conduits, manholes, channels, ditches, drainage easements, retention and detention basins, infiltration facilities and other components. 
(b)  The elements of the city storm and surface water management system that provide for the collection, storage, treatment, and conveyance of stormwater benefit and provide services to all property within the city. 
(c)  The cost of operating and maintaining the stormwater utility management system and the financing of existing and future repairs, replacements, improvements, and extensions thereof should, to the extent practicable, be allocated in proportion to the benefits enjoyed, and the services received therefrom. 
(d)  Due to the age of the existing infrastructure, some rehabilitation and replacement may be required. 
(e)  Water quality is degraded because of erosion and the discharge of nutrients, metals, oil, grease, and other substances into and through the stormwater system. 
(f)  Public health, safety, and welfare are adversely affected by poor water quality and flooding resulting from inadequate stormwater management practices. 
(g)  Real property either uses or benefits from the presence and operation of the stormwater utility management system. 
(h)  Florida local governments have the authority to establish stormwater utility management programs pursuant to the home rule powers provided in the Florida Constitution and F.S. ch. 166 and ch. 403. 
(i)  The Florida Legislature, through the adoption of F.S. § 403.0893, specifically authorizes and encourages local governments to provide stormwater utility management services as a utility function for which service charges may be levied. 
(j)  New and dedicated funding for the stormwater utility management program of the city is needed, and the levy of a stormwater utility management fee is the most equitable method of providing this funding. 
(k)  The Federal Clean Water Act, and the implementing regulations adopted by the Federal Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), require the permitting of certain municipal stormwater systems to ensure that minimum water quality standards are met. 
(l)  The establishment of a stormwater utility management plan now will mitigate the impact of the costs ultimately imposed upon local governments through the adoption by the EPA of permitting standards for separate stormwater systems. 
(m)  Adoption of a stormwater utility management program will generate revenues needed to implement the level of service standards contained in the city's comprehensive master land use plan drainage element and the capital improvement elements which were adopted in conformance with the requirements of F.S. ch. 163. 
(n)  Local natural resource features such as wetlands, lakes and groundwater supplies can be protected and enhanced as part of the stormwater utility management program. 
(Ord. No. 96-06, 6-4-96)  
Sec. 54-103. - Definitions. 
Unless specifically defined below, words or phrases shall be interpreted so as to give them the meaning they have in common usage and to give this article its most effective application. 
City means mean the City of Hialeah Gardens, Florida. 
Category I means any lot or parcel developed exclusively for residential purposes including, but not limited to single-family homes, duplexes, multi-family apartments, manufactured homes, mobile homes, and condominiums. 
Category II means any developed lot or parcel not in category I or category III, as defined herein. 
Category III means any property which is undeveloped, or having been developed, has not been significantly altered from its natural state by the addition of improvements such as buildings, structures, impervious surfaces, and changes of grade or landscaping. This includes but is not limited to, vacant property, parks, airports, golf courses, well fields, etc. For the purposes of this section, property shall be considered developed upon issuance of a certificate of occupancy, or upon completion of construction or final inspection if no such certificate is issued. 
Director means the director of the public works department or designee. 
Dwelling unit means any residential space identified for habitation by members of a single household unit. 
Impervious area means any part of any parcel of land that has been modified to reduce the land's natural ability to absorb and hold rainfall. 
Stormwater runoff means that part of precipitation that travels over natural, altered or improved surfaces to any stream, channel, canal, river, impoundment area or city owned and maintained rights-of-way. 
Stormwater utility management plan means a plan for receiving, storing, transporting and treating storm and surface waters within the city stormwater management system. 
Stormwater utility management system includes all natural and manmade elements used to convey storm water to a suitable location, internal or external, to the boundaries of the city. The stormwater management system includes, but is not limited to, all pipes, channels, streams, ditches, wetlands, sinkholes, detention/retention basins, ponds and other stormwater conveyance and percolation or treatment facilities. 
(Ord. No. 96-06, 6-4-96)  
Secs. 54-104—54-125. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - STORMWATER MANAGEMENT UTILITY 
 
Sec. 54-126. - Stormwater management utility established; operational status. 
There is hereby created and established a stormwater management utility, which shall be the operational means of implementing and carrying out the functional requirements of the stormwater utility management plan. The stormwater management utility shall also be responsible for the operation of the city's stormwater management system. 
(Ord. No. 96-06, 6-4-96)  
Sec. 54-127. - Stormwater management utility fee. 
A stormwater fee is hereby imposed upon each and every lot and parcel of land within the city, for the services and facilities provided by the stormwater management utility. 
For purposes of imposing the stormwater fee, all lots and parcels of land within the city shall be classified into one of the following three categories: 
(1)  Category I, as previously defined herein; 
(2)  Category II, as previously defined herein; or 
(3)  Category III, as previously defined herein. 
(Ord. No. 96-06, 6-4-96)  
Sec. 54-128. - Assignment of category by director. 
The director shall determine and assign to each and every lot and parcel of land within the city a customer category as previously defined in this article. 
(Ord. No. 96-06, 6-4-96)  
Sec. 54-129. - Stormwater management utility rates. 
A stormwater management utility rate will be established and adjusted annually by city resolution based upon the projected annual operating and capital improvement budgets for the stormwater management utility as applied to the respective runoff coefficients for the applicable land use categories. However, nothing contained herein shall prevent the city from amending any annual rate resolution during any annual period if deemed necessary and appropriate by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 96-06, 6-4-96)  
Sec. 54-130. - Billing and payment; penalties. 
(a)  Bills or statements for the stormwater utility fee shall be rendered either monthly or bimonthly, in accordance with the regular utility billing cycle of the city by the finance department for all properties subject to the fee. Bills shall be payable at the same time, and in the same manner, and subject to the same penalties, as set forth for water services in the city's water and sewer rules and regulations approved and adopted by Ordinance No. 90-46. Any unpaid stormwater fees shall constitute a lien against the property, which lien shall be prior to all other liens on such property, except the liens for state, county and municipal taxes, and shall be on a parity with the liens of such state, county and municipal taxes. Such lien, when delinquent for more than 30 days, may be foreclosed by the city in the manner provided for by the laws of Florida for the foreclosure of mortgages on real property. 
(b)  For properties normally receiving periodic municipal service bills for other services, the stormwater utility fee shall be included in the periodic utility bill rendered to the established customer. 
(c)  For properties not receiving periodic municipal service bills for other services, the bill or statement for the stormwater utility fee shall be sent to the property owner, as determined from the property appraiser tax rolls. In such cases, the finance department may render an annual bill or render a special monthly municipal service bill at the option of the city. 
(d)  The owner of a property is ultimately responsible for all fees imposed under this article. 
(Ord. No. 96-06, 6-4-96)  
Sec. 54-131. - Adjustment of customer category or rate based upon property characterization or size. 
(a)  Requests for adjustments of the assigned customer category or rate paid shall be submitted to the public works department, on the forms to be provided by the department, and shall set forth; in detail the grounds upon which relief is sought. The city's mayor shall have the authority to administer the procedures set forth herein, and to establish the standards and review criteria to be utilized for the adjustment of any category or fee assigned. The public works department shall provide technical assistance and input to the mayor's office during the administration of the adjustment process. No adjustment or credit shall be given for the installation of facilities required by the city or county development codes or state stormwater rules. The following procedures shall apply to all adjustment requests: 
(1)  Adjustment requests will be reviewed by the city within a four-month period from the date a completed application, including all required documentation that is needed to support the application, has been submitted to the public works department. Adjustments resulting from such requests shall be retroactive to the date the application is complete, including submission of all documentation but, in any case, shall not exceed one year. 
(2)  Anyone requesting an adjustment shall be required to provide information along with their application which shall include, but shall not be limited to, survey data and engineering reports, performed by either a professional land surveyor currently registered in the state or a professional engineer currently registered in the state to support their request. The failure to provide such information within four months of the date of the filing of the application form shall result in the automatic denial of the adjustment. 
(3)  Adjustments to the fee to be paid shall be made upon the granting of the adjustment request, in writing, by the mayor, or his/her designee. Denials of adjustment requests shall be made in writing by the mayor, or his/her designee. 
(4)  During the period of time that a request for adjustment is pending, all fees must be paid, and the applicant for an adjustment must also be current on the date the application is filed. 
(b)  Category I customers shall be permitted to request a change in category only. 
(Ord. No. 96-06, 6-4-96)  
Sec. 54-132. - Stormwater management utility enterprise fund. 
There shall be established a stormwater management utility enterprise fund for the deposit of all fees and charges collected pursuant to the stormwater utility management program. These funds shall be collected and maintained for the exclusive use of the city's stormwater management utility, including, but not limited to, the following: 
(1)  Stormwater management utility services, such as studies, design services, permit reviews, plan preparations and development reviews; 
(2)  Operation, maintenance, repair and replacement of the stormwater collection, storage, treatment and conveyance infrastructure; 
(3)  Project costs related to the construction of major or minor structural improvements in the stormwater related infrastructure as provided in the city wide stormwater utility management program; 
(4)  Administrative costs associated with the management of the stormwater utility management program; 
(5)  Debt service incurred for the financing of stormwater related capital improvements; and 
(6)  Funding of studies associated with the planning of stormwater related infrastructure. 
(Ord. No. 96-06, 6-4-96)  
Chapter 56 - VEHICLES FOR HIRE  
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Secs. 56-1—56-20. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - TOWING 
 
Sec. 56-21. - Applicability and compliance of city regulations. 
The following provisions shall be applicable to towing companies whose services are utilized by the City of Hialeah Gardens for towing. The following rules and regulations shall apply and be complied with by towing companies utilized by the City of Hialeah Gardens: 
Equipment: Each towing company utilized by the city shall have the following equipment: 
(1)  Class A wreckers (minimum three): 
a.  Tow truck shall have a minimum manufacturer's capacity of 10,000 pounds GVW; 
b.  Boom capacity of not less than three tons per boom; 
c.  Drum or power winch pulling capacity of not less than six tons; 
d.  One hundred feet or more of 3/8 -inch cable on each drum; 
e.  Double booms so constructed as to permit splitting each boom to operate independently or jointly; or single boom, hydraulic, elevated and extendable; 
f.  Cradle tow place or tow sling equipped with safety chain. 
(2)  Class B wreckers (minimum one): 
a.  Tow truck shall have a minimum manufacturer's capacity of 10,000 pounds GVW; 
b.  Boom capacity of not less than four tons; 
c.  Two power winches pulling capacity of not less than four tons each; 
d.  Minimum of 100 feet of at least 3/8 -inch cable; 
e.  Single boom hydraulic, elevated and extendable; 
f.  Cradle tow or tow sling to pick up vehicles; 
g.  Dual wheels; 
h.  Two 50-foot spools of extra 3/8 -inch cable, with end hooks. 
(3)  Class C wreckers (minimum one): 
a.  Tow truck shall have a minimum manufacturer's capacity of not less than 45,000 pounds GVW; 
b.  Boom capacity of not less than ten tons per boom; 
c.  Drum or power winch pulling capacity of not less than 20 tons; 
d.  Two hundred feet or more of 9/16 -inch cable or larger on each drum; 
e.  Double booms so constructed as to permit separating each boom to operate independently or jointly, or hydraulic boom, elevated and extendable; 
f.  Vacuum booster or airbrake so constructed as to lock all wheels automatically upon failure. 
(4)  Class D wreckers (minimum one): 
a.  Tow truck shall have a minimum manufacturer's capacity of not less than 66,000 pounds GVW; 
b.  Boom capacity of not less than 30 tons per boom; 
c.  Drum or power winch pulling capacity of not less than 45 tons; 
d.  Two hundred feet or more of ¾-inch cable or larger on each drum; 
e.  Double boom so constructed to permit separating each boom to operate independently or jointly, or hydraulic boom, elevated and extendable; 
f.  Vacuum booster or airbrake so constructed as to lock all wheels automatically upon failure. 
(5)  One 35-ton landroll for recovery or container equipment hauling. 
(6)  Three flatbed trucks. 
(7)  One service vehicle for immediate assistance as it relates to Class 5 (batteries, out of gas, locked out, etc.). 
(Ord. No. 99-02, § 2, 1-19-99)  
Sec. 56-22. - Required equipment. 
Each wrecker shall have the following equipment: 
One heavy duty push broom 
Floodlights on hoist (night scene) 
One axe 
One shovel 
One crowbar/prybar 
One fire extinguisher 
One set of bolt cutters 
Thirty-minute flares 
Four traffic cones, 28-inches high 
Amber beacon lights on all wreckers 
Company name printed on both sides of wrecker (driver and passenger doors) 
All wreckers must be ready at dispatch. 
(Ord. No. 99-02, § 3, 1-19-99)  
Sec. 56-23. - Additional requirements. 
All towing companies utilized by the City of Hialeah Gardens shall have a minimum of $1,000,000.00 liability insurance coverage and $50,000.00 property damage insurance coverage. 
All towing companies utilized by the City of Hialeah Gardens shall be located within the city, or within three miles of the city limits. 
All towing companies utilized by the city shall have inside storage capacity of a minimum of three cars and outside storage capacity of a minimum of 75 cars. 
All towing companies utilized by the city shall be established for a minimum of five years. 
All towing companies utilized by the city shall comply fully with state and county law and be licensed by the city, and subject to the provisions of Code sections 56-21 et seq. of the Code of the City of Hialeah Gardens and all provisions of chapter 56 of the Code of the City of Hialeah Gardens not in conflict herewith are incorporated herein by reference. 
(Ord. No. 99-02, § 4, 1-19-99; Ord. No. 2006-43, § 2, 12-19-06)  
Sec. 56-24. - Contracts with towing companies. 
The City of Hialeah Gardens may, by resolution, enter into contracts with one or more towing companies to provide towing services for the city. Such towing companies shall meet the qualifications provided herein and may limit the number of towing companies the city contracts with in order to provide a consistent and uniform service as it relates to city ordered towing. Excepting emergency situations, no other towing company shall be utilized by the City of Hialeah Gardens other than those contracted with to perform the services for the city. Such contracts shall be for such term and under such provisions as are in the best interest of the city. 
(Ord. No. 99-02, § 5, 1-19-99)  
Subpart B - LAND DEVELOPMENT REGULATIONS  
Chapter 58 - BUILDINGS AND BUILDING REGULATIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Code compliance, § 2-211 et seq.; flood hazard reduction, § 70-31 et seq.; housing regulations, ch. 74. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Secs. 58-1—58-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - CONSTRUCTION STANDARDS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Building standards, F.S. ch. 553. 
 
Sec. 58-31. - Technical standards adopted. 
The following technical construction standards are hereby adopted: 
(1)  The South Florida Building Code (Dade County edition); 
(2)  The Public Works Manual of Metropolitan Dade County and the standards of the county water and sewer authority department, chapter 28 of subdivisions; 
(3)  The Energy Efficiency Code of Building Construction, 1991 edition, developed by the department of community affairs; 
(4)  The National Electrical Code, 1990 edition; and 
(5)  The requirements for accessibility by physically disabled persons as specified in F.S. ch. 553, part V; 
together with any and all amendments to such codes and statutes from time to time enacted are hereby incorporated into this Code by reference and as if fully set forth herein, and such codes and statutes, as amended, shall be considered technical construction standards to be followed in construction and enforced by the city. 
(Code 1985, § 155.08.01; Ord. No. 90-32, §§ 1—4, 1-22-91; Ord. No. 90-40, § 2, 6-4-91)  
Sec. 58-32. - Construction permit application. 
Applications for a permit for new construction, inclusive of, but not necessarily limited to, roads, buildings, and site work, as well as alterations or repairs of valuation exceeding 50 percent of the appraised value of existing construction, shall be accompanied by a current survey prepared within 90 days of the date of application for such permit. 
(Code 1985, § 150.01)  
Sec. 58-33. - Construction survey. 
The survey required by section 58-32 shall be approved by a duly authorized person licensed by the state to render such approval. The required survey shall indicate existing elevations and conditions, as well as elevations and conditions required by the building official or code compliance officer of the city. 
(Code 1985, § 150.02)  
Sec. 58-34. - Approval of site condition. 
If required by the building official or code compliance officer of the city, approval of existing site condition shall be rendered by a duly authorized person so approved, licensed, and registered by the state to render such approval. 
(Code 1985, § 150.03)  
Sec. 58-35. - Structure permit. 
If the application for building permit is for a structure permit, the applicant for such permit shall submit for approval, prior to tie-beam inspection request, a recent survey indicating finish floor elevation and site conditions. 
(Code 1985, § 150.04)  
Sec. 58-36. - Certificate of completion. 
Prior to a certificate of completion being issued by the building official or code compliance officer, a survey shall be required indicating all completed improvements, finish floor grades, and site grades. This survey shall be submitted for approval by the building official or code compliance officer. 
(Code 1985, § 150.05)  
Sec. 58-37. - Dedication of property to city. 
(a)  Before a building permit is issued for a parcel of land, the owner of the land must dedicate to the city by deed 35 feet on all section lines, half section lines, and quarter section lines, and 30 feet on all other sides of the land involved. The deed shall be in a form approved by the director of the department of public works. 
(b)  Before a building permit is issued for a parcel of land lying within the portion of the city now zoned EU-1 having as one of its boundaries existing or projected N.W. 131st, 133rd, 135th, and 137th Streets, or existing or projected N.W. 97th, 99th, 102nd and 104th Avenues, the owner of the land must dedicate to the city by deed 35 feet on all section lines, half section lines, or quarter section lines, and 30 feet on all sides of the parcel having one of the streets or avenues as a boundary which is not a section line, half section line, or quarter section line. The deed shall be in the form approved by the building official or code compliance officer. This subsection contemplates that all homes built on each of the streets or avenues mentioned in the section of the city now zoned EU-1 shall face in the same direction, and it shall be the duty of the building official or code compliance officer to assure this uniformity in the issuance of building permits so that each of the parcels of property bordered by the streets and avenues aforementioned will be improved with residences facing in the same direction, whether that be north, south, east, or west, and these and other categories of determinations, locations of streets, and dedications not indicated specifically by the terms of this section shall be determined by the building official or code compliance officer. 
(c)  Should there in fact be an existing road or planned road concerning the property as described in subsection (b) of this section, then in fact the dedication required by this section shall be measured from the centerline of the road or planned road. 
(Code 1985, § 150.06)  
Sec. 58-38. - General information of special fees, refunds, extensions and cancellations. 
The building department shall charge and collect for permits at the rates provided for in the following schedules and on file in the city clerk's office. 
(1)  Double fees. 
a.  When work for which a permit is required is commenced prior to the obtaining of a permit, the permit applicant will be required to pay $100.00 plus double permit fee, but in no event the fee shall be less than $200.00. The payment of the required fee shall not relieve them from being subject to any of the penalties therein. The double fee requirements shall be applicable to all divisions of the building and zoning department as noted herein. 
b.  For second offense of doing work without a permit, the permit applicant shall be required to pay twice the double permit fees plus $200.00. 
c.  For each offense thereafter, the permit applicant shall be required to pay twice the double permit fee plus $500.00. 
(2)  Reinspection fees. When extra inspections trips are necessary due to (1) wrong address being given on call for inspection, (2) prior rejection of work due to faulty construction, (3) work not being ready for inspection at time specified, (4) failure to call for final or other inspections, (5) required corrections not being made or completed at time specified, (6) permit cards and plans not available for the inspector, (7) no access to the site provided for the inspector. A fee of $50.00 for each reinspection shall be charged to the permit holder in the trade concerned. 
(3)  Lost, revised and rework plans fee. 
a.  Lost plans: When plans for new buildings, remodeling and additions are lost by the owner or contractor, a recertification fee will be required to review, stamp and approve a new set of plans as a field copy. Such fee shall be based on 30 percent of the original building permit fee, with a minimum fee for group I (SFR) of $50.00, and a minimum fee for all others of $90.00. 
b.  Revised plans processing fee: Plan revisions after permit is issued shall be subject to a fee of 30 percent of the original permit fee up to a maximum of $1,000.00 In no event the fee for review of plan shall be less than $20.00 per sheet or $60.00 per hour or fraction thereof. 
c.  Reworks: A fee of $75.00 may be charged for failure to make required corrections previously indicated. 
d.  Lost permit card fee: A replacement fee of $25.00 shall be charged for the loss of a permit inspection record card after a permit has been issued. 
e.  Records of inspection results $50.00 per report. 
(4)  Refunds, time limitations, cancellations. The fees charged pursuant to this schedule, provided the same are for a permit required by section 301.1 of the SFBC, may be refunded by the chief building official, subject to the following: 
a.  No refunds shall be made on requests involving: 
1.  Permit fees of $100.00 or less; or 
2.  Permits revoked by the building official under authority granted by the SFBC, or permits canceled by court order; or conditional permits; or 
3.  Permits which have expired; or 
4.  Permits under which work has commenced as evidenced by any recorded inspection having been made by the department; or 
5.  The original permit holder when there is a change of contractor. 
b.  A full refund less $100.00 or 50 percent of the permit fee, whichever is greater, rounded to the nearest dollar, shall be granted to a permit holder who: 
Requests a refund, provided: 
1.  The department received a written request from the permit holder prior to the permit expiration date; and 
2.  The permit holder submits with such request the applicant's validated copy of such permit; and 
3.  No work has commenced under such permit as evidenced by any recorded inspection and/or field inspection. 
c.  Where there is a change of contractor or qualifier involving a permit, the second permit holder shall pay a fee of $75.00 to cover the cost of transferring the data from the original permit to the second permit. Except when the original permit has expired or the original permit fee is under $75.00, in which case the original permit fee shall be paid. 
d.  A fee of $55.00 shall be paid by the permit holder who submits a written request for a permit extension as authorized under section 304.3(b) of the SFBC. 
e.  Where a permit has become null and void pursuant to paragraph 304.3 (a) of the SFBC, a credit of 50 percent of the permit fee shall be applied to any reapplication fee for a permit covering the same project and involving the same plans, provided that the complete re-application is made within six months of the expiration date of the original permit, and provided that no refund had been made as provided in this section. 
If re-application is made after six months of the expiration date or if this is not the first re-application made on the project, the full permit fee shall be charged on the renewal application. The permit re-application must be submitted with the plans and the applicant's validated copy of the original permit. The amount of this fee shall be as least equal to or higher than the minimum fee for the trade concerned. 
(5)  Special projects. A fee equal to actual staff time and related costs shall be assessed for special projects requiring research by the department in order to answer questions proposed by developers, attorneys, realtors, or municipalities, etc., in connection with the use, resubdivision, and developments of properties, or to determine if any existing violations are on the property through a review of departmental records. Such special fee only will be levied for requests outside the scope of normal departmental work. A minimum fee of $60.00 shall be charged. A fee equal to $2.00 per page be assessed for preprogrammed computer records on department records. The minimum fee shall be $50.00. 
(6)  General information. 
a.  A $0.01 per square foot fee will be added to building permits for the state to study building code requirements for radon gas and certification and regulation of building code administrators, plans examiners and inspectors. 
b.  A fee of $0.50 per $1,000 job cost, or fractional value of work to be done as has been mandated by Dade County Code Compliance Office under County Ord. 91-74. This Code compliance fee shall be in addition to any other fees and costs that may be payable as a condition of obtaining a permit, and shall be non-refundable. 
(7)  Inspections requiring overtime. Charges for construction inspections, which are requested in advance and which requires that an employee work overtime, will be at a rate of $50.00 per hour including traveling time, in accordance with applicable employee contracted bargaining agreements. 
(8)  Fees based on estimated cost-documentation requirements. The department may require the permit applicant to submit appropriate documentation as proof of estimated cost of construction used to compute permit fees. 
(9)  Owner—Builder. Permit fees established by this article shall be increased by 100 percent except painting of residence or duplex. 
(10)  Courtesy inspection fee. When a homeowner requests that a courtesy inspection be performed by a code compliance officer. In order to establish if any violation exists and a written report is prepared. A fee of $75.00 shall be paid to the city. 
(11)  Telecommunications towers and antennas. 
a.  New telecommunication towers .....$4,000.00 
b.  Collocations .....$2,800.00 
(Code 1985, § 150.07; Ord. No. 89-18, § 1, 11-14-89; Ord. No. 90-28, § 1, 5-7-91; Ord. No. 90-44, § 1, 10-15-91; Ord. No. 90-58, § 1, 2-4-92; Ord. No. 92-03, § 1, 9-28-92; Ord. No. 93-11, § 1, 9-7-93; Ord. No. 95-03, § 1, 6-20-95; Ord. No. 96-12, § 1, 9-3-96; Ord. No. 2005-51, § 1, 11-1-05)  
Sec. 58-39. - Conditions for obtaining building permits. 
(a)  No building permit shall be issued until such time as the following conditions have been met in addition to all other conditions as prescribed by county and city ordinances and resolutions and state statutes. 
(1)  Plans are presented to the city setting forth with specificity the location of water lines that have been installed or will be installed to the property for which the building permit is sought. 
(2)  A right-of-way deed is given to the city encompassing the property to be utilized as a street adjacent to the property for which the building permit is sought. 
(3)  A proposal is submitted to the city by a qualified contractor setting forth the cost of installing the water lines as set forth in subsection (a)(1) of this section. 
(4)  A proposal is submitted to the city by a qualified contractor setting forth the cost of bringing the street or streets up to grade, or paving the street or streets which is or are adjacent to the property for which a building permit is sought. 
(5)  Plans are presented to the city setting forth with specificity the location of areas which will be kept free of parked vehicles in order to facilitate access to buildings by authorized emergency vehicles, as defined by F.S. § 316.033, together with appropriate entrances to the property and appropriate fire lanes and emergency parking areas when property is used as a shopping mall, parking lot, parking garage, planned unit development, mobile home park, industrial or warehouse park or business district or multifamily residential complex or other use which provides for a concentration of buildings within an area of restricted vehicular access. The number of authorized emergency vehicle parking areas and fire access lanes shall be subject to approval by the building inspector and the chief of police taking into consideration the following factors: 
a.  The number of people who are estimated to frequent the property. 
b.  The accessibility of the property by authorized emergency vehicles, including entrance. 
c.  The frequency of calls for emergency services anticipated at the property. 
d.  The need for accessibility to buildings by tenants, vendors, and persons making deliveries to the property. 
e.  Official acts of the county which relate to the particular use of the property as designated by the applicant. 
(6)  All authorized emergency vehicle entrances and parking and fire lanes shall be constructed and maintained in accordance with the approved site plan, building permit, or other requirements of this Code. 
(7)  A bond is posted by the owner of the property for which a building permit is sought in the form of placing with the city a deposit sufficient to cover the cost of construction of the improvements required under this article or a bond issued by a good and sufficient surety in such amount payable to the city and guaranteeing the completion of the improvements set forth in this section. 
(8)  A statement submitted to the city and signed by the landowner that the building permit issued is conditioned upon the improvements set forth in this article being made by the owner and acknowledging that no certificate of occupancy will be issued until such time as such improvements are made. 
(b)  If, within 18 months from the date of issuance of the building permit, the streets described in subsection (a) of this section have not been brought to grade and paved or the water lines described in subsection (a) of this section have not been installed, then, in that event, the city, at its option, may, using the deposit made by the owner, install the water lines and complete the streets or may claim the bond proceeds due and payable and from the proceeds install the water lines or complete the streets by bringing the streets up to grade and paving the streets. 
(c)  If the amount of the deposit or the amount of bond required by this section is insufficient to cover the costs of installation of the water lines or the grading and paving of the streets, then, in that event, upon completion of the work done by the city regarding the installation of water lines or the grading and paving of the streets, there shall be a lien placed upon the property for such amounts as are in excess of the deposit or bond. Should such lien not be paid within 90 days from the date it is placed on the public records, then the city may institute foreclosure procedures and in addition to all sums due be entitled to reasonable attorney fees and costs. 
(Code 1985, § 150.08)  
Sec. 58-40. - Landlord's obligation to maintain premises. 
Unless otherwise agreed in writing, the landlord of a dwelling unit other than a single-family home or duplex shall: 
(1)  At all times during the tenancy of such dwelling unit, make reasonable provisions for: 
a.  The extermination of rats, mice, roaches, ants, wood-destroying organisms, and bedbugs. When vacation of the premises is required for such extermination, the landlord shall not be liable for damages but shall abate the rent. The tenant shall be required to vacate the premises on seven days' written notice, if necessary, for extermination pursuant to this subsection. 
b.  Locks and keys. 
c.  The clean and safe condition of common areas. 
d.  Garbage removal and outside receptacles therefor. 
e.  Heat during winter, running hot and cold water. 
(2)  At the commencement of the tenancy of a dwelling unit other than a single-family home or duplex, make reasonable provisions for smoke detection devices. "Smoke detection device" means an electrical or battery-operated device which detects visible or invisible particles of combustion and which is listed by Underwriters Laboratory, Factory Mutual, or any other nationally recognized testing laboratory utilizing nationally accepted testing standards. 
(Ord. No. 90-16, § 1, 6-12-90)  
Sec. 58-41. - Protection of construction materials and removal of construction waste and debris. 
(a)  Findings. Developers, building contractors, and homeowners who undertake construction and building repair work in the city place and keep construction materials on or about the property where construction or repair work is occurring. South Florida is frequently threatened and affected by tropical storms and hurricanes. During tropical storms and hurricanes, the high winds scatter construction materials, converting such construction materials into potentially deadly missiles which are likely to and do cause injury to life and property. Construction materials which are placed or kept on or about a site where construction or repair work is occurring pose an imminent danger to the health, safety, and welfare of the community. Any individual or enterprise that has control of the property where any construction materials are placed or kept is in a superior position to avoid the risk posed by such construction materials during a tropical storm or hurricane. 
(b)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, as used in this section, shall have the meanings given in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Construction materials includes all lumber, boards, planks, plywood, particle boards, blocks, brick, mortar, cement, rock, conduit, pipe, tubing, floor tile, roof tiles, felt or tar paper, drywall, and sheetrock. 
Construction waste and/or debris means and includes any discarded piece, scraps, and remnants of any lumber, board, plank, plywood, particle board, block, brick, mortar, cement, rock, conduit, pipe, tubing, floor tile, roof tiles, felt or tar paper, drywall, and sheetrock. 
Reasonably clean condition means that there is no accumulation of waste or debris of any kind on the site, whether in a heap, pile, or scattered, except that waste and debris may be placed in an approved dumpster on the site, provided the dumpster is removed and the waste discarded weekly. 
Responsible party means and includes the landowner or homeowner of the site; the developer of the site; any construction manager or superintendent; the general contractor or other qualifier of the project; any architect or engineer who is in a supervisory position, either as a special inspector or as a representative of the owner or developer; and any subcontractor who caused the materials to be brought on to the site. The term shall also include any individual or enterprise that procures a permit for the work. 
Secure means to remove all uninstalled construction materials from any roof or elevated place and to store the materials indoors or on the ground anchored with approved anchors capable of withstanding winds as provided for in the current edition of the South Florida Building Code, in such a manner as to prevent the material from becoming airborne, and shall include bundling or palletizing of materials with strapping, provided the materials are anchored as required under this definition. 
(c)  Site requirements. The following are the requirements for all construction sites: 
(1)  All responsible parties shall keep the site where any construction or building repair is occurring in a reasonably clean condition and free of unsecured construction materials and debris at all times. 
(2)  All construction waste or debris shall be removed from any site where any construction or building repair is occurring within the boundaries of the city, on no less than a weekly basis. 
(3)  No responsible party shall place or keep construction materials in an unsecured manner on any property within the municipal boundaries of the city for a period in excess of ten working days. 
(4)  No responsible party shall place or keep construction materials on any roof or other elevated place above ground level on any property within the municipal boundaries of the city for a period in excess of five working days. 
(5)  No later than ten hours after a storm or hurricane warning is announced by the weather service, all responsible parties shall: 
a.  Remove all construction waste or debris from the property; 
b.  Remove all construction materials from any roof or other elevated place above ground level, causing such materials to be secured on the ground; and 
c.  Secure any and all construction materials. 
(6)  All responsible parties who are in any manner connected with any site where any construction or building repair work is occurring are jointly and severally liable for observing the provisions of this section and for causing all those who are performing any construction or repair work on the site to comply with the provisions of this section. 
(d)  Abatement by city. If any responsible party fails to remove all construction waste or debris, or remove all construction materials from any rooftop or other elevated place above ground level, and cause such materials to be secured on the ground, or to secure all construction materials as required by this section, ten hours after a storm or hurricane warning is announced, the city may take all reasonable and necessary steps to remove all waste and debris and secure the construction materials. If the city is required to remove waste or debris or secure construction materials because a responsible party has failed to do so, the responsible party shall be liable for all costs incurred by the city. 
(e)  Permit applicants to be furnished copy of section. Upon making application for any permit related to construction or building repair, the applicant shall be provided with a copy of this section, and shall execute an acknowledgement that the applicant received a copy of this section and understands it. 
(f)  Penalty. Any person or entity convicted of violating the provisions of this section shall be punished as provided in section 1-16. 
(Ord. No. 95-15, §§ 1—12, 9-19-95) 
Cross reference— Solid waste, ch. 42.  
Secs. 58-42—58-65. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - MOBILE HOMES AND MANUFACTURED BUILDINGS 
 
Sec. 58-66. - Bringing prefabricated structures into the city. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to bring into the territory of the city, without prior consent or approval of the city council, homes, residences, business buildings, and all other structures which have been previously fabricated outside of the territorial limits of the city, in which may reside persons or animals or in which materials may be bought, stored, or deposited, except as those allowed by the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1985, § 153.01)  
Sec. 58-67. - Temporary office trailers. 
Any corporation, company, or individual who is engaged in construction upon which a license or permit has been issued by the city council or building department of the city may bring upon the construction site a construction shed or trailer, so-called, for the purposes of an office or storage place. Such trailer shall not have live-in privileges and shall not be left upon the premises for a period of time in excess of six months from the date of securement of original license or permit without express approval of the city council, but in all cases shall be removed upon completion of the construction. Trailers thereon must bear a legible nameplate of the contractor. 
(Code 1985, § 153.02)  
Sec. 58-68. - Parking of mobile homes. 
No mobile home shall be parked or allowed to remain in the city for a period of time in excess of 24 hours unless the mobile home shall have been shipped to a properly licensed agency, for sale or for lease to a person or corporation outside of the city limits or within the city limits subject to this article. 
(Code 1985, § 153.03)  
Sec. 58-69. - Exclusions. 
This article is not intended to apply to those trailers not intended as mobile homes and, more particularly, to those trailers designated as tractor-trailers which are used principally for field transportation of materials or items from point to point. A home otherwise designated as a mobile home, so-called, may be removed from such category when properly made stationary with full electrical, sewage, and water facilities, with a permanent base within a designated mobile home park, as may be approved by the building department and any other interested departments of the city. All other mobile homes shall be barred within the city by this article. 
(Code 1985, § 153.04)  
Secs. 58-70—58-95. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - FILLING OF LAND 
 
Sec. 58-96. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Property means any real property located in the city, whether vacant or occupied, which includes therein lakes, canals, drainage pits, rock pits, and other water-filled areas. 
(Code 1985, § 156.01) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 58-97. - Compliance required. 
In addition to all other ordinances, resolutions, rules, and regulations governing building permits and filling of property, no property shall be filled in whole or in part without the owner, or the owner's legal representative, of that property complying with the terms and conditions of this article. 
(Code 1985, § 156.02)  
Sec. 58-98. - Permit requirements and restrictions. 
(a)  Application for fill permit. Prior to the filling of any property, the owner or the owner's representative shall: 
(1)  Make application, under oath, for a property fill permit, which application shall include, among other things, a map designating the area of the lake to be filled. 
(2)  State the type of fill to be utilized. 
(3)  Provide a title certificate or a statement by a member of the Florida Bar designating with specificity the name and address of the owner of the property to be filled. 
(b)  Fencing. All properties requiring fill shall be fenced before filling of the land. 
(c)  Dumping. No dumping signs shall be posted at all sites and shall be enforced except where and when authorized permits therefor are granted. The property owner or his designated representative shall obtain the required permit from the appropriate agency. 
(d)  Security barrier. Unless waived by motion of the city council, the property owner or his designated representative, as registered at city hall, shall provide the necessary security for his property by means of a chainlink fence or appropriate barrier to prevent unauthorized dumping after any act of unauthorized dumping and upon notice from the building official or code compliance officer. 
(e)  Dumping materials restricted. Only persons possessing written authorization from a property owner or his representative shall be authorized to dump materials as defined by the department of environmental resource management on any property within the city. 
(f)  Unlawful dumping. In the event police or the building official or code compliance officer determines that an unlawful act of dumping has occurred in violation of this section or any other statute or code having jurisdiction within the city, the building official or code compliance officer shall issue a cease and desist notice to the property owner. All dumping activity shall terminate. A property owner shall have the right to appeal the entry of the order to the mayor and present argument and evidence indicating that the unauthorized or unlawful dumping did not occur. The property owner may enter into a performance bond conditioned upon construction of required fences and security necessary to prevent unauthorized dumping in the penal amount of $25,000.00. The bond in favor of the city shall remain in full force and effect until the property has been filled and graded. The decision of the mayor denying further dumping until compliance with this section shall be final and subject to appeal. 
(g)  Permits to be obtained prior to landfill operations. The property owner or his designated representative shall obtain all required permits prior to any and all operations designed to fill lands for future construction. These shall include municipal, county, state, and federal permits as required for environmentally sensitive land areas. 
(h)  Structure foundations. All structure foundations must be demucked in accordance with the South Florida Building Code. 
(i)  Permitted fill material. Only clean fill, limited to crushed limerock, sand, dirt, concrete screenings, concrete debris, and other environmentally acceptable materials which comply with the South Florida Building Code will be permitted. 
(1)  Concrete debris restrictions. When using concrete debris only solid concrete construction material will be allowed and shall not exceed 18 inches in diameter and will not exceed ten percent of the total fill area. Such concrete debris shall meet the above-stated specifications prior to being delivered and deposited on the site. 
(2)  Areas of dedication. When filling of areas dedicated or proposed to be dedicated as public right-of-way or road purposes, such areas shall be filled in strict accordance with the requirements as set forth in section 30 of the Dade County Standard Road Specifications entitled "Excavation and embankment." 
(3)  Organic materials. Organic materials (i.e., muck, silt, tree debris) shall be completely removed from the areas to be filled as required by the code prior to the addition of the permitted fill to the site. 
(j)  Prohibited fill material. The following materials are not acceptable for use in the filling of land: petroleum products; roofing materials; lumber or wood; furniture; glass; aluminum; trees or parts of trees; cut vegetation; rubber; wire or cable; insulation materials; plastic materials; fabric materials; and trash and garbage. 
(Code 1985, § 156.03; Ord. No. 93-12, § 1, 9-7-93; Ord. No. 94-06, § 1, 10-18-94)  
Sec. 58-99. - Application fee. 
At the time of the filing of the application for a landfill permit, the applicant shall pay a permit fee on file in the city clerk's office. Such fee shall be refunded if the permit is denied. 
(Code 1985, § 156.04)  
Sec. 58-100. - Review of application. 
The application for a landfill permit shall be reviewed by the city council at a public hearing. If the application is in order, and if the request has complied with state statutes, rules, and regulations, county and city ordinances and resolutions, and is in proper form, the permit shall be approved. 
(Code 1985, § 156.05)  
Sec. 58-101. - Duration of permit. 
The permits issued under this article shall be in full force and effect for a period of six months from the date issued. Should filling not commence within such six-month period, then the permit issued under this article shall be considered void. 
(Code 1985, § 156.06)  
Sec. 58-102. - Revocation of permit. 
Any permit issued under this article may be revoked if, in fact, completion of filling does not occur within six months from the date filling of the property commenced. 
(Code 1985, § 156.07)  
Sec. 58-103. - Filling of Samari Lake prohibited. 
The filling of the lake commonly known as Samari Lake shall be prohibited. 
(Code 1985, § 156.08)  
Secs. 58-104—58-130. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - SOIL AND MUCK 
 
Sec. 58-131. - Permit—Required. 
No person shall dig or excavate or cause to be dug or excavated any soil, rock, muck, marl, sand, or fill from any property within the city limits without first having obtained a permit to do so as provided in section 58-132. 
(Code 1985, § 94.25)  
Sec. 58-132. - Same—Application; issuance. 
(a)  No permit required by this article shall be issued except upon and with the approval of the city council. No application for such permit shall be considered unless there is attached to the application a detailed sketch or plan prepared and certified by a civil engineer licensed to practice under the laws of the state, showing the proposed excavation and ultimate development or restoration of the property in such detail as to meet the requirements of the city engineer; nor shall such application be accepted unless and until the detailed sketch or plan has been approved by the city engineer. 
(b)  Each application for a permit under this article shall be filed with the city clerk in writing and verified by oath of the person making the application as to the truth of the statements contained therein. The application shall set forth the name and address of the person owning the property, the legal description and location of the property, the number of cubic yards of material to be excavated or removed, and the purpose thereof. The requirements contained in this section shall be cumulative. 
(Code 1985, § 94.26)  
Sec. 58-133. - Performance bond. 
The city council shall consider the application for a permit under this article and if, in its discretion, the granting of the permit shall not be detrimental to the public safety, health, and welfare of the city, then the city council may, in its discretion, issue or cause to be issued the permit as applied for. However, no permit under this article shall be granted unless and until a performance bond in the form and in an amount approved by the city council has been posted with the city clerk. 
(Code 1985, § 94.27)  
Chapter 62 - COMPREHENSIVE PLAN[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Future land use map, § 78-11. 
 
Sec. 62-1. - Adoption; amendments. 
(a)  The Comprehensive Plan, 1989—2000, is hereby adopted as the official comprehensive plan for 1989—2000 of the city. 
(b)  All development undertaken by and all actions taken with regard to land covered by the comprehensive plan shall be consistent with the plan. All land development regulations which are enacted or amended shall be consistent with the Comprehensive Plan, 1989—2000. 
(c)  Any future land development regulation, land development code, or amendment thereto shall be referred to the city council for review and action thereon. 
(d)  The Comprehensive Plan, 1989—2000, adopted by this section may be amended in accordance with the provisions of the state law and rules, as provided in this section, or as amended in the future. 
(Code 1985, § 151.01)  
Sec. 62-2. - Local planning agency.
